header: siuhy: "Sometimes we just forget to relax and regenerate"
text: The Polish captain said MOUZ learned from their mistakes earlier in the year. After a successful end to the spring season with titles at BetBoom Dacha and ESL Pro League Season 19, MOUZ entered the break as one of the world's top teams. Their early form since returning is encouraging, too, as they placed in the top four at IEM Cologne and the Esports World Cup. Despite their successes, Kamil "siuhy" Szkaradek says the team has worked hard to adjust their approach to avoid a similar burnout to the one they felt at IEM Dallas in May with the goal of hitting peak form just in time for the Shanghai Major. siuhy sat down with HLTV to discuss MOUZ's title chances in Belgrade, their expectations for the rest of the year, and Andreas "Xyp9x" Højsleth's integration into the team ahead of their BetBoom Dacha campaign. I wanted to start by talking about your season so far. You achieved a top-four at the Esports World Cup and a top-four at Cologne, so how are you feeling about those results? The season has been going really well. The only downside was IEM Dallas. I think that is one of the tournaments where we could have performed a lot better but, overall, it has been a really good season for us. I think we can all be proud of it. Now, the goals are a lot higher coming into the next season. We just want to do even better than last time. So far, since the break, you've only lost to Vitality and NAVI, playing them pretty close as well. What do you think you can do to get over that little hump? I think we have a very good base level at the minute, and we are able to compete against the best teams, but for us, I think it matters a lot if we step up on the day. When we do play against a top team like Vitality or NAVI, they will show you no mercy and they will capitalize on the mistakes you make. I think it's very important for us to be there on that day and show the best Counter-Strike we can. If we don't, the best teams in the world will just run you over, and I think that is something we need to work on. At IEM Cologne specifically, how good did it feel to get to a top-four finish at such a prestigious event? The narrative that people like to talk about is that you choke on stage, so how good did it feel to make a top-four? It felt really good, personally. Also for the team, and also for the organization. It's the first time MOUZ has ever won a stage game in Cologne, which is important for them, and I think it was an amazing feeling to do that. Especially also for the fans over there. The fans were amazing, we had our own MOUZ corner and they were great. It was a really great experience to play in front of them and to provide them with the experience that they missed out on in the last years. I'm really happy we were able to do that for them. I think semi-finals in Cologne is definitely not an easy task to do and we did that, but our goals were maybe a little bit higher than that. We were still happy with what we got, and I think it's a good start to the season and it sets us again on a good baseline for the next tournaments. Maybe even a line that we want to be higher above. So we are happy with that. torzsi made some comments recently that, at that tournament, you outplayed and outcalled G2. How does it feel to have that confidence from your teammates, that they really believe in you and your calling? It means a lot. Probably to any player, not only to me specifically. I'm sure that if any player feels that trust and that confidence coming from your teammates, especially, it will mean a lot to you. It just makes you a better player. Who doesn't like confidence, who doesn't like people giving you compliments, you know? Hearing this from your closest friends and teammates boosts you. It allows you to keep up that form. That's what torzsi did and I'm thankful to him. torzsi also played great in that game, so here's me... Passing it back? Exactly, I'm passing it back to him right now. So yeah, it feels great. Coming into this tournament, surely it's one MOUZ are looking to win? Yes, this is a tournament that we are coming into with high expectations for ourselves. At the same time, we also don't want to put pressure on ourselves to win it, but we know this is a good tournament for us to win again and build up a confidence streak similar to last season, when we won EPL and BetBoom. Winning it now, we are looking to create that form again and ride off of it for the rest of the season. Looking forward to the rest of the season, is the big goal just the Major and peaking for that? That is the goal for us. We had long talks before the start of the season. We talked about what we want to achieve this season and we highlighted the most important tournaments for us. We basically created a path on how to reach success and reach the peaks at each tournament. So that is what we are working on as a team, and obviously the most important are the Major, Cologne, all these tournaments, especially those with a crowd. We are on the right path to do that. When it comes to the Major, how important is it to manage your energy and manage those peaks? Maybe Dallas was one of those tournaments where you didn't manage your energy the right way. It's all about regeneration, especially in this team. We are a very young team and we like to have fun a lot of times. We like to do things, explore, and spend a lot of energy. Sometimes, we just forget to relax and regenerate when we know that an important tournament is coming up soon. That's what we are working on this season. We're working closely with our sports psychologists and coaches to make sure we have days when can do nothing, regenerate and relax, to have a fresh mindset coming into the next tournament. I think that's the most important for us because last season, we didn't really put a focus on it, and you could sense that coming into IEM Dallas. We lacked that regeneration. We didn't really know how to do it correctly and coming into Dallas we felt like we were a different team. Now, we're working on it from day one of this season, and to go into a Major it's going to be a very long journey. It's almost a month in China if you're there since the RMRs, so it's going to be very important that we reach our regeneration levels at the right time and reach our peak levels just before the tournament. Last question: You've been working with Xyp9x for a while now, what's that been like for the team? Something new for us, I've personally never had two coaches. Well, two 'coaches', because obviously I had an analyst before, but two coaches that you work closely with and the responsibilities are shared. So there are some things that you approach the assistant coach, which would be Xyp9x, and there are still some things that you approach sycrone with. It's good that we work on making it clear what responsibilities they have, so they are able to help us with one thing, and the other coach is helping us with a different thing. Our relationship in the team with everyone and Xyp9x has been really good so far, he's worked himself to join the team slowly. We didn't really rush him into having high responsibilities from the start. We wanted him to get to know the team and we didn't really want to change the dynamics instantly, we wanted to still be the MOUZ that we know we are, and we wanted him to just join us and make us better with what we already have. That's what he's doing at the minute, he's still slowly getting into the team, and still slowly learning new things. Obviously, it's a new role for him as well, there's still a lot of things for him to learn, but he's doing a really good job. I think he has helped us quite a bit so far, so I think it's going in the right direction with him.

header: 9 Pandas slam FURIA at BetBoom Dacha
text: The Russian team has avoided an early meeting with rivals Aurora and will instead face off against Eternal Fire for a spot in the playoffs. 9 Pandas rounded out the second day of the BetBoom Dacha Belgrade Season 2 Play-in with a statement 2-0 victory over FURIA to send the Brazilian side to the elimination zone. With the win, the Russian squad moved on in the Group B upper bracket to play against Eternal Fire in a match for a place in the Belgrade tournament's playoffs, set to take place on Monday at 18:00 . Meanwhile, FURIA will play for survival against Aurora, who lost to Ismailcan "XANTARES" Dörtkardeş and company earlier on the second day of the play-in stage. In a brief comment to HLTV following the match, Aleksandr "shalfey" Marenov said the achievement against FURIA was "not a big win" for the 9 Pandas, who the in-game leader thinks are being underrated at the moment. "I feel that we are a very strong team, and not everyone right now understands that," he said. "We have a lot of firepower and a lot of good stuff that we can bring to our game." The 42nd-ranked team's Belgrade campaign began just two days after they also successfully traversed the Perfect World Shanghai Major Europe closed qualifier to secure a place at the RMR, despite a last-minute dramatic turn in their trade with Aurora nearly ending in them being unable to use their newest player, Evgeny "r3salt" Frolov. They started off the run in Serbia in more than convincing fashion against FURIA, winning Dust2 13-7 after r3salt led the way to a dominant T side finish, and Mirage 13-8 despite starting off the first half down 2-5.

header: Short news: Week 34
text: The Esports World Cup seems poised to return in 2025, with an announcement on Twitter stating that the Riyadh-based tournament would be hosted in July and August next year. ESL had previously announced tournament dates for 2025 that feature a tournament running from August 20-24, a possible date for EWC's return. Playing Virtus.pro in their deciding Showdown match for a spot in the BLAST Premier Fall Final, Falcons were just about to lose their grip on map one. That was until Álvaro "SunPayus" García clutched the 1v4 in the 23rd round to avert the comeback: After first unveiling Samuel "Zyppe" Martinsson as their new coach, GODSENT have now announced their new all-Swedish Counter-Strike lineup. The team features three members from the organization's former academy team, Young Gods, and looks as follows: Charlie "Cham" Ahlm Leo "Wonder" Wänlund Frank "Fraaank" Issal Liam "MaiL09" Tügel Timmy "Snow" Bruhn Samuel "Zyppe" Martinsson (coach) The organization spared no words of praise when speaking about their talent, saying the team has an ability to "become absolute world-class in a short time" and calling 15-year-old MaiL09 a "true god" and "likely the next Lionel Messi of Swedish CS." On X, BLEED coach Aleksandar "kassad" Trifunović admitted that he is unsure what the future will hold after his team failed to qualify for the Europe RMRs. BLEED were defeated by GamerLegion 2-0 in the final round of the Swiss stage. On Mirage, the second map of the series, they let a 12-3 lead slip before losing the game in overtime. "Embarrassing, really," kassad wrote. "Not sure what's next." Amidst all the RMR chaos, paiN have eliminated Cloud9 from the BLAST Fall Showdown in a two-map series. Rodrigo "biguzera" Bittencourt and company won Nuke 13-8 and then weathered a Cloud9 comeback, started by Kirill "Boombl4" Mikhailov's ace, to win Mirage 13-9. HLTV parent company's tournament organizer AR3NA.GG is hosting a Counter-Strike 2 league for companies all around Europe called COLLEAGUE, which will take place from September 26-December 15. The league's main goal is for colleagues to team up and have fun in a competitive system, but there's a big prize for the winning team too: An all-expenses paid trip to a PSG or FC Barcelona Champions League match. Anyone can sign up for a fee of €150 per company team by September 10. You can find out more on the official website. Citing an overlap with the announced dates of the PGL Shanghai Major RMRs, ESL has moved the scheduled date for ESL Challenger Katowice back nearly one month, from November 22-24 to October 25-27. BIG EQUIPA have announced the temporary addition of Martyna "LETi" Owsik, who will replace Alexandra "kyossa" Tykhonska in the starting lineup. LETi has been without a team since the start of the month, when NAVI Javelins decided to go international. BIG EQUIPA are now: Ana "Zana" Queiroz Jennifer "JennyR" Irina Brea Rodriguez Paulie "pauliiee" Barazani Julia "juliano" Kiran Martyna "LETi" Owsik (temporary) Alexandra "kyossa" Tykhonska (inactive) Jonathan "MusambaN1" Torrent (coach) Romanian tournament organizer PGL is close to acquiring Swedish matchmaking platform Esportal, according to a report from Dust2.se. This comes just weeks after the platform's company, Esportal Group, filed for bankruptcy. According to the same report, Swedish CS legend Tommy "Potti" Ingemarsson will take over Inferno Online, the company's famous LAN centers. Rounds have announced that they have dispensed with the services of Olli "sLowi" Pitkänen. On X, the Finnish organization explained that the team's association with the former HAVU player "did not bring the desired results." "Together with Olli, the team decided it was time to move on," Rounds added. With the 28-year-old's departure, Rounds are now: Panu "p12" Schutschkoff Pekko "p3kko" Korkalainen Ville "Villeboe" Saarela Kosti "Kollo" Kallioniemi "You can wallbang from back of B site to quad theoretically," the map designer added in reply to a question about whether the windows in Checkers are penetrable. Previously, he has shared images of Middle, A site, and B site. 9z will be without head coach Gustavo "tge" Motta for BetBoom Dacha Belgrade Season 2 as he will undergo surgery, Sebastián "siag" Ahumada, the organization's sporting director, revealed on X. The Brazilian coach will be back in time for ESL Pro League 20, which kicks off September 3, siag added. 9z will take on Falcons in the first round of the Play-In's Group A, which also includes paiN and BetBoom. On X, Ulrich "theflyingdj" Schulze, SVP of Game Ecosystems at the ESL FACEIT Group, clarified that the company has not yet made a decision regarding the use of Snap Tap and similar keyboard features in its tournaments. He also cited "miscommunication" in a statement issued to Dust2.us. "Valve have released a detection method that is not available to everyone yet, so we are waiting for this to be the case before aligning our rules with it," he stressed. Schulze then added: "We usually do not define rules when we are missing key information about how to enforce them across the tournaments they apply to (such as, for example, availability and reliability of the detection), which is why we are not doing that right now." Valve has added a small update to CS2, introducing the "Masterminds 2" Music Kit Box to the game, featuring contributions from eight different artists. You can view the (very brief) patch notes here, and listen to snippets of the new Music Kits in the post here. Martin "STYKO" Styk has released a video showing how he consistently lands a popular Mirage jump-thrown smoke: "Am I just lucky or those who are saying it's inconsistent are being skillgap'd?" Russel "Twistzz" Van Dulken has also released a few videos on Twitter from various maps and had a more nuanced take: "Smokes that have room for error are going to be fine, but certain smokes that required a consistent movement are not going to always hit without a bind." IHC have announced the addition of former Evil Geniuses and Copenhagen Flames coach Daniel "Vorborg" Vorborg as an analyst to aid the Mongolian team. Vorborg retired from coaching and co-founded esports agency UNCORE in July. The second IEM Rio Europe open qualifier kicked off on Sunday and only two rounds are left to play, with the best-of-one quarter-finals currently underway before the best-of-three qualifying round kicks off. A highlight match in the quarters has Cloud9 facing off against Ninjas in Pyjamas on Anubis, with ENCE notably missing out after a shameful loss to kONO, a Ukrainian team ranked No. 98 in the world. FAVBET have announced Max "Marix" Kugener as their new fifth, replacing Andrii "guthriee" Havrysh. Marix has dual nationality, sporting the Luxembourgish flag on HLTV but also using the Ukranian flag on Liquipedia. They are now: Vladyslav "bondik" Nechyporchuk Oleksandr "Smash" Turchyn Max "Marix" Kugener Yevhen "j3kie" Serhachov Daniil "t3ns1on" Kashura

header: woxic: "It needs to be the main goal for us to go for first place"
text: After mixed results since the PGL Copenhagen Major, Eternal Fire have their sights set high. After securing a quarter-final finish at PGL Major Copenhagen, Eternal Fire has struggled to replicate their heroics from the all-important Danish event, dropping from 7th to 19th in the world rankings over the past four months, further compounded by a recent early exit from the IEM Cologne Play-in. As such, Engin "MAJ3R" Küpeli's troops are aiming for redemption at BetBoom Dacha Season 2, with the Turkish side already getting off on the right foot with an opening victory over Aurora. Shortly after his team's victory over Aurora, Eternal Fire AWPer Özgür "woxic" Eker spoke with HLTV regarding the match versus the Russian side, Eternal Fire's aspirations for the event, and how the team has dealt with their decline in form since the Copenhagen Major. Congratulations, what are you feeling after that series? At the start I was not feeling good, but in the end, when you are bouncing back and managing to come back to this kind of games, I feel happy. I wasn't personally ready for the first map, because I had a stomach issue and I came too late to the computer. So I had like one or two minutes to warm up, because we had to go and walk and after that we just started instantly. It's not an excuse, we should have won that first map as well if we did not do small mistakes in clutch situations, or in entering site situations. So yeah, I'm feeling happy about the result. So was it just small mistakes that threw the 10-5 lead on Mirage? Yeah just small mistakes, not understanding each other, little communication issues, these kind of things happened to us. Also aiming issues I personally had in the first map, kills I should get I didn't, which also affected the game. Maybe it also happened for the other guys, but I don't know from their perspective. I had to do my best to come back on the second and third map, I just kept my motivation and my mental. Is this a type of tournament that Eternal Fire aim to win? Yeah of course. First we need to qualify, and after that we should win this kind of event. Of course, maybe you cannot win a Major, Pro League, or these kinds of IEM tournaments, but this kind of tournament, it needs to be the main goal for us to go for first place. I think we can do it, if we just do what we did in the last two maps, if we just do this for all of the tournament, I think we can beat anybody. Eternal Fire had a big peak at the start of the year, you had a really good finish at the Major and hit your best HLTV ranking, but things have fallen off since then. What do you think has happened there? I think after the break our performance went down a bit. We were showing good Counter-Strike and we were feeling very nice inside of the team, but after that, the bad result after bad result, we lost our confidence a bit. We've just overall redone our tactics and playbook, everything we just switched up or changed. Small changes, if there's a smoke for example, we are changing the smoke so it won't land on that timing, these kinds of things. I think we are going to show our good side of Counter-Strike, like we did before, and I think we are not far away from that because we are working really hard at the moment. So I think we are going to get the prize in the end. Do you think, once you hit the peak at the Major, the motivation dropped off a bit after that? When there's a Major, it's like you are, personally and as a team, having a different kind of mindset. Mentally you just want to win that tournament, or do as much as you can, because it's a Major, it's a legendary event. In the other events when we fell off after that, like in India or in Abu Dhabi, even the TeamSpeak is not the same as when we were playing in the Major games. I think this is our minus side. If we improve that, we will not get these kind of results in this kind of tournament.

header: HLTV Confirmed: RMR qualifiers, NiKo rumors, Showdown results
text: Join the show from Chad "SPUNJ" Burchill, Milan "Striker" Švejda, and Zvonimir "Professeur" Burazin are back online for your favorite Counter-Strike show, discussing a combination of results and rumors from the scene. The big one is the returning rumor about Nikola "NiKo" Kovač going to Falcons, as well as a business one about PGL set to acquire Esportal. Results-wise, Striker rejoices as the Czech scene makes a huge step forward with three teams qualifying for the RMR, but we also discuss teams that faltered at the early stage of online qualification such as ENCE, Monte, and BLEED. However, the latter two are back in contention after a dramatic turn of events and the PARIVISION disqualification. A lot of opinions coming tonight, the full topic list is: Recent news- Chopper dismisses Spirit changes- NiKo to Falcons back on the table?- PGL reportedly set to acquire Esportal- HLTV Attributes introduced- Skinionaire RMR qualifiers- PARIVISION disqualification- r3salt transfer saga- Czech success!- What are the odds?- ENCE, Monte*, BLEED* out Showdown- +FaZe, Falcons, -VP, COL Live broadcast on TwitchUpdates and clips on TwitterPast HLTV Confirmed episodesAudio versions of the show

header: Media: NiKo to join Falcons after Shanghai Major
text: Falcons are reportedly due to make their second attempt for NiKo stick after failing the first in late 2023. G2 superstar Nikola "NiKo" Kovač is on course to joining Falcons after the ongoing season concludes at the Perfect World Shanghai Major, multiple reports suggest. French streamer and leaker Sebastien "KRL" Perez first said on Saturday that G2 and Falcons reached an agreement to transfer the Bosnian at the beginning of 2025 and that the deal only hinged on a signature from NiKo. A Sheep Esports report followed two days later with the information that the agreement was accepted on Monday and that the transfer is worth between $1 to $1.2 million. It also says that NiKo plans to accept a three-year contract with Falcons starting on January 1. This is the second time that Falcons are after NiKo. When the Saudi Arabian organization's ambitious new roster was being built at the end of 2023, the Bosnian was all but confirmed to join the likes of Emil "Magisk" Reif and Marco "Snappi" Pfeiffer on the roster, until he decided to stay with G2 for the 2024 season in a last-minute U-turn. After failing to land the No. 2 player of 2023, Falcons have struggled to make good on the high ambitions they set after landing Magisk and Danny "zonic" Sørensen from Vitality in a bid to create a new Counter-Strike superpower. Their best result in 2024 remains a top-four finish at IEM Katowice from the beginning of the year, when Falcons still featured Mohammad "BOROS" Malhas on the roster. The Jordanian was replaced on the team by Peter "dupreeh" Rasmussen just two months later in the aftermath of their failure to qualify for PGL CS2 Major Copenhagen, but the change has done little to improve their results. In their five months with the 31-year-old, Falcons failed to make it to the playoffs at three consecutive Big Events and only achieved modest success in smaller tournaments with a top-four finish at BetBoom Dacha Belgrade and second place at ESL Challenger Jönköping. Falcons are currently deep into their campaign at the second edition of BetBoom Dacha Belgrade, having just qualified for the playoffs. They're also playing for a spot at IEM Rio in the European closed qualifier, which runs concurrently with the event taking place in Serbia. G2 and Falcons declined to comment on the matter after being contacted by HLTV.

header: Falcons get revenge on 9z to book BetBoom Dacha playoff spot
text: Snappi's troops put their experience to use in another elimination series as they brushed aside the South American side. Falcons have booked a spot in the main stage of BetBoom Dacha Belgrade Season 2 thanks to a 2-0 victory over 9z in Group A's consolidation final, exacting revenge for Saturday's 2-1 defeat in the opening round. It was a dominant display from Marco "Snappi" Pfeiffer's charges, who once again found a way to play their best game in an elimination series, like Emil "Magisk" Reif had suggested. They came back from 7-2 down on Dust2 and then hammered 9z on their own map pick, where they posted a flawless CT half. "Tired of losing," Falcons coach Danny "zonic" Sørensen said after the series. "We need to get the grind up. When you're losing, you have to play more. That's how it is. The guys are putting in a lot of work and we're professional. We're tired of losing and we really want to get more Ws." 9z will be disappointed with the way their Belgrade campaign came to an end. They started the match brightly and looked comfortable on Falcons' map pick of Dust2. But a blunder from Maximiliano "max" Gonzalez late in the first half seemed to breathe life into the European team. Falcons ended the half down by just two rounds, and they quickly dispatched their opponents in the second half, ending the game on an 11-2 run. Carrying their momentum into Mirage, Falcons went 12-0 on the CT side before putting the series to bed just two rounds into the second half. 9z will now have a few days to lick their wounds and process this latest European defeat before returning to action in ESL Pro League 20. As for Falcons, they will take on paiN on Tuesday in Group A's final before entering the playoffs, where they will join the Brazilian side, MOUZ, Spirit, Virtus.pro, HEROIC and two more teams.

header: BnTeT's Alter Ego among 11 teams to pass final Asia RMR open qualifiers
text: All five sub-regions in Asia have now reached the closed qualifier stage on the road to the Perfect World Shanghai Major. Open qualifiers on the road to the Shanghai Major in East Asia and Rest of Asia have concluded with five teams passing through to the closed stage in the former sub-region and six teams in the latter. Among those who made it in Rest of Asia are Alter Ego featuring some well-known names from the region, including former TYLOO duo Hansel "BnTeT" Ferdinand and WingHei "Freeman" Cheung and ex-MVP PK star Hyun-Pyo "XigN" Lee. The mixed roster won the open qualifier and joined invited sides True Rippers and Gods Reign and five other qualified teams in the closed qualifier, where they'll fight it out for an Asia RMR spot from August 28-30. Rest of Asia closed qualifier (August 28-30) In East Asia, three East Russian and two Mongolian sides traversed the open qualifier to join Chinggis Warriors, ATOX and GR in the closed qualifier, which will also be played from August 28-30. In a rather absurd turn of events, Glamour made it to the closed qualifier despite the fact that they were forced to forfeit their quarter-final matchup at the beginning of the second day due to one of their players being asleep. The Russian side ended up winning the fifth-place decider bracket with two consecutive victories just a few hours later. East Asia closed qualifier (August 28-30) The two qualifiers were the last of a series of seven open tournaments which fed teams into the five Asian sub-regions' closed qualifiers along with the Valve Regional Standings. Previously the Chinese, Middle Eastern, and Oceanic closed qualifiers had their full team lists completed. Each of these will also qualify one team for the Asia RMR, which will take place in Shanghai, China from November 11-14 and offer three spots at the Perfect World Shanghai Major. China closed qualifier (August 27-29) Oceania closed qualifier (August 27-29) Middle East closed qualifier (August 28-30)

header: SunPayus: "I haven't been performing, but it's a matter of time"
text: Despite his and his team's recent improvements, SunPayus expects more. Falcons have enjoyed a mini-resurgence in recent weeks, playing solid Counter-Strike at IEM Cologne before qualifying for BLAST Fall Final thanks to a near-flawless run through Showdown. The European combine continued this uptick in form in Belgrade by qualifying for the main event at BetBoom Dacha Season 2, taking down BetBoom before emphatically dusting off 9z, avenging a loss to the South Americans earlier in the competition. Álvaro "SunPayus" García sat down with HLTV after securing a spot alongside MOUZ and Spirit in the BB Dacha main event to give an interview, and he spoke about his team's recent improvements, his own form, and the team's expectations for the rest of the tournament. Congratulations, you've made it through to the main event. How are you guys feeling? We are feeling really good. We are playing so many officials these days, since we came to Serbia, so I think we are just getting better and better, and getting used to making fewer mistakes. So yeah, we are pretty happy. Speaking about this game specifically: 9z beat you earlier in the event, what allowed you to turn it around and get a different result this time? They beat us because I think they played great on the third map, on Nuke. They played a really good T side, but we didn't actually convert some CT rounds that we had an advantage in, so, in the end, it was a really close match. We knew it was our first official here and we didn't play well. After we got some officials rolling and we fixed some mistakes from that match, we just improved quite a lot from that day to today. Specifically on Mirage they beat you 13-5 the first time around, and it was a complete change of result today. Do you think it was to do with playing more officials, or did you play any differently? Yeah, we actually had… not a long talk, but a mini-talk, about 10 minutes, about how our CT defaults would look, how we should move around the map. So we put some new agreements in place so we are more dynamic on the map, and that's why I think we played much better. Yesterday we also played another tournament, against VP, and we played much better also against them. We are good on CT-side Mirage now (laughs). Like you said, you have been playing a lot of officials at the moment. How has it been for you? Obviously, a little bit tiring, but it looks like you are improving. I think it's good just because we want to get as ready as possible for the Shanghai Major. We were practicing a lot and we were playing okay, but all of a sudden in officials we were not playing as well, so zonic and Snappi decided to play more, so we came here and we have also these online tournaments. Yeah, I think it's really tiring but also nice, because I can see the development from the team pretty fast. I spoke to Magisk yesterday and I asked him about the team, because you guys are improving and it feels like you're on the right track at the moment, but your personal form also seems to have picked up since the start of Falcons. How are you feeling right now? Well right now I don't think I'm on a good level, the team is getting better and as the team gets better I will also play better. Obviously I know what I'm capable of, and it also happened to me when I joined ENCE, for the first six months I didn't perform. Right now, these six months, I haven't been performing, but I know myself and it's a matter of time. I just need to keep smiling, keep my good attitude, and keep moving on. Watching from the outside it feels like you are picking the rifle up a little bit more. Is that a conscious decision, or how has that come about? Well, I like to play rifle, too, I think every AWPer is also really good with a rifle. It's not a decision, but if we start a match, we are 4-0, I am feeling the rifle and we are having good economy… if I feel like we don't need to pull out the AWP because it's not needed yet, then I don't pick it up. It also depends on the map, I might need to take the AWP out much more. Is this a tournament Falcons are looking to win, or go deep in? Right now I don't think we have really high expectations. There are really good teams in the next stage, and our main goal is to get ready as much as we can for the Major, so we are taking these officials as practice. Our goal is just to keep playing officials.

header: Sources: PARIVISION's RMR disqualification overturned after appeal**
text: F_1N appealed his ban with ESIC months ago, but the esports watchdog failed to share its decision with Valve at the time, sources tell HLTV. Update 03:15 : In a statement to HLTV, ESIC denied that they directly reduced F_1N's ban, but that an "Independent Appeal Panel (independent of ESIC) has recently both accepted and made a decision with respect to a significantly out of time appeal by F_1N and communicated the same to Valve." The decision is expected to be published on ESIC's website within 24 hours. ESIC added: "It seems that Perfect World was not aware of F_1N’s appeal to ESIC’s independent appeal panel when making their decision to disqualify the team “PARIVISION”. Perfect World has recently reached out to ESIC to confirm the details of the appeal and the decision made." HLTV's sources however say F_1N's demerit points were updated after his appeal months prior and that the decision was not communicated to Valve nor Perfect World until recent events. Update 22:04 : Monte's assistant coach, Piotr "nawrot" Nawrocki, has confirmed on X that a tournament admin informed teams that there will be no last-chance qualifier. PARIVISION will be allowed to compete at the Perfect World Shanghai Major Europe RMR after successfully arguing its case with organizers, multiple sources with knowledge of the situation tell HLTV. The Russian team was disqualified from the competition due to having a Valve-banned individual, coach Ivan "F_1N" Kochugov, present during their closed qualifier campaign. The 40-year-old and accompanying staff surrounded the team in a now-deleted celebratory video after PARIVISION beat GamerLegion in their 2-1 qualifying match. F_1N was among over 30 coaches banned by the Esports Integrity Commission (ESIC) in 2020 for using the infamous coaching bug. He was found to have used it in six official matches for 34 rounds, resulting in a nine-month ban from ESIC member events and a permanent ban from Valve Majors based on his total demerit points. However, sources tell HLTV that the Russian coach successfully appealed his ban with ESIC's independent appeal panel and had his demerit points reduced earlier this year, and that the esports watchdog did not announce or share its decision with external parties until after PARIVISION's disqualification took place. With a reduction in demerit points, F_1N would fall below the six-point cut-off for a permanent suspension by Valve and be allowed to return to Majors, which now appears to be the reality after Valve were reportedly made aware of ESIC's decision. As a result, the two last-chance qualifier matches that were scheduled to determine a replacement for PARIVISION are expected to be canceled, leaving KOI, Monte, and BLEED out of Major contention once again.

header: Eternal Fire through to BB Dacha playoffs; Aurora eliminated
text: Just one more group-stage spot remains up for grabs. Eternal Fire are through to the main stage of BetBoom Dacha Belgrade Season 2 following a 2-0 win over 9 Pandas in the Group B upper-bracket final. Earlier in the day, Aurora were eliminated by FURIA, who now have one more chance to make it to the group stage tomorrow. The Turkish side joins paiN and Falcons in qualifying for the group stage, where Spirit, MOUZ, Virtus.pro, and HEROIC await the four Play-in teams. Just one more spot remains up for grabs, and it is set to be decided between 9 Pandas and FURIA. The teams already met in the upper-bracket semi-final, where 9 Pandas were able to get the better of the Brazilians, sparking a war of words between Aleksandr "shalfey" Marenov and Gabriel "FalleN" Toledo. Their rematch will happen on Tuesday at 14:30 . Eternal Fire met 9 Pandas in a late-night match due to the Turkish side previously playing in the Europe IEM Rio qualifier, where they progressed to the upper-bracket final after 2-0 wins against B8 and Cloud9. Eternal Fire's game against 9 Pandas was equally straightforward, with two dominant CT sides on Nuke (9-3) and Anubis (10-2) paving their way to the BB Dacha group stage. The Turkish side's play-in campaign isn't done after the victory, though, as they will face off against the winner of FURIA vs. 9 Pandas for seeding purposes and $10,000. Before the qualification bout, the Group B action began with an elimination clash between teams in dire form. Aurora came into the game by winning one out of their last eight matches, while FURIA won one out of five. The series began on Mirage, where FURIA couldn't handle Denis "deko" Zhukov's AWP, as the sniper racked up a 1.70 rating on the map. His team wasn't able to hold on to the lead, however, allowing FURIA to put together a nine-round Inferno T side to tie up the score. The Nuke decider was another close-fought affair, but FURIA's offensive half was once again enough for the FalleN-led squad to stay alive in Belgrade after a 13-9 victory.

header: RED Canids, Fluxo, Legacy facing elimination after first day of Americas RMR qualifiers
text: Eight teams are already out of Shanghai Major contention across the two Americas qualifiers. The first day of closed qualifiers for the Americas RMR has reached its end with eight teams eliminated across North and South America. The brutal format of the qualifiers, which use a Swiss system to determine four out of 16 teams who advance, means that teams are eliminated after just two losses rather than three. Two teams advance from the 3-0 pool and two from the 3-1 pool, with a fourth-place decider played between the 3-1 teams with the lower Bucholz scores for the final spot. This resulted in some early strife for the three highest-ranked teams in the South America qualifier — ODDIK, RED Canids, and Fluxo — as they were narrowly upset in their opening best-of-one games and cast down to the 0-1 pool. All three stabilized in series play, with Fluxo bagging a convincing 2-0, ODDIK winning two one-sided maps in a reverse-sweep, and Marcelo "coldzera" David's side coming closest to an early exit and only barely scraping past Intense 2-1. Two qualification matches and four elimination matches will take place on day two of the SA qualifier, with the matchups looking as follows: 2-0 advancement pool 1-1 elimination pool The first two rounds of the NA qualifier played out much as expected, although NRG faced some early trouble from Akimbo in a 13-10 win before easing past Elevate to make the 2-0 pool. BOSS was awarded a forfeit win in their opening round after a player from Take Flyte was stuck in traffic and couldn't arrive in time for the match, and converted that into a 2-0 record after edging past Gabriel "NEKIZ" Schenato's Legacy 13-10 on Anubis, casting the Brazilian team down to the 1-1 elimination pool. The matchups for day two of the NA qualifier are: 2-0 advancement pool 1-1 elimination pool

header: Official: PARIVISION's RMR disqualification overturned
text: Tournament organizer Perfect World cite a "newly communicated ESIC appeal process" that meant F_1N was allowed to be around the PARIVISION squad. PARIVISION will compete at the Shanghai Major EU RMR after their disqualification was overturned by Perfect World, confirming a report by HLTV. The decision means the EU Last Chance Qualifier, scheduled for August 27 featuring the three 2-3 teams KOI, Monte, and BLEED, is no longer required and has been cancelled. PARIVISION were initially barred from flying to Shanghai by Perfect World after posting celebrations on social media that showed coach Ivan "F_1N" Kochugov, then believed to be serving a permanent ban from Valve events, present with the team. F_1N was one of 37 coaches suspended in 2020 for using the infamous coach bug in six official matches for 34 rounds. That was enough to earn a permanent ban from Valve, while the Esports Integrity Commission (ESIC) barred him from their member events for nearly nine months. His ban has now been cut short after what ESIC called a "special evaluation of the significantly out-of-time appeal." The appeal, posted four years after the sentence was handed out, proved successful after a review by ESIC's Independent Appeal Chair "based on the appeal’s merits and the compelling evidence provided by him." "This change has been communicated to and accepted by Valve." This process was not made public until today, but F_1N's status was not communicated to Perfect World immediately upon its conclusion. Upon receiving this information, the TO overturned PARIVISION's ban and re-instated their place at the EU RMR. Valve's Major rulebook, section Stage Integrity, sub-section Team staff restrictions says: "In the case of any matches where event admins are not physically present (e.g. online matches), no team staff, including the coach, may be physically or virtually present or communicate with the players at any time during the match." Having any staff other than players present in the room during online matches is still against the rules, according to the excerpt from Valve's Major rulebook above. This alone, however, was not the reason behind the original decision to bar PARIVISION from participating in the RMR, with Perfect World focussed on F_1N's status as a banned individual. HLTV has reached out to ESIC to inquire about when the appeal process was completed and when it was communicated to Valve, but did not receive a response at the time of the article's release.

header: PGL to host events in Argentina, Kazakhstan, and more in 2025-26 circuit
text: Buenos Aires, Bucharest, Astana, and Belgrade will host four Valve-ranked PGL events in 2025 with a prize pool of $1,250,000 each. PGL has announced details for eleven tier-one events around the globe over the next two years, including annual events in Astana, Kazakhstan and Buenos Aires, Argentina. The circuit will also see the Romanian tournament organizer host events in Bucharest, Belgrade, and — in 2026 — São Paulo and Barcelona. The capacity for more is also present, with PGL pledging "other surprises" in addition to these 11 initial events. See the full calendar for the next twelve months at hltv.org/calendar The operator has hosted no standalone events in recent years, with calendar space restricted by the semi-franchised ESL and BLAST circuits, but hosted three Valve Majors (Stockholm, Antwerp, and Copenhagen) and is partnered with Perfect World for the CS Asia Championships and a fourth Major in Shanghai this November. With Valve removing direct team-to-TO partnerships from 2025 onwards, PGL are re-entering the space aggressively with a minimum of eleven events in the next two years. Six will be run by PGL on their own, in addition to four events in partnership with FiReSPORTS and a continuation of their Perfect World partnership with CS Asia Championships 2025. "PGL is pleased to announce that the CS2 competitive landscape has evolved, embracing a more open and inclusive approach," the TO said in a press release. "This change marks a pivotal moment in esports, democratizing event organization and fostering a more vibrant and diverse competitive scene." Each 16-team event will have a Major-matching prize pool of $1.25 million, and a budget of $450,000 for hospitality purposes including tickets, accommodation for 8 people, food, and six-person practice rooms for each invited team. They will also function as 'Ranked' events in line with Valve's new rulebook. Invites for the events will be handed out directly based on the global Valve Regional Standings (VRS), with no open qualifiers because of the "very busy event schedule." If a roster declines the invite, or cannot secure visas in time, it will be extended to the next roster in the VRS until all slots are filled. The exception to the global invite system will be the three South American events, where the top two teams from the home region will be invited in addition to 14 intercontinental invites. All events will sport a best-of-three Swiss system group stage and eight-team single elimination playoff brackets with a best-of-five grand final. PGL has announced venues for their first eight events, with the exception of 2026's São Paulo and Barcelona events. They include Buenos Aires' 3300-capacity Teatro Gran Rex in 2025, before moving to the larger 15,510-capacity Estadio Mary Terán de Weiss in 2026. There is also the 11,578-seater Barys Arena in Astana, and the 20,000 Belgrade Arena for the two Serbian events. PGL Bucharest, however, will not feature a crowd and be played in the TO's studios. The preliminary event schedule is as follows: 2025 PGL on FiRe Buenos Aires - February 13-23 PGL Bucharest - April 3-13 PGL Astana - May 8-18 PGL Belgrade - October 23 - November 2 Perfect World CS Asia Championships - October 1-13 2026 PGL on FiRe Buenos Aires - February 12-22 PGL Bucharest - April 2-12 PGL Astana -  May 7-17 PGL Belgrade - August 6-16 PGL on FiRe São Paulo - October 1-11 PGL on FiRe Barcelona 2026  - October 22 - November 1

header: FURIA take revenge on 9 Pandas to secure final BetBoom Dacha playoffs spot
text: FalleN said he was looking forward to the rematch against a "not that good" 9 Pandas side and delivered on his promise with a 1.65-rated performance. FURIA have claimed the final spot in the BetBoom Dacha Belgrade Season 2 playoffs after securing a 2-0 win over 9 Pandas at the end of the play-in stage. In the rematch from the opening round, where 9 Pandas had battered FURIA on two maps, the Brazilians responded in kind as Gabriel "FalleN" Toledo delivered on some fighting words he had brought to the game. In a reply to Aleksandr "shalfey" Marenov's claim that 9 Pandas' opening triumph against FURIA was "not a big win," the veteran AWPer said to Esports.gg that he was looking forward to the rematch because 9 Pandas were "not that good." FalleN went on to dominate the Russian side with a scoreboard-topping 46-22 K-D performance (1.65 rating). Inferno was a straightforward affair with FURIA putting on a 10-round CT side, while on Dust2 the Brazilians fought off a 9 Pandas comeback from 6-12 to secure the game in overtime. The Brazilians are still due to play a best-of-one match for first place in the group against Eternal Fire, which will have a higher seeding going into the playoffs up for grabs. From Wednesday, FURIA will join the likes of MOUZ and Spirit in a double-elimination bracket.

header: G2 recover from map one defeat to smash FaZe
text: A G2 risk to ban Inferno and leave Mirage in the pool paid off in a 13-6 decider. The new G2 has continued its strong form by toppling FaZe 2-1 and securing a spot in Group C's final, putting them one series from Fall Final. That was despite dropping Ancient 13-9, G2's pick and the map Nikola "NiKo" Kovač and company had a six-map winning streak on. By the time we moved to Nuke, however, G2's individuals had warmed up and the result was utter domination. It was a statement series for the under-pressure Nemanja "huNter-" Kovač, who ended top of the board with a 1.33 rating. He now has a 1.26 rating for the event, his best average since the Copenhagen RMR and far above his 1.04 CS2 average. "Since CS2 I'm really playing a lot, that's not an issue,"  huNter- said post-match. "When you make some changes, you want to show them that you're the player that everyone remembers and be a good example to the other players. As long as we are winning I don't care about my own performance." Mario "malbsMd" Samayoa was the key man on Nuke, despite having four negative ratings in a row on the map for G2 and M80 as the Ramp anchor and Lobby lurker beforehand. The Guetamalan took over proceedings after a quad-kill on the MP9 in a confidence-filled display as he continues to prove both his talent and his versatility. He ended the half 17-3, and shone as the sides switched too with a sensational Deagle double-entry into Ramp — the second fully blind, and requiring an inch-perfect 90 degree snap. Map three was Mirage, G2's permaban under Rasmus "HooXi" Nielsen, and eyebrows were raised on the desk after G2 chose Mirage over their usual pick of Inferno. "We are practicing Mirage a lot and we are comfortable there," NiKo had said pre-game. "We haven't played it much as well, so it's good to have Mirage officials under our belt." If it was intended as practice in a non-elimination match at a fairly low-stakes event, Mirage could not have gone better for G2 as they sat FaZe down by rushing to a 9-0 lead with eight rounds in a row that denied a bomb plant, and 13-6 win. It does not mean, however, that G2 are turning away from Inferno, according to NiKo: "Inferno has been our best map, one of our best ever since I joined G2. Snax kind of has to get used to it, it's stupid not to play it when we're already really good at it." FaZe now drop to the lower bracket against one of Cloud9 or Ninjas in Pyjamas as they look to combat their slide down the rankings. Only David "frozen" Čerňanský put up any significant resistance on Nuke and Mirage, and after a poor Esports World Cup by their standards the FaZe team have a fight on their hands to return to the level required by their lofty standards. A rematch against G2 is still possible, in a match that will decide which Group C team qualifies for Fall Final early.

header: bobeksde joins Johnny Speeds
text: The former GODSENT player replaces Lekr0 after filling in for the Swedes in the past few months. Johnny Speeds have announced the addition of Jonatan "bobeksde" Persson. The 20-year-old replaces Jonas "Lekr0" Olofsson, who left the organization-less side to join Ladislav "GuardiaN" Kovács's BC.Game roster on Monday. William "draken" Sundin has also taken over in-game leadership in the team in the aftermath of the former captain Lekr0's departure. bobeksde's arrival looks like a no-brainer after he has already been seen filling in for Johnny Speeds for various members since April. Most recently he helped the Swedes win titles in Svenska Eliteserien Spring 2024 Finals and European Pro League 2nd Division Season 13. He also has further previous experience playing alongside Kalle "Ro1f" Johansson and Olle "spooke" Grundström from his last official team, GODSENT, and from his previous outing with PROSPECTS. Johnny Speeds now are: William "draken" Sundin Hugo "chawzyyy" Günther Kalle "Ro1f" Johansson Olle "spooke" Grundström Jonatan "bobeksde" Persson Christian "chrille" Lindberg (coach)

header: Lekr0 and pr1metapz complete BC.Game roster
text: BC.Game complement their talent with some much-needed experience in Lekr0 as their in-game leader. BC.Game have announced the completion of their new Counter-Strike roster with the signings of Jonas "Lekr0" Olofsson and Luca "pr1metapz" Voigt. The newly founded organization previously unveiled the signings of coach Ladislav "GuardiaN" Kovács, AWPer Guy "anarkez" Trachtman, and riflers Aleksandar "CacaNito" Kjulukoski and Joel "joel" Holmlund over the past week. Lekr0 joins the squad from Johnny Speeds. Formed earlier this year around the former GODSENT, NIP and fnatic veteran and William "draken" Sundin, the Swedish team made waves in recent months by winning seven local and lower-tier competitions. Despite their successes they remained without an organization, and playing on no salary for the past six months played a big factor in the decision to move on, Lekr0 has said in a comment to HLTV. He however stressed his belief in the new BC.Game roster. "It is a team with solid players and a coach I have a lot of respect for, so I believe we can go very far," he said. "The team is looking long term and that's what I believe in as well. BC.Game asked me a lot of times before deciding I'm gonna make this move." pr1metapz recently made headlines as part of a 5W roster also featuring another BC.Game member, joel, which fell apart within a month from its formation amidst allegations that the Indian organization "scammed" its players and ceased communication. Before that, the 23-year-old German most notably played two stints for BIG Academy, among other German-majority sides. "After the 5W Project I was pretty confident in finding a new home fast since we as a team and me as an individual played good CS," pr1metapz said to HLTV. "Being able to get picked by these extremely experienced players like Lekr0 made me super happy since it's the perfect opportunity to develop even more. I'm excited about the future in BC.Game and will do my best to show my true potential." BC.Game are: Guy "anarkez" Trachtman Aleksandar "CacaNito" Kjulukoski Joel "joel" Holmlund Jonas "Lekr0" Olofsson Luca "pr1metapz" Voigt Ladislav "GuardiaN" Kovács (coach)

header: EYEBALLERS sign 17-year-old poiii: "He's Sweden's next superstar"
text: JW heaped praise on his team's new addition, who has impressed with Lilmix in 2024. EYEBALLERS have rounded out their roster with former Lilmix player Alex "poiii" Nyholm Sundgren, the Swedish organization announced on Monday. The 17-year-old effectively replaces Anton "Sapec" Palmgren, who parted ways with EYEBALLERS in early June to join Metizport. Robin "flusha" Rönnquist was standing in for the squad in the meantime, and he now takes a step back once again. poiii was hailed as "Sweden's next superstar" in the announcement by EYEBALLERS CEO and teammate Jesper "JW" Wecksell. After joining Lilmix in February with little prior experience, the youngster has averaged a 1.26 rating over 25 maps recorded on HLTV and achieved a near 4,000 ELO peak on FACEIT. But the team says they've had their eye on the newcomer for longer than that, from just after the launch of the organization in 2022. "When we had just started the team, we went to DreamHack to meet our fans. At that weekend Alex showed up and challenged us to shootouts in the JBL booth and won a shirt," JW said in a statement on EYEBALLERS' website. "Somewhere in there, I think he decided to focus on Counter-Strike." Joining EYEBALLERS brings with it poiii's first opportunity to focus on Counter-Strike full time. To do so, he is taking a break from high school with the support of his family. "EYEBALLERS have been incredibly professional in their dialogue with me and my parents, who are very important to me in my adventure. Having support from home means everything," poiii said. "I am very grateful for this chance to play with legendary players like Golden and JW who have lifted the biggest trophies together. I know I have to work hard to one day be as succesful as them." EYEBALLERS now have: Jesper "JW" Wecksell Peppe "Peppzor" Borak Ludvig "HEAP" Alonso Maikil "Golden" Selim Alex "poiii" Nyholm Sundgren Kevin "Kevve" Bohlin (coach)

header: HooXi benched in G2
text: The in-game leader follows nexa to the chopping block as G2 look to shake things up further in this off-season. Rasmus "HooXi" Nielsen has been removed from G2's starting roster, the organization announced in a farewell video on Monday. The in-game leader's removal is the second change in the G2 camp in the summer off-season. The organization replaced Nemanja "nexa" Isaković with former M80 up-and-comer Mario "malbsMd" Samayoa on Friday. HooXi's replacement is not yet known. It is however likely finalized given that the roster submission deadline for the upcoming Esports World Cup, where G2 are slated to play, is today (Monday, July 1). HooXi joined G2 in the summer of 2022 from Copenhagen Flames. His two-year tenure got off to a poor start as the team failed to qualify for the IEM Rio Major, but the Dane went on to lead the organization to its first Big Event trophy since 2017 at the BLAST Premier World Final just two months later. That victory kickstarted a brief run of dominance which saw G2 go on a streak of 13 consecutive Big Event match wins and claim the title at IEM Katowice in the process. In the second half of 2023, G2 also lifted another highly-coveted trophy at IEM Cologne. But while they made nearly every playoffs, titles eluded HooXi following the triumph in Germany last August. G2's only victory came at IEM Dallas this May while Jake "Stewie2K" Yip was playing instead of HooXi, which came as a further indictment on the already heavily scrutinized in-game leader. Exchanging Justin "jks" Savage for nexa at the brink of the year did little to change their fortunes, the Serbian was shown the exit door just six months later to make space for malbsMd, and HooXi now follows to the chopping block. The only question that remains is who will come in to replace the Dane. Is it going to be another in-game leader, or will G2 give the reins to Nikola "NiKo" Kovač following his success as the temporary captain in Dallas? After the series of changes, G2 are down one man: Nemanja "huNter-" Kovač Nikola "NiKo" Kovač Ilya "m0NESY" Osipov Mario "malbsMd" Samayoa Wiktor "TaZ" Wojtas (coach) Nemanja "nexa" Isaković (benched) Rasmus "HooXi" Nielsen (benched)

header: TSM sign trio to complete Danish roster
text: acoR, niko, and Altekz have landed on TSM. TSM have announced the signings of Frederik "acoR" Gyldstrand, Alexander "Altekz" Givskov, and Nikolaj "niko" Kristensen, thus completing their transition to a full Danish roster. The trio joins Valdemar "valde" Bjørn Vangså, Rasmus "Zyphon" Nordfoss, and coach Allan "Rejin" Petersen on the team, who are now the only remnants of their previous European project. The move marks a return to their roots for TSM, who entered Counter-Strike in 2015 by signing a Danish team that eventually joined Astralis. acoR signs for the squad as the primary AWPer from GamerLegion, who he played for since September 2022 before getting removed after the Copenhagen Major. He played a key role in GamerLegion's run to the final at the BLAST Paris Major and helped the organization break into the top 10 of the world rankings in the process. Altekz comes into the team as a free agent after his latest team, Preasy, ceased operations in April. The 20-year-old is most known for his stint in the main Astralis team during 2023, when he helped the team reach the IEM Dallas playoffs while averaging a 0.98 rating across his tenure. The final piece of the puzzle is niko, who joins after a short period of inactivity. The 26-year-old departed Sashi in April and temporarily played for Grannys Knockers before entering free agency. The new-look TSM will debut in the ESL Challenger League Season 48 Europe, set to begin on July 15. TSM are now: Valdemar "valde" Bjørn Vangså Rasmus "Zyphon" Nordfoss Frederik "acoR" Gyldstrand Alexander "Altekz" Givskov Nikolaj "niko" Kristensen Allan "Rejin" Petersen (coach)

header: Editorial: Best and worst transfers of CS2
text: HLTV's writers share their opinions on who made the best and worst transfers so far in CS2. As we approach the first full year of CS2, which was released after the summer of 2023, we wonder what the best and worst roster changes have been during the early era of the game post-CS:GO. Initially, the idea was to look back on the winter market, but with the advent of CS2 many teams jumped the gun and started to form their rosters in late summer and early fall, so we expanded the window to include all of the changes that came about with the seismic shift around the time the game was released. From Dmitry "sh1ro" Sokolov joining Spirit to Ninjas in Pyjamas's overhaul, or Astralis' no-anchor mayhem and G2's unpopular removal of Justin "jks" Savage, our staff give their opinions to see if there is a quorum on the best and worst transfers affecting the first half of 2024. sh1ro's decision to step down from Cloud9 came out of left field and was heavily scrutinized considering the roster he was leaving. There's no denying now that teaming up with Danil "donk" Kryshkovets was a slam dunk of a move, and when you look at the ruin that is now Cloud9 perhaps we were too blind to see then that sh1ro was jumping a sinking boat. Singling out Emil "Magisk" Reif in the whole Falcons ordeal might seem harsh when the former ENCE core also came out much worse for it. However, the Dane was the first to commit to Danny "zonic" Sørensen and was leaving Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut behind and a Vitality team that went on to win a couple of events despite the downgrade. Who knows how this could have turned out had Nikola "NiKo" Kovač not made the last-minute U-turn, and perhaps the promise of the Bosnian superstar may have swayed many of the incoming players, but the reality is Falcons have been nothing short of a disaster post-Katowice. - Milan "Striker" Svejda Ninjas in Pyjamas' RMR was a disaster. But it also offered the new management an opportunity to mold the team in their image. Björn "THREAT" Pers and Richard "Xizt" Landström came in, were trusted with sporting matters, and improvement came overnight. After a baffling amount of time was spent trying to make Fredrik "REZ" Sterner, Kristian "k0nfig" Wienecke, and Ludvig "Brollan" Brolin co-exist in the same team, the new team plucked anchor Isak "isak" Fahlén out of GamerLegion — a huge coup — and promoted the impressive Max "maxster" Jansson to (accidentally, they say) restore a Swedish core. But the big one is adding Artem "r1nkle" Moroz. Daniil "headtr1ck" Valitov was a touch passive, but it's not like there was zero potential. You could have kept him. Instead, they boldly moved for the opposite style of sniper, compatriots though they are. At YaLLa Compass, we saw why r1nkle may very well end up as one of the three best rookies of 2024. Anyone who watched even a single map of Astralis and HEROIC in 2023 could have told you that making Martin "stavn" Lund and Benjamin "blameF" Bremer co-exist would be difficult. Playing exactly the same CT positions (and both wanting to be the trader on T) is one thing, but the clash in how they saw the game was even more stark. stavn is all about team-based proactivity and his ability to mid-round. blameF, as good as his raw numbers are, is about setting his own individual plays up. Adding Jakob "jabbi" Nygaard simultaneously only made things worse. Astralis removed Christian "Buzz" Andersen and Johannes "b0RUP" Borup, the two anchors in the old team, and added rotator jabbi and shifted poor old Victor "Staehr" Staehr — who was their best role-adjusted player in this period — to the graveyard shift of B on Mirage. Under blameF, stavn had a 0.99 T rating, and 1.08 on CT. jabbi, meanwhile, had 0.98 in his new anchor roles. Since the RMR, and blameF's departure, stavn has a 1.29 on CT and 1.12 on T. jabbi has a 1.13 on CT, and 1.19 on T. Roles matter. - Harry "NER0" Richards Spirit's management could hardly believe their luck when they learned that sh1ro had been made available for transfer by Cloud9. This wasn't a cheap move (rumors suggest that the deal cost upwards of $1 million), but it instantly allowed Spirit to solve one of their biggest issues while giving donk a reliable right-hand man. With Spirit, sh1ro has rediscovered his joy of playing and his best form, playing a key role during the team's title-winning campaigns in Katowice and London. With a 1.22 average rating and four EVPs, he is firmly in the conversation for Best AWPer of 2024. Casper "cadiaN" Møller is becoming a great example of how quickly things can change in modern Counter-Strike. Just months after making his first-ever appearance in the HLTV Top 20 Players of the Year, the Danish AWPer/IGL finds himself in an extremely fragile situation after a barren spell with Liquid. The fault lies squarely between the player and the organization, as the team never fully bought into the Dane's system, which raises serious questions about the thought process that went into creating the lineup. After half a season, the two brains of the project, cadiaN and Wilton "zews" Prado, are gone, and another player is believed to be on his way out. This is certainly not what cadiaN had in mind when he signed with Liquid at the end of last year. His stock has taken a precipitous fall, to the point where he might have a hard time finding a top team, and he may be left with no choice but to sit out the rest of the season. - Luís "MIRAA" Mira Losing David "frozen" Čerňanský was inevitable for MOUZ, and replacing a player like the Slovakian seemed impossible due to his fragging output. They passed the test with flying colors, though, as they found a worthy replacement in Brollan. The Swede's career was seemingly waning before MOUZ became the team to finally unlock his potential, something that both fnatic and Ninjas in Pyjamas failed to do. Because he is a different type of player and didn't take frozen's roles, his addition also helped his teammates reach a higher level, which allowed MOUZ to become one of the world's top teams despite losing their star player. A team short of firepower due to NiKo's and Nemanja "huNter-" Kovač's struggles in CS2 removed a high-fragging anchor for a much more supportive one, and that alone is enough to make the move a bad one. When you add how G2 handled the communication and that the community seemed unanimous in branding the change a downgrade, which added so much pressure to the team, it's safe to say Nemanja "nexa" Isaković's addition didn't have the desired effect. His removal in the summer break also tells its own story. - Žan "Sumljiv" Zupanič If there were any commensurate roster-building moment in CS2 that parallels 2012's legendary Ninjas in Pyjamas roster, then sh1ro joining Spirit would be the one. This change-out created titanic headwinds in CS2 and catapulted a five-man core into a permanent Top 5 fixture. sh1ro added the perfect amount of firepower, impact, and cohesion to Spirit’s roster, and has been the Patrik "f0rest" Lindberg to donk’s Christopher "GeT_RiGhT" Alesund (in terms of 2012 and 2013 days). This roster move also freed up Myroslav "zont1x" Plakhotia, allowing him to play a more specialized role and paid dividends to Leonid "chopper" Vishnyakov’s overall leadership system. But most of all, since we love storylines at HLTV, it was the ultimate emotional payoff from the days of sh1ro looking like the poster child for depression during his time at Cloud9 to the new days of winning events. Three cheers for the Russian anime team. There are a couple good contenders here: cadiaN joining Liquid, Lukas "gla1ve" Rossander to ENCE (despite early promise), and the entire Falcons project. But nothing quite has the morbid and corrosive sting as nexa’s stint on G2 in hindsight. The obsession with nexa’s lack of impact on this roster reached fever pitch by the mid-half of 2024 prior to his benching. In Dante’s Inferno, the eighth circle of Hell is known as the Malebolge (“evil pouches”); in the first pouch, Dante is shown a gathering of frauds running to and fro while being scourged by whips amidst hellfire. If there ever were a space for a Pouch 1.5 to be created for our modern de_inferno, then surely it would be for nexa's pit position play on CT-side and how he was continuously scorched there. At the very least that is how many will remember his stint on G2. - Michal "stich" Malachowski After the heavyweight signings of jabbi and stavn failed to net results for Astralis, culminating in arguably the organization’s most embarrassing result in missing out on the PGL Copenhagen Major, the decision to part ways with blameF and bring on Alexander "br0" Bro was exactly the move the team needed. Taking on the supportive roles that the team sorely needed to be filled, br0’s addition has helped breathe new life into Astralis, who snagged four consecutive semi-finals in his first events with the team. One will be hard-pressed to find a bigger waste of time this season than the addition of storied in-game leader gla1ve to ENCE. He initially joined a lineup with one foot in the grave at the end of 2023, and matters were made only more bizarre by the Danish captain being tasked to lead four Poles ahead of the new year. A stunning quarter-final finish at IEM Katowice exceeded expectations for the skipper’s new side, but the remainder of ENCE’s season provided almost nothing to be excited about. If one believes that gla1ve’s prime is far behind him, it stings to see an organization like ENCE, which previously commanded competitive lineups, place him as the centerpiece of their roster. For those who believe that the Dane still has more to give, seeing him thrust into a season surrounded by players signed at the last minute makes the first half of gla1ve’s 2024 feel like a waste of time for nearly everybody involved. - Samuel "Draik" Popkes The MongolZ put themselves on the map in 2023 with a handful of upsets at Big Events, notoriously playing spoiler to FURIA in the Play-ins of IEM Katowice and IEM Cologne in what looked like a tale as old as time: An emerging roster from Asia attends a few top events and surprises higher-ranked teams, but fails to convert that into a deeper run and drops back into the depths of their region, not to be seen again until their next upset win or two in a handful of months. It was apparent quite early on that this was something different, though. The type of Counter-Strike The MongolZ played wasn't a gimmick, nor had off-meta strategies that surprised and allowed for "fluke" wins. The team had the structure and was working on playing "proper" Counter-Strike, but lacked the experience and firepower to contend against the best. Enter Munkhbold "Senzu" Azbayar. The 17-year-old previously played for The MongolZ in 2022, under a different lineup, and his return to the organization under Garidmagnai "bLitz" Byambasuren's leadership came upon the eve of the transition to CS2. Senzu has firmly established himself as the team's best player since joining, and the change has paid dividends as The MongolZ enjoyed breakout success in the first six months of 2024 making the Major's Elimination Stage, EPL playoffs, and two smaller titles to reach a high of 11th in the world rankings. The disaster-class of Falcons is a disappointing tale from a wealth of angles, including the ripping apart of a successful ENCE roster, but the impact it's had upon Magisk and his 2024 career is in a league of its own. Admittedly, the Dane may have joined with the expectation of the organization completing the blockbuster signing of NiKo or other superstar talent. However, their failure to complete that move, their results since, and his departure from a successful Vitality roster — one that went on to win titles without him — leaves a bitter taste. Not only has his form dipped (1.05 LAN rating with Falcons, 1.14 in his last six months with Vitality), but I'm remiss to think of the other possible destinations he could have gone to when he made the transfer to the maligned Falcons roster, whether they were on the table or not. To FaZe for a departing Russel "Twistzz" Van Dulken? Fire. G2 in place of nexa? No doubt. Staying on Vitality? Not hard to imagine what could have been. Even a reunion with Nicolai "device" Reedtz on Astralis, if Magisk would actually return to the organization, leaves one salivating. This was a point I made on Snake & Banter in December, and though it didn't seem to age well with Falcons' playoff run in Katowice, it's one that I look back on now with sadness as to what could have been. - Danish "Nohte" Allana The Spanish-speaking world was taken by surprise when AWPer Antonio "MartinezSa" Martinez joined 9z. Most in Spain considered it a lateral move at best, perhaps incentivized by a better paycheck, but boy, is he proving everyone wrong. The 23-year-old had recently taken up the spot previously held by Spain's most prolific player ever, Álvaro "SunPayus" García, and given the chance to prove himself on the world stage with his country's flag-bearing team, Movistar Riders (now KOI), who often compete at events like ESL Pro League, can win mid-level LANs such as ESL Challengers, and even qualify to Majors on occasion. Then Maximiliano "max" Gonzalez did what he does best: get AWPers to excel in his system. The team's two past AWPers, Santino "try" Rigal and Lucas "nqz" Soares, played their best while in 9z, and now MartinezSa is following that trend with a career-high 1.20 rating. It took a few months, but they went from a fringe top 30 team to 12th in the world after a Cinderella semi-final run at IEM Dallas and hoisting the trophy at the FiReLEAGUE Global Finals (where Dust2.com.br named 'Marti' their MVP). It's hard to find hipster picks for the worst move.  Second-line Chinese teams adding random European players could be one. FURIA departing from their aggressive Andrei "arT" Piovezan-led style and giving Gabriel "FalleN" Toledo the keys could be a hot take to stoke the fire — although it probably doesn't qualify as it has been a transformation taking place since well before CS2 was out. But it's just as hard to pick one particular high-level train crash above the rest. Was nexa's return worse than gla1ve knowingly signing onto a dead team and having to end up leading a Polish lineup? Or Falcons failing to secure their star roster and the following meltdown that ensued after keeping Mohammad "BOROS" Malhas? Or Liquid investing hugely into an international squad just to never buy into one vision of the game and it all falling apart? What sets the removal of jks apart from the others is that it seemed completely unnecessary from the outside, and nobody has come out to dispel that line of thought. When G2 made the announcement, it was unanimously hailed as a lateral move. However, even lateral moves carry risk, and with nexa now benched after a not particularly prolific period, that seems to be the case — made worse in hindsight by the fact that they had won a Katowice and Cologne double in 2023 with the Australian. - Lucas Aznar Miles

header: ICY leaves AMKAL
text: The AWPer is rumored to be in Cloud9's crosshairs. AMKAL has announced that 19-year-old AWPer Kaisar "ICY" Faiznurov will not continue with the team, adding more fuel to the rumors that have him set to land on Cloud9. The North American organization is rebuilding its team around Sergey "Ax1Le" Rykhtorov and Kirill "Boombl4" Mikhailov, the only two players left, and an experiment in playing without a dedicated AWPer following Dmitry "sh1ro" Sokolov's departure did not pan out. The Kazakhstani player was being investigated by AMKAL to "determine if there has been any unfair behavior from the player toward the organization," but it ultimately seems like it came to nothing, and he is no longer tied to the team he had been playing for since December 2023. After joining AMKAL from AVANGAR at the turn of the year, ICY made his first Major appearance at the PGL Major in Copenhagen, where he averaged a 1.04 rating and 1.21 impact in the team's 0-3 run in the Opening Stage. ICY didn't get much chance to play on LAN with AMKAL, attending only the Major and its RMR, but a 1.15 overall rating garnered enough attention for him to secure a transfer. AMKAL is currently: Vladislav "Krad" Kravchenko Igor "Forester" Bezotecheskiy Aleksandr "TRAVIS" Timkiv Daniil "Sdaim" Tupov Svyatoslav "svyat" Dovbakh (coach)

header: ZywOo interview: Not enjoying fame, six years at Vitality, and his future
text: The French superstar sat down with HLTV for a lengthy chat about his career. HLTV sat down with Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut before the player break to talk about all things Counter-Strike in an in-depth interview conducted by Jason "moses" O'Toole. The duo touched on several topics throughout the interview, ranging from his time in Vitality to some more personal subjects. The French superstar began the interview by looking back at his career in Vitality, where he spent six years. "It's now not only people working for me. It's more friends, and it's awesome to have them behind," he began. "I don't care about being the superstar because, in the end, they are all just my friends. They don't see me as ZywOo but as Mathieu Herbaut, that's why I like them. Whenever I see their smile, I'm just happy to see them." ZywOo had a plethora of teammates throughout his six years in Vitality, but Dan "apEX" Madesclaire was a constant presence across the superstar's time in the organization. The Frenchman also transformed into a respected IGL during their time together, and ZywOo says he always saw him as a leadership figure. "When we had the discussion about who should take over as the IGL, it was 100% clear he is the next leader for me," he said. "We can just follow his call because we know it's going to be a good call. We try to help him, but when he makes a call, his energy ensures it's a good one." The conversation transitioned to his enjoyment of CS, and the Frenchman admitted he doesn't enjoy the limelight. "When I'm playing games, I don't feel anything because I know what I'm doing. I'm more afraid of speaking in front of people than playing." He was then asked about the best and worst aspects of being a pro player and gave a simple answer. "We are going from one tournament to another so fast, so sometimes it's really hard to enjoy it," he said about the negatives. "But the first thing that makes me enjoy it is winning. laughs Also, having all this chemistry with your teammates. You can feel all five connected on the server and feel really good, and when you are in a good team bubble, you can beat anyone." ZywOo then shared that he doesn't watch demos to prepare, something that has become a staple of top-tier CS in recent years. "I'm watching the game while I'm playing, and I see things instantly, but I'm never rewatching it. Once I have seen it once, I don't need to see it twice." The interview ended with ZywOo looking to the future, and he admitted he doesn't think about it yet. "For me, I'm living day by day, not thinking about the future and what I'm going to do, or if I'm going to be a coach or manager. Just enjoying the moment." You can watch the full in-depth interview through the embed at the start of this article or on HLTV's YouTube channel.

header: Who are 2024's rookies?
text: We take a look at the frontrunners, outsiders, and ones to watch from this year's newest batch of top-tier players. First things first, we're going to drop the charade. It would take a cataclysmic event to stop Danil "donk" Kryshkovets from winning Rookie of the Year at 2024's HLTV Awards in Belgrade. But there's an intriguing race for the last two spots on the podium behind Spirit's star man. Counter-Strike 2 has brought with it a new generation of players, and it is only right that we shine a light on this new intake, so come along for the ride with us, forget about donk, and let's dive into the race to be the second-best rookie of 2024. Our usual top 20 event list of MVP events and RMRs has been extended to increase the sample size for the rookies: At the turn of 2024, our candidates must meet the following criteria, and age is deliberately not included to give late bloomers like last year's winner, Guy "NertZ" Iluz, a chance even if their career is stalled by factors outside of their control. It is all about being new to tier one. Criteria- Fewer than 30 maps versus Top 20 opposition on LAN- Fewer than 5 Big events (including Super-Elite play-ins)- No appearances at the second (Legends/Elimination) stage of a Major- Fewer than 20 weeks in the Top 20 of our ranking One more thing on donk, though: This is on track for as good a rookie year as Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut in 2019, and better than Valeriy "b1t" Vakhovskiy in 2021 or Ilya "m0NESY" Osipov in 2022.
