What kind of impact do you think this victory will have on the team? A very positive one. The same thing happened in the match against G2. By winning and showing dominance, we feel quite comfortable playing against these teams, and we want more and more.

header: AMKAL transfer-list Sdaim
text: The 19-year-old Ukrainian is out of AMKAL after just four months, just as the team is due to compete at two important tournaments. AMKAL have placed Daniil "Sdaim" Tupov on the transfer list following mutual consent, the organization announced on Friday. The Ukrainian had only been a part of the team for four months. He first joined the roster in April as a stand-in after Aleksei "NickelBack" Trofimov was placed on the bench, and was confirmed as a permanent member a month later. In those four months AMKAL most notably placed in the top eight at CCT Global Finals and won RES European Masters Fall over Monte to secure a place at the BLAST Premier Fall Showdown. They were also recently invited to participate in the European RMR closed qualifier leading up to the Perfect World Shanghai Major, which is due to run on August 21-24, concurrently with the Fall Showdown. It's unclear who will replace Sdaim on the roster for the two important tournaments. They are using Emil "nota" Moskvitin as a stand-in for their ongoing match against Young Ninjas in the playoffs of CCT Europe Series 8. AMKAL have: Aleksandr "TRAVIS" Timkiv Vladislav "Krad" Kravchenko Igor "Forester" Bezotecheskiy Evgenii "topo" Lopatin Svyatoslav "svyat" Dovbakh (coach) Daniil "Sdaim" Tupov (transfer listed)

header: MOUZ's teamplay overcomes G2's individuals in statement arena win
text: MOUZ's usual arena jitters were nowhere to be found as they ended G2's run early. MOUZ have broken their arena curse by defeating G2 in convincing 2-0 fashion. G2 came into the game red hot favorites after dominating the lower bracket of Group A, even beating world No. 2 Spirit 13-3 and 13-1. But their individuals were shut down by the superior system and teamplay of Kamil "siuhy" Szkaradek and Dennis "sycrone" Nielsen's MOUZ squad. MOUZ, with an average age of 20.9, are by far the youngest team out of the six teams consistently contending for titles in 2024 and have earned a reputation for strong studio form but coming unstuck in the arenas. In Cologne, they are trying to leave that reputation behind them and have started strongly. siuhy and company's next challenge is a squad more similar to themselves, in the form of Aleksi "Aleksib" Virolainen and Andrey "B1ad3" Gorodenskiy's Natus Vincere. "We prepared a long time ago for this game," siuhy told the desk. "We put in a lot of work out of the server. We wanted to win a game on stage, a lot of hard work went into this game, and it paid off." That preparation even extended to a special facility at MOUZ's headquarters in Hamburg. "We have some interesting options there" explained sycrone, "Stage lights, a tribune, different things to recreate a similar real stage scenario." Clip: Jimpphat 1v2 strikes life into MOUZ Whatever their preparation was, it worked. G2's individuals turned up in key moments, with a Nemanja "huNter-" Kovač double on the P250 and a Janusz "Snax" Pogorzelski triple on the Five-SeveN giving them two key CT rounds on Dust2 and Ilya "m0NESY" Osipov ending the series on 42 frags. But in the more conventional gun rounds, siuhy had G2's number and put together a five-round streak on T side to go from 8-8 to a 13-8 win. Remarkably, MOUZ won just eight opening duels compared to G2's 14 on Dust2, but still came away with the win. The theme of siuhy's calling outdoing G2 continued on Mirage, as MOUZ lost both pistols but still secured a 7-5 T half and ended the game in another streak, this time of six CT rounds, as G2 won zero buy-v-buy rounds in the second half of either map. Clip: Snax taps away on B to win 3v5 "They were just better," admitted Nikola "NiKo" Kovač to Eefje "sjokz" Depoortere post-game. "We were not decisive. We hesistated a lot about each other, lost some important rounds that broke our momentum." It was also a disappointing match on a personal note, with NiKo in incredible form in groups as he took aim at a second consecutive IEM Cologne MVP but ended the quarter-final on a 0.86 rating. "I played poorly as well, I just couldn't get into the game," he said. It was also a match to forget for new signing Mario "malbsMd" Samayoa, who has shone for G2 in new roles but came unstuck in his first ever big stage appearance. After a strong start on T side on Dust2, he struggled on CT side on both maps and let his frustration out after being bested by Jimi "Jimpphat" Salo in a 1v1 late on Mirage. Clip: Jimpphat prompts a desk slam from malbsMd after 1v1 The story of the match, though, was MOUZ's teamplay and preparation shining through — with Anchor of the Year frontrunner Jimpphat especially impressive. "All of G2's individuals are shining," sycrone said pre-game. "But they're going up against a team today, and we're gonna push them." Post-match, with Oliver "OJ Borg" D'Anastasi, Ádám "torzsi" Torzsás was asked how far MOUZ could go. The Hungarian AWPer replied simply, just pointing at the trophy down the catwalk from him. MOUZ are two wins away from making that come true.

header: torzsi: "siuhy outplayed G2"
text: torzsi praised his in-game leader for a clinical 2-0 victory against G2. Despite a shaky group stage and a hard-hitting G2 squad against them, MOUZ came out on top in the quarter-finals to face Natus Vincere in the semi-finals. The stage fright many now associate with the young squad was nowhere to be seen as MOUZ won the game in a clean 2-0 series, spearheaded by Jimi "Jimpphat" Salo on Dust2 and then Ádám "torzsi" Torzsás on Mirage. In an interview with HLTV, the Hungarian AWPer praised his in-game leader, Kamil "siuhy" Szkaradek, for the clinical victory, especially on the Terrorist side of Dust2. "siuhy had really good calls," torzsi said shortly after the match. "He outplayed G2, basically. He had really good mid-round calls to go long and also reset to B on the good rounds, and it just worked out." He also spoke about the upcoming matchup against Natus Vincere, a rematch from the Esports World Cup semi-finals, where Aleksi "Aleksib" Virolainen's team came out on top en route to the title. "They play great CS," torzsi admitted. "I think it will be a banger game." Most people were writing you off in the playoffs, predicting a semi-final between G2 and NAVI. What does it feel like to beat them so convincingly in just two maps? It feels great to play well on the stage. I mean, we had already played vs G2 in Chengdu on stage, so we kind of knew what to expect, and we were also really prepared for this game. I'm just looking forward to tomorrow. You looked a little bit shaky at times during the group stage. How important was it to come here and play like this in front of such a big crowd? I think that at the end of the group stage we were a little bit shaky. So I think this game gives us a lot of confidence going into tomorrow against NAVI. I think they are a great team. This game was needed for us. Also, winning on Dust2 was really nice. We showed that the last game against Vitality was maybe an off-day. On Dust 2, you lost 14 of 22 opening duels, but it seemed that, tactically, you just outplayed them on that map. I didn't know about that, but that doesn't sound too good, to be honest, to lose that many entries, but I think siuhy had really good calls. He outplayed G2 basically. He had really good mid-round calls to go long and also reset to B on the good rounds, and it just worked out. We also did it perfectly, so it was amazing. I wanted to ask you about your Mirage pick. Did you want to punish G2 for some of the things that they did against Astralis? Was that your thinking? Not too much. Mirage is one of our best maps. We have, like, 10 wins on it or something like that. We have a really good winrate on it, and we prefer Mirage a lot. It was just a comfort pick from us. It was not about punishing them or anything. siuhy was smiling throughout the series. He seemed to be having a good time and making some very good calls. Yeah, we were having a lot of fun. I think when you are on stage you shouldn't get nervous or focus on the crowd. You have to enjoy this moment, playing on a stage. Especially here in Cologne. You don't get to play on this stage many times. I saw you hugging some people now after the match. Is it your family? Yeah, it's my family and my girlfriend. I'm just happy they can see me play in person. You're now going to face NAVI, are you looking to get some revenge for what happened at EWC? As I said before, I think they are a really good team, and we really want to beat them. They also have a Hungarian analyst, so I always like to play against them. It will be a great game. NAVI are one of the most consistent teams at the moment. They play great CS. I think it will be a banger game. You are now through to the semifinals. Considering how you played here in front of a crowd, how far do you think you can go here? Until the end of the catwalk right there in front of the trophy.

header: Aurora and 9 Pandas trade r3salt and clax
text: The two Russian sides have traded personnel. Aurora have announced the addition of Timur "clax" Sabirov from 9 Pandas, with Evgeny "r3salt" Frolov moving in the other direction. The move ends clax's 16-month stint with 9 Pandas, whilst r3salt had only been with Aurora for four months. In their announcement on X, Aurora suggested they had initiated the move, going on to state they had done so because "it's important that every member of the team is not only an excellent player but also behaves in the most respectful manner toward both the club and their teammates." The transfer comes as a surprise as r3salt performed well for Aurora during his short time with the team, averaging a 1.17 rating and helping the squad win Skyesports Masters 2024, all whilst Aurora maintained their place around the top 20 of the world ranking. By joining 9 Pandas r3salt will reunite with Aleksandr "shalfey" Marenov, with whom he played on FORZE over the course of 2023. clax averaged a 1.06 rating over the past three months as 9 Pandas' lowest-rated player. The team overall enjoyed modest success in recent months, claiming the CCT Season 2 Europe Series 3 title and qualifying for BetBoom Dacha Belgrade Season 2. clax was also notably part of the 9 Pandas team that completed an impressive underdog run to qualify for PGL Major Copenhagen earlier this year, taking down the likes of Astralis and GamerLegion in the process. The team were eventually unable to compete at the Major due to visa issues. This marks the second change in recent months for 9 Pandas, as they recently swapped storied IGL Denis "seized" Kostin out from the starting roster in favour of shalfey and added Artem "Fierce" Ivanov as their coach. The two squads are now: Aurora: Aleksandr "KENSI" Gurkin Evgeny "Norwi" Ermolin Denis "deko" Zhukov Viktor "Lack1" Boldyrev Timur "clax" Sabirov Stepan "brain" Sivoronov (coach) 9 Pandas: Artem "iDISBALANCE" Egorov Aleksandr "glowiing" Matsievich Daniil "d1Ledez" Kustov Aleksandr "shalfey" Marenov Evgeny "r3salt" Frolov Artem "Fierce" Ivanov (coach) Denis "seized" Kostin (benched)

header: XTQZZZ: "We felt that if we broke SAW's momentum, it'd be GG"
text: The French coach was pleased that his team stuck to the game plan against SAW. Vitality are through to the grand final of IEM Cologne 2024 after beating SAW 2-0 in dominant fashion. The international outfit was better in every department and conceded only 11 rounds across the series, with Rafael "arrozdoce" Wing admitting that his team was outplayed on both maps. Speaking to HLTV after the series, Rémy "XTQZZZ" Quoniam said that his team respected SAW and drew up a good game plan for the match. "We knew they were going to be proactive," he said. "They move a lot on the T and CT side, they're a bit crazy. So we felt that if we broke the momentum, it was going to be GG for us." Almost nine months into 2024, Vitality are still chasing their first title this year. After being on the losing end of the ESL Pro League 19 and IEM Dallas finals, XTQZZZ hopes this can be his team's turn to lift a trophy. "We will talk tonight and figure out how we want to approach the game tomorrow," he said. A quick 2-0 victory against SAW and you're through to the final. Are you happy with the way the team played today? Yeah, we got the job done for the semi-final. I think we respected SAW. They played very well. The plan was good. We stayed calm and focused, so I'm happy. But the job is not done yet. After watching SAW beat FaZe, what was the mindset like? What did you discuss yesterday to make sure you'd stay composed and focused and wouldn't underestimate SAW here? Just focus on the plan for how we needed to play against them. We knew they were going to be proactive. They move a lot on the T and CT side, they're a bit crazy. So we felt that if we broke the momentum, it was going to be GG for us. So that's it. Nuke was perhaps SAW's best map heading into this series, but you were in control from the beginning. It seemed like you were very well prepared. Can you walk me through the game plan for Nuke? Actually, I think they changed their T side a bit, so we were not that ready in two or three rounds. After that, we had a plan on the T side to take things slowly but surely. Just try to take advantage and chill. Can you also walk me through Dust2, where you were in control almost from the beginning? You lost the first pistol round but then took control of the game. You made it look very easy. I think the forcebuy did everything, to be honest. We smashed them on Nuke, they won the pistol and then lost to a forcebuy. So I think it helped a lot today. After that, we played default and took our time. And yeah, it was really smooth, I would say. You're now going to face the winner of MOUZ vs NAVI. What are your expectations? Which team would you rather face? You lost to MOUZ in the EPL final, and you haven't faced NAVI this year. Honestly, I expect a banger. I think it can be a good game. We would be happy to play NAVI because they are, at least for me, the best team in the world. And MOUZ, it could be the real revenge for EPL if we play against them in the grand final. No matter what, it's going to be a really good game, I think. This is going to be your third final this year, after finishing in second place in Dallas and in Malta. This is also going to be apEX's third final here in Cologne. Do you think that third time will be the charm for you guys here? laughs I hope so, honestly. I think we need to talk a bit, because when you lose two finals in a row or sometimes you feel you were pretty close, even in the semi-finals… We will talk tonight and figure out how we want to approach the game tomorrow. And if you win the tournament here, how big of a boost would it be for the rest of the season? If we win, I think we will have achieved something this year. And for the future, the RMR is in two or three months. So yeah, we need that. We have been preparing for this tournament since the break. This has been our mission, basically. And hopefully tomorrow we will win the trophy.

header: BetBoom Dacha Belgrade S2 team list finalized
text: The 12 participants in the $500,000 event have been determined. Tournament organizer Fissure has announced the remaining invites for the main stage and play-in stage of BetBoom Dacha Belgrade Season 2 after previously announcing six of the 12 participants three weeks ago. Joining Virtus.pro, Spirit, and reigning BetBoom Dacha champions MOUZ in the second stage of the event is HEROIC, who look to squeeze in an appearance ahead of their campaign in Group A of ESL Pro League Season 20. Three new sides have received places in the play-in stage, as 9z, Falcons, and Eternal Fire have rounded out the list of eight teams vying for a place in the main stage. Those three squads will be joining fellow invitees BetBoom, FURIA, and Aurora, as well as regional qualifier winners paiN and 9 Pandas. The team list for the main stage of BetBoom Dacha Season 2 is: The team list for the play-in stage is:

header: Vitality roar past SAW to reach Cologne final
text: A close start on Nuke soon segued into a stomp for Vitality in the semi-final match. The first semi-final of IEM Cologne 2024 has drawn to a close, seeing Vitality claim their place in the final over Portuguese underdogs SAW after a confident 2-0 victory. With this win, Vitality have secured their third final in 2024, offering an important opportunity considering the fact that the European side is one of the few top sides to be without a trophy throughout the year so far. Conversely for SAW, this result puts an end to the best run that Christopher "MUTiRiS" Fernandes's men have had in a Big Event, one that saw them move past top squads G2 and FaZe while also securing their first appearance in front of a crowd of Cologne's magnitude. "We saw what happened to FaZe yesterday, and we did not underestimate SAW," shared Vitality captain Dan "apEX" Madesclaire following the team's semi-final victory. "They have had such a strong run, but we focused on ourselves, and it paid off." The series kicked off on SAW's pick of Nuke, where the Portuguese squad managed to stand toe-to-toe with their opponent throughout much of the first half, taking an early lead on the offense. After squandering a round by losing to pistols, SAW were soon beaten back further by a clutch from apEX, allowing Vitality to tie things up and shift the momentum in their favor. Clip: apEX ties up Nuke by clutching versus ewjerkz After turning a 3-5 deficit into a 7-5 half, Vitality continued to turn up the heat on SAW on the offense, allowing just one round to slip away as they stole away Nuke 13-6. By the time Vitality's pick of Dust2 began, the international side was fully into the swing of things, stamping out a deflated SAW throughout the T-side to bag a 10-2 half before closing out the map not long after with a 13-5 scoreline.

header: Clutches power NAVI past MOUZ to Cologne final
text: Aleksib's side reach their third consecutive grand final after extending their unbeaten streak on Mirage to 12. Natus Vincere have reached the grand final of IEM Cologne by scraping past MOUZ in an intense two-map series, where Aleksi "Aleksib" Virolainen's side barely managed to extend their unbeaten run on Mirage to 12 courtesy of winning five out of six clutches in a 13-11 victory. The Copenhagen Major champions were favorites to take the win after a confident group stage campaign put them straight through to the semi-final, but MOUZ made them work for it in a series that could, in the end, have gone either way if not for NAVI outlasting MOUZ when the game came down to the wire. Clip: Daylight robbery as NAVI win round with USPs MOUZ's surprise Inferno pick caught Natus Vincere off-guard, Aleksib admitted on the desk after the match, but even that wasn't enough to net the German organization a win in the series. "I don't think Inferno was a good choice for them," the Finnish captain said. "I did think that they had more strengths on other maps, but to be honest they caught us off guard. We prepared way more on other maps. "We still knew how they would approach Inferno, but after they picked it, we were really sure that they changed a lot of stuff trying to throw us off and not play the same as the last official." Aleksib also admitted that Natus Vincere will need to level up on the T side if they want to beat Vitality in the best-of-five grand final, set to kick off on Sunday at 17:00 . Clip: b1t 3K and clutch breaks MOUZ's streak Kamil "siuhy" Szkaradek's men needed to prove themselves on stage as conversations continued about their prowess in studio environments not translating under the bright lights of arenas, and they took a huge step toward that after a convincing dismantlement of G2 in the quarter-finals. They took another stride in the right direction by not crumbling on their Inferno pick despite a disastrous 1-8 start, but also showed they have a ways to go yet as they couldn't close out when it came down to the wire, and lost out in almost every clutch situation on Mirage. NAVI put up a brick wall in Banana that MOUZ struggled to break through at the start of the series, and a quiet half from Ádám "torzsi" Torzsás left the map feeling like a wash before he came alive in the second half. MOUZ were left staring down a 3-10 deficit after losing the second pistol, but they won a force-buy and clawed all the way back to force overtime after NAVI crumbled on the T side with lost 5v4s and poor late-rounds. That effort proved all for naught, however, as Valeriy "b1t" Vakhovskiy reigned supreme in Apartments once back on the CT side to net NAVI a 16-13 win. Watch: jL and Aleksib win 2v2 for map point MOUZ showed tenacity as they shrugged off the loss and kicked into a higher gear on Mirage, giving NAVI the same treatment as they'd received on Inferno. Dorian "xertioN" Berman looked simply unstoppable as he ripped apart Natus Vincere's defaults for an 18-5 K-D and 152 ADR half, with NAVI's only salvation coming off the back of two clutches from Justinas "jL" Lekavicius and one from Ihor "w0nderful" Zhdanov. Clip: jL insane 1HP 1v3 clutch Those lost clutches came back to haunt MOUZ in the second half, and it was here that their difficulties on stage reared their head once again. siuhy's side lost the pistol and subsequent force, but got back in the driver's seat with guns in hand to regain control, 10-7. They fumbled a crucial, easy round to USPs after b1t grabbed a crazy double kill in Middle, and despite answering back with a win of their own to hit 11, couldn't close out from there. Aleksib, who had a quiet map until this point, won back-to-back clutches to pull his team over the finish line and book a ticket to the final against Vitality.

header: B1ad3: "We need to show a much better game if we want to beat Vitality"
text: NAVI's coach was very open about his team's shortcomings versus MOUZ despite emerging victorious. Natus Vincere have continued their successful run results at IEM Cologne, making their third consecutive grand final as they secured a hard-fought victory over MOUZ in front of a packed LANXESS Arena. Although NAVI came away with a 2-0 win, it was hardly a confidence-boosting match for the world's No. 1 side. With their Terrorist sides lacking, they had to fend off a big Inferno comeback from MOUZ to win in overtime and relied heavily on their individuals' five clutches to win Mirage. As they head into their grand final affair against a red-hot Vitality squad, coach Andrey "B1ad3" Gorodenskiy admits NAVI need to step up their game to secure their third trophy of 2024 and their second in a row. "We need to show a much better game if we want to beat Vitality," he said in an interview with HLTV. The veteran coach was open about Natus Vincere's mistakes versus MOUZ, highlighting hurried rounds and communication issues throughout the close series. In addition, B1ad3 shared his thoughts on MOUZ's surprising Inferno pick, capitalizing on the mistakes of opponents, and the mentality of the team as they stand just one win away from hoisting the IEM Cologne trophy. A 2-0 victory, and you're straight through to the grand final. How are you feeling? I'm feeling relieved, kind of, because it was a very tough match. We were really close to losing both maps. That's always a relief. I wanted to start with the veto. Were you surprised that they went with an Inferno pick? I was very surprised.  I didn't expect it. First of all, I don't like it when people pick Inferno. It's bad for them. Because this map is really hard to anti-strat and control everything. It's my opinion. We can also fully ignore preparation on Inferno, do our defaults, and still be in control sometimes. They had a good CT side, but I think they were a little bit lost in the mid-round when we were on the CT side. Imagine how hard it is to pick the map when you haven't picked it before in the tournament. It's very hard. It was risky but maybe they respect us a lot and that's why they picked it. I don't know. You seemed to be in control on Inferno. You were up 10-3 and then you lost that round to some pistols and an MP9. It seemed that round shifted the game in MOUZ's favor. Did you feel that you lost control of the game? I think that at that moment, we lost communication a little bit. We thought there were two B, but there were three. Maybe we were hurrying things up. I think we were hurrying things up on Inferno a lot of times, and also sometimes on T side on Mirage. It's very important to be aware of what can happen. And we use to say that, on stage, there's a loss of packages, like 5 percent loss, constantly. You need to know this before you make a move because maybe your teammate didn't hear you, or something like that. This is something we need to learn for tomorrow, for sure. MOUZ ended up taking the game to overtime. How did you manage to stay so calm and composed after regulation? And what was the message that you told the players as you went into overtime? I only say this when I see that we are shaky, lost on the map or something. When I see we are kind of afraid to lose. But I saw that the atmosphere was pretty good, kind of like a work in process, that's how we used to say, and the players were ready to execute ideas. So we didn't say anything about the mindset. We only spoke about what to change, because from Inferno OT, we changed completely. I said to change on Banana and we changed. That's all. Because we were a little bit passive. We were giving them too much vision. We were a little bit blind and I think it helped for one round. Second round, Justinas jL was in control more than before. Talking now about Mirage. Why do you think you struggled so much on the T side? You won only four rounds, and three of them were clutches. One of the problems that could have given us maybe two more rounds: we were hurrying things up. Okay? We spoke about how they played and we said, 'As soon as we have control, please don't hurry up because they are passive, they have good off-angles, it can be dangerous for us. We need to maybe use some flashes, maybe swing together, and so on.' And in MR12, it's very dangerous if you lose one or two rounds, unfortunately. In the end, you got the win. You won five clutches and an eco round on the CT side. Do you think MOUZ were feeling the pressure a little bit? For me, usually when it happens, from my experience, luck is on the side of the better team. I've been in this situation before. I think we were lucky in this situation. But the only thing that we can do is fish for mistakes, okay? The biggest part of what can happen is on their side. I think 70 percent is down to them. If they had done everything perfectly, we would not win the round. So maybe you're right, it's like pressure. The same thing happened with Liquid against FaZe, for example. I think 70 percent of the job was done by Liquid, in my opinion. You are now going to face Vitality in the final. You haven't faced them this year. What are your expectations for this match? We need to show a much better game if we want to beat Vitality. We haven't played them in a long time, I think the last time was at BLAST. I think they respect us, which is what has changed since the last time. I think they are very well prepared. I said this before the event that they are very well prepared and they are ready to win. The two best teams in the tournament will face each other, I think the better team will win, but we for sure need to step up if we want to win. We can play better, in my opinion. This is your third final in a row. Cologne is a trophy that no one on the team has won except for b1t. What would it mean to the team to win this tournament, especially as we head into the Major? It's good if we don't think about this as players. Because, let's be honest, this line-up is not like FaZe, when you open their profiles and there's like dozens of trophies. And when they lose, they're, like, 'Fuck, we could have got one more trophy.' And they've already had huge careers. But for these players, I think it's fine not to win this. We don't need to overvalue this. If we overvalue this, it can be like a zugzwang situation, when you're afraid to make a move on the map. It's very important not to think about how important the Cologne trophy is. But yeah, this place is amazing. The Cathedral.

header: IEM Cologne quarter-finals day as it happened
text: NiKo to sjokz on the loss: "I don't really know, honestly, they were better. Dust2 was a very weird game, I felt like we had too many bad rotations on the map, we weren't very decisive, hesitating a lot and doubting each other. They won some important rounds like the forcebuy on T side, and that broke our momentum, it was hard to come back after on CT side because our economy was not the best." "I played poorly as well and couldn't get into the game at all. Nothing to take away from MOUZ, we won the majority of the pistols and managed to lose kinda easy." ZERO T side gun rounds for G2, with frustration getting to both Mario "malbsMd" Samayoa and Ilya "m0NESY" Osipov down the stretch. What a moment for MOUZ on stage! MOUZ 9-8  G2 G2's force buy gets them into the 1v1 despite it being a 3v5 at one moment, but Jimi "Jimpphat" Salo stands tall. G2 6-7  MOUZ What a drive-by that is. Train would write a sequel if they saw that from Ilya "m0NESY" Osipov. MOUZ 6-5  G2 Some misses earlier let Ilya "m0NESY" Osipov and G2 into the game, but Ádám "torzsi" Torzsás makes no mistake here. MOUZ 4-4  G2 Kamil "siuhy" Szkaradek finally came undone when he called MOUZ into the A stack one round ago, and now a 5v3 has gone begging thanks to Janusz "Snax" Pogorzelski from B Short. MOUZ 4-2  G2 New map, same Kamil "siuhy" Szkaradek calling. MOUZ just keep finding the gap in G2's defences. G2 2-1  MOUZ G2 9-13  MOUZ G2's individuals falter against a MOUZ that — after that Janusz "Snax" Pogorzelski triple — picked the right bombsite time after time. Mario "malbsMd" Samayoa dominated as an entry on T but on CT, as a Long anchor, he went 6-9 and was punished repeatedly. G2 end the game winning FOURTEEN opening duels (and losing 8) but only win 9 rounds. G2 9-12  MOUZ Janusz "Snax" Pogorzelski and Nemanja "huNter-" Kovač, with B smoked, picked the worst possible moment for a Mid retake and MOUZ take full advantage. G2 9-10  MOUZ Wait a minute, MOUZ are winning? G2 have had all the pop offs, two low-eco wins, but in the standard gun rounds they are being seen off by the MOUZ machine and Kamil "siuhy" Szkaradek's calling. G2 9-8  MOUZ G2's firepower goes deep, but it's their unlikeliest candidate who gets them onto nine. MOUZ have stood strong in the face of some of these rounds, but how many times can they rally in one match? Here's some insight from former M80 analyst Bobby "stamina" Eitrem. G2 8-7  MOUZ Mario "malbsMd" Samayoa got it started with an opener on his saved AK, but it's Nemanja "huNter-" Kovač's P250 that gets the round done. G2 7-5  MOUZ Dorian "xertioN" Berman has a 0.97 rating in stage games this year — 0.23 below his average. MOUZ need their spacetaker to wake up on T side. G2 4-2  MOUZ How MOUZ needed that from their young Finn. Mario "malbsMd" Samayoa is terrorising their defence with an 8-2 K-D and needs to be stopped; this is one way to do it. G2 1-0  MOUZ It's Mario "malbsMd" Samayoa's first true arena match, and he gets a triple in the pistol as G2 succeed on both A and B. This guy can play any role, any situation, under any level of pressure. What a signing he's proved to be already. G2 have already upset MOUZ at PGL Copenhagen and IEM Dallas, but now, with Mario "malbsMd" Samayoa and Janusz "Snax" Pogorzelski, they are the favorites. Two German organizations, so there's an extra bit of spice to this one on a 'home' stage. The nightmare map pool on FACEIT when you're facing aimers like G2's. What are MOUZ cooking? siuhy to BanKs on how much G2 changed with Snax and malbsMd: "A lot, actually. They play a much more loose style, which I think actually suits their players, now they have more firepower, obviously." On playing on the stage: "We're excited to play here. The main thing to do is to have fun on stage, something we need to work on and something we need to do and show up. We've done a lot of hard work behind the scenes, and now it's just about having fun and enjoying the moment." sycrone to BanKs on battling stage jitters: "One thing we have done recently is MOUZ built a new headquarters in Hamburg, and here we have some interesting options, stage lights, a tribune, different things to recreate a similar real stage scenario. On G2: "They play free, a little bit as a mix, and all the individuals are shining. But they're going up against a team today, and we're gonna push them." Speaking to OJ on stage: "This is the greatest achievement I've ever had. This is better than being at the Major, this is another level." "This is our best achievement, on an arena everyone excepted us to lose. But I feel like we can do better." Take a bow, Michel "ewjerkz" Pinto and Rafael "arrozdoce" Wing. FaZe 14-16  SAW It's happened! FaZe thought they were the heroes of this story. It was a classic FaZe tale, full of comebacks and clutches. But, for once, the procrastinators are punished. FaZe 13-15  SAW Two more match points after Michel "ewjerkz" Pinto delivers on the B bomb-site. FaZe 12-14  SAW Pressure off, and Christopher "MUTiRiS" Fernandes finds the calls he couldn't in regulation with those match points. Two T rounds already! FaZe 12-12  SAW Four CT rounds on the bounce for FaZe to secure OT! The Robin "ropz" Kool renaissance has a new great work of art. FaZe 8-12  SAW A 3v5 again! Rafael "arrozdoce" Wing does everything in the lower bomb-site FaZe 8-10  SAW FaZe 7-9  SAW A 1v4 clutch and then a fast A pop call means Christopher "MUTiRiS" Fernandes has won SAW back-to-back rounds himself. Shades of Peter "dupreeh" Rasmussen's cl;utch from Katowice 2017 with the one-tap on the last. Chef's kiss. But SAW cannot get ahead of themselves. Catching FaZe is one thing, passing them is another. FaZe 5-7  SAW "All roads lead back to Ricardo "roman" Oliveira," says Harry "JustHarry" Russell as SAW take the lead. The veteran is up to 104.7 ADR and SAW have earned their lead. Lesser teams would have crumbled under the pressure after the heartbreak on Anbuis, but SAW have been worth every penny. FaZe 5-5  SAW SAW getting back into it? Time for a Finn "karrigan" Andersen double entry. FaZe 4-3  SAW If he pistol was crucial what are the first few gun rounds? FaZe have now won three out of four buy-versus-buy rounds with Finn "karrigan" Andersen's new slower and more micro-managing style serving FaZe well. Both teams excel on T side on Nuke, remember. FaZe 0-2  SAW A nice idea from FaZe, who fake a Secret push with a smoke and two players only for three to pop out on A. But even with Hut player Rafael "arrozdoce" Wing rotating downstairs, SAW survive the fake and win their first pistol since Inferno. Robin "ropz" Kool delivered most of his impact (like he did on Inferno) early on in the game, and had  110.3 ADR and a 1.82 rating at the end of the first half. But those T rounds proved absolutely crucial — the only two CT gun rounds FaZe won were the 2v3 retake in round 23 and David "frozen" Čerňanský's 1v2 in round 24. WIthout that good start (and the Helvijs "broky" Saukants-led 2v4), we're looking at SAW in the semi-finals. It was a clip a round at the stretch there as classic FaZe bullshit kicked in — this Nuke decider cannot come soon enough. FaZe 13-11  SAW Noooooo SAW! All that work is for nothing. 4-10 to 11-11, just to lose 11-13. FaZe 12-11  SAW Heroics at the death! SAW miss their Camera smoke in the 3v2 post-plant on A and it costs them everything. FaZe 11-11  SAW Michel "ewjerkz" Pinto, Finn "karrigan" Andersen, and Rafael "arrozdoce" Wing all deliver with a 2K each but it's the young Portugese duo who come away with the round win. We're all tied up! FaZe 10-7  SAW FaZe won the second pistol but SAW have won the first two gun rounds to break Finn "karrigan" Andersen and company's bank. They've just been so well drilled all tournament — the Danny "BERRY" Krüger and Christopher "MUTiRiS" Fernandes gameplan still has legs. FaZe 8-4  SAW SAW have kept it coming with a new active plan every CT round, but sometimes FaZe only need two alive to turn the game on it's head. They end the half with eight rounds by winning the mid and late round battle. SAW 4-4  FaZe Some strong work from Robin "ropz" Kool got FaZe a lead, but they are still lacking fragging out of the rest of their players. Helvijs "broky" Saukants in particular is continuing his poor series, in the clip below he fired off a full AWP clip and hit nothing. SAW 1-2  FaZe Robin "ropz" Kool has ensured the force-buy wars continue, his opening 2k allowed FaZe to rotate back to hit the A site and win the round. SAW 1-1  FaZe So indecisive from FaZe on the push into the site... SAW 0-1  FaZe SAW 13-6  FaZe A completely one-sided affair, FaZe never really looked like they were in this map. SAW's proactive CT approach had FaZe at sixes and sevens in the first half, before they cruised over the finish line with some potent work on T side, particularly by Rafael "arrozdoce" Wing. arrozdoce and Michel "ewjerkz" Pinto were imperious all game, but it must be said FaZe seemed to come into this map cold. Helvijs "broky" Saukants had a stinker, posting one frag in the first half, and David "frozen" Čerňanský was uncharacteristically shaky. SAW 10-6  FaZe Oh dear SAW... SAW 8-4  FaZe SAW have dominated their CT half on Inferno thanks to an aggressive and proactive approach. They read FaZe well and always had the right push to take away space and prepare quick flanks. FaZe had a couple of standout rounds, as shown below, but overall looked a little lacklustre. SAW 4-3  FaZe Just when SAW were taking control... SAW 4-2  FaZe SAW have now strung defensive rounds together, taking control of the half. SAW 2-2  FaZe SAW had almost nothing in that round, but Michel "ewjerkz" Pinto's saved rifle has allowed the Portuguese to tie up the score. SAW 0-1  FaZe Already a spicy pistol round to kick things off. FaZe recovered from a lost opening kill by overwhelming the A defence, but Rafael "arrozdoce" Wing nearly pulled off the clutch. A very interesting veto has come through, thanks to SAW picking Anubis instead of Nuke. If the choice pays off, we are in for a fascinating matchup. BIG might not have made it to the playoffs, but their fan group is still in the arena in full force. One of the flags the group are flying sports Fatih "gob b" Dayik's face and a message thanking the German for his service. Finn "karrigan" Andersen stopped for a quick chat with Eefje "sjokz" Depoortere on the broadcast, giving his thoughts on FaZe's performances in Cologne. On playing in Cologne: It is the cathedral of CS. Over my career I have seen everything grow. Katowice and Cologne are the two events you want to win, there's prestige, there's pain, there's happiness, there's everything attached to these two tournaments. As a player for me, this is what I live for, this is what I breathe for, this is what I want to play for. Some other tournaments are not as important as this one. What karrigan wants from his team: The most important thing is I wanted the boys to come out and enjoy it. Rewatching the Liquid game kinda sets everything in perspective. When we were in the flowstate we didn't talk much, we just focused on next round, next round, next round. That's where we're dangerous, that's where we thrive the most, under the pressure and under the circumstances, and there's no other circumstances like this that can make everyone perform. On FaZe's approach: Sometimes when you're in it you can't really see it, but looking back at some games, at the Major and over the last three months, we kinda lost ourselves, how we want to play and the philosophy. So taking a step back and going back to the basics, me with more control, but if I see the confidence is right, if I see people going for duels, I can switch the philosophy mid-game. I am used to playing under different circumstances. Christopher "MUTiRiS" Fernandes spoke to James "BanKs" Banks on the broadcast ahead of SAW's match against FaZe, giving some insight into his team's mentality. On his feelings: I don't know, it's hard to find some words for what I am feeling right now. It's a dream, coming here in this big stage and arena is just special. I'm just surprised for everything, so I just want to enjoy this. On the pressure of a big stage: I think that the pressure is going to be here all the time, and it's good, we just need to use the pressure to be more hungry to win, just use the pressure to be more focused. That's what we talked about. I don't have special tips for my guys because I have never been on this stage (laughs). We just want to enjoy it together and play as a team, and I want to show good Counter-Strike to the arena, that's the most important thing. On losing to FaZe recently at BLAST: I think that we learned so much in the past months, so we are a different team now. Our map pool is better now, that's the biggest factor I think, because when you have a bad map pool you go to BO3s and are afraid of everything. On SAW's approach to the game: We just need to be ourselves, we are pretty confident but we know that FaZe on these stages are just different. We don't need to think too much about that, just focus on ourselves and give our best. Of course we are the underdogs... but we want to win. Danny "BERRY" Krüger is fully embracing the "Julio" meme, the Portuguese name that SAW's fans have started to call him by. On paper, FaZe got the dream playoff bracket. Avoid Natus Vincere until the final, and get SAW instead of G2 in the quarter-final. But that doesn't tell the whole story. SAW might have dropped off towards the end of last season but they have been revitalized in Cologne, taking down G2 in beautiful fashion to kick off their campaign before securing a playoff berth with a resilient victory over The MongolZ. FaZe meanwhile have been in sub-optimal shape for some time and whilst they have experienced some thrilling highs in Cologne, such as their epic comeback against Liquid, they have also laboured at times. These two sides met recently at BLAST Premier Spring Final, where FaZe took a 2-0 victory by virtue of stealing SAW's map pick of Ancient in overtime before battering the Portuguese squad on Inferno. SAW are, however, a different beat with time to anti-strat a specific opponent. The map pool would seem to slightly favour FaZe. SAW's perma-ban is not a great battleground for FaZe, whilst FaZe's usual ban of Vertigo is a solid battleground for SAW. SAW have picked Nuke in every series in Cologne, and the winrates suggest they should go for it again, but FaZe picked it in both series against Liquid, indicating they would be comfortable if the veto went that way. Expect to see Nuke picked by SAW, Inferno or Ancient picked by FaZe, and the final map to be the middleground of either Anubis or Dust2. Likely Dust2, as FaZe tend to remove Anubis if their opponent bans Vertigo. Before we head into the business-end of IEM Cologne, let's get a quick temperature check on the race for MVP. Currently the top seven spots for rating are all occupied by G2 and Natus Vincere players, with Nikola "NiKo" Kovač holding a slender lead at the top. Everything can change however, with plenty of series left to be played. Who do you think will bag the HLTV MVP medal? Cologne has borne witness to many of the best moments in Counter-Strike history. Countless epic plays, era-defining victories, and heart-wrenching losses. But which one is your favourite? HLTV spoke to some of the pros competing in Germany this year to get their take on the matter. Hear from Aleksi "Aleksib" Virolainen, Dan "apEX" Madesclaire, Håvard "rain" Nygaard and more. IEM Cologne has finally reached the playoffs, and the LANXESS Arena's doors are open for fans who made the pilgrimage to watch the two quarter-final series of the day. The early match sets up the playoff underdogs, SAW, against a struggling FaZe side who made an incredible comeback against Liquid in their group stage decider match that filled the team with confidence ahead of the tournament's final stage. The series kicks off at 15:45  and the winner will meet Vitality on Saturday in the semi-finals. On the other side of the bracket, the second match, at 19:00 , will see MOUZ and G2 clash to reach the semi-finals against the world's No. 1 team, Natus Vincere.

header: Monte, B8 among teams through to ESL Challenger Atlanta EU closed qualifier
text: BLEED was one of the notable sides who ultimately missed out on a closed qualifier berth. The ESL Challenger Atlanta Europe open qualifier has concluded, seeing GamerLegion, B8, Monte, and GUN5 secure a place in the closed qualifier for the American event. Those four squads will join the teams already invited to the closed qualifier — Ninjas in Pyjamas, SAW, Aurora, and Sashi — in a double-elimination bracket from August 29-31 for a single spot at ESL Challenger Atlanta. One noteworthy side that failed to make it past the single-elimination open qualifier was Aleksandar "kassad" Trifunović's BLEED, who currently sit just outside the top 30 in the world rankings. The international squad fell short in their penultimate match of the bracket versus SINNERS, while the Czech side subsequently faltered to GamerLegion. The ESL Challenger Atlanta 2024 main event is set to run from October 4-6, with BIG, BetBoom, M80, FlyQuest, and ODDIK each having secured their place at the Georgia LAN already. The final three spots up for grabs will go to the winners of the Europe, North America, and Oceania closed qualifiers. The team list for the ESL Challenger Atlanta Europe Closed Qualifier is:

header: IEM Cologne semi-finals day as it happened
text: Despite the fact that both Vitality and Natus Vincere have been regular competitors in 2024's top events, the two sides have yet to face this year. The last time the black-and-yellow-clad squads faced off was almost exactly eight months ago at the BLAST Premier World Final, where Vitality bested Natus Vincere 2-0 en route to their tournament victory in Abu Dhabi. Since then, Natus Vincere have bagged two trophies, including at PGL Major Copenhagen, while Vitality have found themselves without a trophy so far this year. Who do you have taking this all-important rematch? After emerging victorious over MOUZ in a nail-biter two-map series, Natus Vincere skipper Aleksi "Aleksib" Virolainen shared some comments on the desk regarding the veto, his individual performance in the series, and team's comeback to close out the series on Mirage. On MOUZ's Inferno pick: "I don't think Inferno was a good choice for them. I did think that they had more strengths on other maps, but to be honest they caught us off guard. We prepared way more on other maps. We still knew how they would approach Inferno, but after they picked it, we were really sure that they changed a lot of stuff trying to throw us off and not play the same as the last official." On individual performance: "It was funny. I know what my job is on the T-side, and to be honest, it was rough, a couple of bad calls as well. As soon as I got to CT-side, I feel like it's a new half for me. I'm on the bottom a lot of the time, so I can manage. There was a timeout where B1ad3 said they would test me one more time on B. They didn't, but I'm happy I got the clutch." On Mirage comeback: "I actually thought that we can make a comeback even to OT, because we felt so much better on CT-side compared to T-side. Usually, it's the opposite, or our T-sides are very strong in terms of, as soon as we get entries we're just all over the place. Today we had a lot of entries on Inferno, but kudos to MOUZ, they were just one step ahead on their CT-side. After we got the two last rounds on the T-side, and won the pistol, everyone understood this is our game now." Natus Vincere 12-11  MOUZ Natus Vincere 8-10  MOUZ Natus Vincere 7-10  MOUZ Slow start to the half, but MOUZ are finding their footing with Dorian "xertioN" Berman cracking open B with a precision headshot against Mihai "iM" Ivan on Catwalk. Natus Vincere 7-8  MOUZ Natus Vincere 5-8  MOUZ Natus Vincere 4-8  MOUZ Echoes of Inferno right now as MOUZ's 8-2 lead dwindled just ahead of the break. A double entry from Valeriy "b1t" Vakhovskiy granted Natus Vincere their third and this 1v2 clutch from Ihor "w0nderful" Zhdanov closed out the final round of the half after MOUZ gave away man advantages repeatedly, and now the pressure is on for MOUZ to convert. Natus Vincere 2-8  MOUZ Justinas "jL" Lekavicius is the only reason NAVI are in this at all, their only two rounds coming from his 1v3 and this clutch, which shouldn't have been close with Mihai "iM" Ivan in Window. Natus Vincere 1-6  MOUZ This is all coming up MOUZ right now, with Dorian "xertioN" Berman racking up five multi-kill rounds and destroying Natus Vincere's mid-rounds. Kamil "siuhy" Szkaradek and Ádám "torzsi" Torzsás's openers are getting early advantages, and this game is starting to look like how Natus Vincere manhandled MOUZ at the start of Inferno. Natus Vincere 1-4  MOUZ A tall task ahead for MOUZ if they want to force an Ancient decider: NAVI have been indomitable on their Mirage pick, with their last loss dating back to May against HEROIC. MOUZ are no pushovers and had a 12-map winstreak on the map earlier in the year, but were dumpstered 13-5 by NAVI at Esports World Cup the last time the teams faced off. A near crumble by the reigning Major champions on the very map they dominated FaZe on in the Copenhagen final, but they got it over the line in the end. Aggression in Apartments from Valeriy "b1t" Vakhovskiy dismantled MOUZ's defaults and let NAVI win all three CT rounds to close out the map, but at least we have a series now with MOUZ not rolling over. Natus Vincere 15-14  MOUZ Natus Vincere 13-14  MOUZ MOUZ have taken the lead for the first time on their map pick, and NAVI look completely flustered. They couldn't convert yet another 5v4 and floundered with their rotations in the late-round. Are NAVI just going to give this away? Natus Vincere 12-12  MOUZ Studio what, says MOUZ. An incredible comeback to force OT after this looked over at multiple points, and now it's a huge advantage with momentum in their favor. Natus Vincere 10-12  MOUZ Natus Vincere 11-8  MOUZ Natus Vincere 10-8  MOUZ Five straight from MOUZ, and these last few haven't been close with Natus Vincere getting only two kills across the last three rounds. Insult to injury as both were opening kills for 5v4s yet NAVI couldn't convert, and it's a two-round game now after what was a complete blowout. Natus Vincere 10-4  MOUZ Valeriy "b1t" Vakhovskiy went full headshot machine in the second pistol round, gooshing four MOUZ players and getting two kills to bag NAVI an easy round, but they've given away the advantage after MOUZ channeled them into a B stack with a force-buy. Natus Vincere 9-3  MOUZ This must have been a hard one to watch if you're a MOUZ fan. Kamil "siuhy" Szkaradek's side had a few opportunities to get into rounds early in the half, but were slaughtered upon entry to bombsites repeatedly with Justinas "jL" Lekavicius and Aleksi "Aleksib" Virolainen proving immovable on B. Back-to-back openings against Valeriy "b1t" Vakhovskiy in Apartments allowed MOUZ to add two to their tally before the break, though, so a comeback isn't out of the question once they swap to the CT side. Natus Vincere 8-1  MOUZ Natus Vincere 7-1  MOUZ Can't say I expected two batterings today, and definitely not in this fashion. MOUZ have nine kills combined, eight rounds into the game, with Ádám "torzsi" Torzsás yet to post a kill in what has been utter dominance from Natus Vincere thus far. Natus Vincere 2 -1  MOUZ A bold pick from Kamil "siuhy" Szkaradek and Dennis "sycrone" Nielsen, completely unexpected by the desk for good reason: It is their least played map and a strong one for NAVI. The curveball is needed, though, with NAVI on an 11-map winstreak on their Mirage pick. Just ahead of his team's semi-final matchup versus Natus Vincere, MOUZ's Dorian "xertioN" Berman shared a few words regarding the impending series, his team's quarter-final win over G2, and his current individual focus. On the win over G2: "I'm very proud of everyone. I think that we played super well on stage, and it's really nice to see, and we really showed our true level. I still think it was not our best, so NAVI should definitely be scared today." On xertioN's focus for the game: "Having fun. I think that was key for us yesterday. For me, it's just about having fun and creating the space for my teammates so they can shine. If I run through a smoke, I may look stupid, but I'm just trying to give confidence to my guys. At the end of the day, I'm just doing what is good for my team." On the NAVI matchup: "I think they are a similar team to us, they tend to play team CS. It's going to be about who plays better as a team today, I would say. I think individually we outmatch them on basically every role, so I am confident about our level today, but of course they are a very good team. I'm looking forward to the game, and hopefully we show our A-game today." Shortly after Vitality's victory over SAW, coach Rémy "XTQZZZ" Quoniam spoke to HLTV in a brief interview. Some snippets can be found below, alongside the video of the full interview. On final matchup: "Honestly, I expect a banger, it's going to be a close game. We will be happy to play NAVI because, for me, they are the best team in the world, and MOUZ for the revenge for EPL. No matter what, it's going to be a really good game." On not having any event wins this year: "I think we need to talk about it, because when you lose two finals in a row, or sometimes you feel you were pretty close even in the semi-final, we have to talk tonight and figure out how we want to approach the game tomorrow." How a Cologne win would affect Vitality's season: "I mean, if we win, we have something this year, and it could help for the future, especially for the Major. In two or three months is the RMR, we need that. We prepared for this tournament since after the break. We are in a mission, and hopefully tomorrow we win the trophy." SAW star Rafael "arrozdoce" Wing spoke with HLTV after the series against Vitality and admitted that his team was outplayed in every department. The Portuguese team will have no time to rest as they will play the RMR closed qualifier, which is slated to start on August 21. "We're not going to rest. We're going to continue to work hard," he said. On what went wrong: Let's just say they were the first team to fully study us. They countered everything we did on both maps. We couldn't play our game. On losing Nuke: We expected them to have studied us and to have a way to defend the A site. We tried to play a bit differently at first and then make some changes and start to lean towards A, but since we were constantly being countered and they were making good reads and winning duels, we didn't know what to do and couldn't recover. On lessons from this event: Anything is possible, we just have to want it and fight to be on these stages again and get the results we had here. Vitality 13-5  SAW After a tight start to Nuke, Vitality emerged victorious on SAW's map pick with a dominant second half, allowing them to snag the map 13-6. The international side kept up the momentum on their own selection of Dust2, taking fights with supreme confidence throughout the first half to take a 10-2 scoreline on their T-side, before closing the map out not long after on the defense. Vitality 11-3  SAW Vitality 10-2  SAW SAW seem like a shell of themselves after Nuke, offering up little resistance as Vitality has simply trampled over the Portuguese side throughout Dust2. Dan "apEX" Madesclaire's men are now three rounds away from securing their place in the final of IEM Cologne. Vitality 5-1  SAW I hate to be the guy to call it early, but stick a fork in SAW, they're done. Vitality 1-1  SAW Unfortunately that hype pistol clutch means little as Vitality answered back on a force-buy with Tec-9s. SAW even got the opening kill. Vitality 13-6  SAW It all started with the loss to pistols. SAW didn't look like the same team after the blunder, losing a bit of the edge and potency that has carried them thus far in the tournament. Once Vitality got onto T side the result was never in question. Dan "apEX" Madesclaire's men have been one of the best offensive teams all year, and nothing changed today. Vitality 11-5  SAW It seems SAW will be left ruing the loss to pistols in the first half. Vitality have put in a workmanlike performance since, winning their T pistol and never looking back. Vitality 5-5  SAW SAW are starting to lose control of a half they could have won by a large margin. The big issue was the fumble to pistols, sending the bomb in first only to lose it to a USP and a Deagle. The Portuguese squad then nearly managed to fend off a Lobby crunch, but Dan "apEX" Madesclaire stayed cool in the clutch. Vitality 3-4  SAW SAW have managed to hold on to the lead, punishing some Lotan "Spinx" Giladi aggression through Hut before hitting the A bombsite effectively. Vitality 1-3  SAW SAW are sticking to their usual T-side approach, staying grouped-up and relying on strong trading and firepower from Michel "ewjerkz" Pinto. Shahar "flameZ" Shushan stood tall in Vitality's first proper gun round to get his team into the map. Dan "apEX" Madesclaire stopped for a chat with James "BanKs" Banks ahead of the upcoming semi-final bout with SAW, and the Frenchman was confident his team were ready for the task. On if they can figure out SAW: Obviously we watched demos, and we're not gonna lie, we don't have to underestimate them. They play really good, they play amazing Counter-Strike, but we know if we play our A game we're gonna beat them. It's all about bringing our A game today. Props to them for making a semi-final in Cologne, it's just amazing and I love to see it. On being ready for an underdog: Of course we are ready, when you are Vitality you have to be ready for any opponent in the semis. We are even ready to lose rounds, lose a map, the important thing at the end is winning the BO3. Ricardo "roman" Oliveira was full of confidence when he spoke with Eefje "sjokz" Depoortere on the broadcast, saying he feels his team can beat Vitality. On playing on stage in Cologne: Just experiencing playing here every player hopes for, so it's incredible to be here, and coming out with a win, it's incredible. We didn't have time to feel it all the way, but it's been so good for us. We just have to keep doing it. On SAW's improvement throughout the tournament: What I'm gonna say is that we've been beating really good teams, and that's a really important factor for us because it will give us a lot of confidence against tier one teams. That was something we were dealing really bad with because we could never beat those teams, and now we feel like we can beat any team in the world. On feeling about facing Vitality: This is basically the same match as against G2 and FaZe. Those teams are also on the best level, so our mentality is exactly the same. If we do our best game, we can win. SAW have made history for Portugal by going further in a prestigious tournament than any of their countrymen have gone before, and by a long margin. Fellow Iberians Movistar Riders made it to the semi-finals of IEM Cologne in 2022, but can SAW go one better when they take on Vitality later today? Movistar Riders' run in 2022: SAW's run so far in 2024: Who had the better run, should SAW's end today? Zvonimir "Professeur" Burazin has been out on the ground in Cologne to find out what people miss the most about CS:GO. Are you in Cologne today? Make sure you grab yourself a HLTV photobook. If you aren't in Cologne, don't worry, you can order one online. Mihai "iM" Ivan, Valeriy "b1t" Vakhovskiy and Justinas "jL" Lekavicius finished Natus Vincere's dominant group stage campaign rated in the range of 1.35 to 1.43, featuring at the top of the leaderboard. The trio from the other group-topping squad, Vitality, aren't far behind, rounding out the top 10. The semi-finals begin in just under two hours' time and we have Vitality and Natus Vincere joining the fray in the LANXESS Arena after making it directly to the semi-finals from the group stage. First, hoping to continue their Cinderella run are SAW, who will take on Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut and company first after their three-map thriller victory over FaZe yesterday. MOUZ's stage fright was nowhere to be seen yesterday as they took down a G2 squad that looked unbeatable in their lower bracket group stage run just a few days prior. They're taking on Natus Vincere in the second semi, in a rematch from the Esports World Cup semi-finals:

header: Short news: Week 33
text: Into the Breach and Owen "smooya" Butterfield previously confirmed forthcoming changes to their roster, with the British player venting his frustration at an unnamed member of the team in a post-match interview. Since then, Into the Breach has played matches in Elisa Invitational Fall, YaLLa Compass Summer 2024 Contenders, and is currently competing in the second IEM Rio EU open qualifier with Karol "rallen" Rodowicz in place of Mohammad "BOROS" Malhas. The Pole has sat on ITB's bench since March and didn't return when the roster was rebuilt in June, but is aiding them in the interim while they finalize a replacement. Meanwhile, ITB is making jokes about the substitution, including a post saying, "Guys, BOROS is just at the dentist!" Mapcore's second big mapping contest, in partnership with FACEIT, has reached its second stage. The "Big Adventures" contest tasked community mapmakers to design an original 5vs5 bomb defusal or hostage-rescue map, with an open entry first stage allowing any creator to submit an entry that would be judged solely on "Fun Factor (Map Design)" and "Originality." Submissions for the first stage could be grayboxes (entirely untextured) or ones in creation prior to the announcement, as long as they hadn't been submitted to the Workshop. Now, the panel of judges have selected 57 maps to advance to the second stage, where map creators will have six months (until February 9, 2025) to iterate, enhance, and add texture to their initial submission before ten finalists are selected for "The Grand Finale." You can find the complete list of maps that advanced to stage two here. Ever wanted to know when the AWP is most useful? Or what the hardest situations are for the AWP to deal with? Who better to give the answers to these questions, and many more, than Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut and Ilya "m0NESY" Osipov The official CS2 Twitter account has taken a moment to highlight Cooper "Trucklover86" Phelps's impressive 1v5 Deagle play, suggesting it as a candidate for ace of the year. What do you think? You can view the clip in either the Tweet embed or the video embed below. In response to a Reddit user finding out that a team received $800 as part of their loss bonus for planting the bomb in the previous round — as opposed to $600, which is the new value following May's economy changes — ESL revealed the wrong server configuration used for the duration of the IEM Cologne quarter-finals. This also happened in the IEM Dallas group stage, which took place just a few days after the economy changes were rolled out. "This specific settings in the config was incorrect after switching from the Group stages of the tournament to the Playoff Stage," ESL Senior Product Manager Michael Parsons said. "The fault is due to human error and not a bug. We have reached out to the teams and will address the issue internally. We can confirm that this has now been fixed for the remainder of the games in the Playoff Stage." "The championship ended so quickly for us and I didn’t have time to say what I wanted to say on stage," began Ilya "m0NESY" Osipov on Twitter. "I want to send a message to a man who inspired millions of people, including me. Sasha, we are all waiting for your return to the pro stage. It's time to turn haters into your fans once again!" ESL released the third player profile during IEM Cologne, on MOUZ's IGL Kamil "siuhy" Szkaradek, just before he played in the quarter-finals: OG has gotten their priorities in order with a busy schedule in front of them, deciding to focus on the RMR closed qualifier and BLAST Showdown. As such, the team has stated they will not be participating in the upcoming open qualifier for ESL Challenger Atlanta. North American side FLUFFY AIMERS have announced the addition of Mexican rifler Edgar "MarKE" Maldonado, taking the place of Vova "bezymecc"  Slobodian on the team's active lineup. MarKE now returns to action after being on the bench of Nouns since mid-April, making way for the trialing of Anthony "CLASIA" Kearney before the eventual signing of William "RUSH" Wierzba. What a treat from Finn "karrigan" Andersen. As a "one-time thing," the Dane has released the entirety of FaZe's communications from their incredulous comeback against Liquid, starting from 1-11 in the second half. Johnny Speeds, a team that is slowly becoming one of the best feel-good stories hailing from Sweden, is bootcamping at NIP's facilities in Stockholm. The squad was praised by Ninjas in Pyjamas's Director of Esports, Erik Wendel, who said that "they're more organized and professional than many tier 2-3 organizations out there." Johnny Speeds recently broke into the top 40 in HLTV's ranking as they're quickly becoming a strong contender in Sweden and Europe's second tier. They are also a top 25 team in Valve's European Ranking, which means they are set to play in the Shanghai Major Europe RMR's Closed Qualifier. "This reminds of the old school 1.6 way of building a team and succeeding," Wendel concluded. "It'll be a lot of fun to keep following their journey, I hope they manage to qualify for the RMR, stay together, and keep climbing the rankings!" A small patch has just been released for CS2, with the most notable tweak being changes to "tagging effects" in order to "reduce instances of players experiencing teleportation when taking damage." Additionally, it seems that Valve have also introduced measures of some kind to track the utilization Snap Tap, although to what end this information is being collected remains to be seen. You can view the full patch notes of the update here. Wednesday saw the start of the first IEM Rio EU Open Qualifier, and several big names are already eliminated. Ninjas in Pyjamas are out after a loss to LEON, while ENCE were eliminated by 500. BC.Game, who are playing with Simon "KWERTZZ" Horák, are also out, as are GamerLegion, TSM, and Metizport. The first day of action is still underway, with the eliminated squads set to receive one more chance in the second open qualifier, set to start on August 18. You can take a look at the bracket here. Into the Breach have put out a Tweet saying that changes in their CS2 roster are imminent, confirming an earlier Tweet by Owen "smooya" Butterfield. The team built around the British AWPer had big expectations at the time of inception but is currently ranked at just No. 104 in the world rankings after a 50% win rate in the last three months. It is worth noting that the team utilized Qiang player Áron "Aaron" Homoki in lieu of Mohammad "BOROS" Malhas in their match versus ECLOT in YaLLa Compass Summer 2024 Contenders earlier today, where Into the Breach secured a 2-0 series victory. Christopher "dexter" Nong has put out a public appeal for analysts to work with FlyQuest after the team suffered poor results at IEM Cologne's Play-In, Esports World Cup, and IEM Dallas. "I had health issues," Sergey "hally" Shavaev told the Spirit IEM Cologne vlog. "We decided it was best for me to recover fully so I would not miss Cologne." Plenty more tidbits in the team's vlog from their disastrous Cologne campaign. This is likely to ensure the ranking is sufficiently up-to-date to work as a meritocratic invite system, but it does create some issues in terms of visas in such a short timeline. "I implore you, please rethink this decision," Complexity GM Graham "messioso" Pitt wrote on Twitter. "Set the window between 16 and 12 weeks. 16 weeks allows TO's to host their events in great, global locations, where visas may be harder to plan for." Danny "mahone" Hsieh and Leetify have released a video looking at the win-rate of starting T and CT, and common wisdom may be getting you in the wrong boat. Fluxo announced two changes. One is that Richard "chayJESUS" Seidy has been moved to the bench, while in Fluxo Demons it is Julia "julih" Gomes who has been removed from the starting five. Perfect World have opened up registrations for open qualifiers leading up to the Asia RMR closed qualifiers in various regions: - Rest of Asia- Levant and North Africa- Arabia- Oceania- East Asia- South Africa ESL released an hour-long podcast featuring Finn "karrigan" Andersen, Dan "apEX" Madesclaire and Aleksi "Aleksib" Virolainen from the IEM Cologne media day, in which the trio discusses the trials of in-game leadership. There are plenty of little tidbits and insight from each about their experiences being an IGL and their current and past teammates, and well worth a watch:

header: Vitality win IEM Cologne 2024 over NAVI after nail-biting 117-round final
text: The Paris Major champions lift their first trophy of 2024 and end apEX's 10-year hunt for the title in Cologne. Vitality are champions of IEM Cologne 2024 after laboring to a 3-1 victory over Natus Vincere in a clear contender for series of the year. Dan "apEX" Madesclaire missed his previous two chances to lift the trophy in the LANXESS in 2015 and 2019, but finally lifted the silverware to end a ten-year-long chase and bag Vitality their first title win in 2024. "Finally, after three Cologne finals, I'm leaving with the trophy," the ecstatic French captain told Eefje "sjokz" Depoortere after the match. He had every right to be overjoyed after he called a fantastic game in an incredibly back-and-forth series, with the first three maps decided by the slimmest of margins and Mirage being one of the best maps we've seen this year. NAVI will lament their chance to bag back-to-back trophies after their Esports World Cup victory, but with their third final in a row and a thunderous show of force in the series, continue to make clear their status as the team to beat among the best in the world. Aleksi "Aleksib" Virolainen and Justinas "jL" Lekavicius will be left in particularly dour spirits, the former unable to break his curse in best-of-five grand finals (now 0-7 in series, 2-21 in maps) and the latter finishing the series at the bottom of the board — a far cry from his Major-MVP level. Natus Vincere were hamstrung at the start of their series with leading MVP candidate Valeriy "b1t" Vakhovskiy pummeled in a woeful 1-11 first half on Nuke. A 3K and 1v1 clutch from jL was the sole beacon of light for the Copenhagen Major champions, helping them to a three-round streak, but with firepower not making the difference for Natus Vincere and apEX steps ahead of Aleksib tactically, Vitality romped ahead to an 8-4 lead. b1t's nightmare continued as apEX called a Ramp attack into him to net Vitality the second pistol, but that 10-4 lead didn't last long: A triple spraydown from Ihor "w0nderful" Zhdanov to fend off an A rush let Natus Vincere stabilize, and in the absence of b1t, Mihai "iM" Ivan stepped up. The Romanian was a stalwart for Natus Vincere in late rounds and repeatedly found multi-kills in rotation and at Door to power a comeback effort to overtime. However, his efforts weren't enough to make up for two crucial clutches going Vitality's way at the eleventh hour and superb entries from apEX, who made the difference to clinch a 16-13 win. Clip: apEX entries and ZywOo clutch set Vitality on map point NAVI won their first pistol to kick off Dust2, and despite Vitality disrupting their early defaults, jumped up to a 5-2 lead. Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut came alive with two huge multi-kill rounds to get Vitality back into the game, including one on a low-buy, but Natus Vincere went into the break with the lead and extended that with a second pistol and conversion, 9-5. Vitality had a clear game plan to abuse jL and b1t on B, and it was working: the defenses crumbled time and time again, but two back-to-back improbable retakes from NAVI stemmed the bleeding in a map that could've rapidly spiraled out of control. That abuse kept coming, though, as Vitality inched toward forcing overtime, but b1t went from absent on map one to a hero on Dust2 by recovering a 4v5 with a single-handed shutdown of the site to clinch victory. Clip: b1t shuts down B to win Dust2 NAVI, having recovered from losing their pick, came into Mirage with heads held high, a 12-map winstreak giving all the confidence they could have needed. A loss to a force-buy made for a poor start, however, and Vitality used that to run up a 5-1 lead with players disrupting NAVI's preparation by popping up in different spots than their normal positions. iM again was the hero for Natus Vincere with two big clutches and a Paris-Major resplendent level, which allowed NAVI to win six straight to end the half and gain the lead in the second, dominating in entries and going big in late-rounds for a 12-10 lead. Those chances to close the map was squandered by Natus Vincere, though, and in overtime ZywOo stepped in spades. His impact in overtime was immense as he single-handedly won two rounds, and w0nderful came alive too late as Vitality edged out a win in a triple overtime affair that contends for map of the year. The usual trend from a blowout map like that is the next ends up one-sided in a flat end to the series, and that seemed exactly what was destined. Vitality again came into Inferno with an excellent game plan and brutalized Natus Vincere in Banana round after round, and used that conditioning to run up a 10-2 lead at the break. Clip: mezii's heroic defense of A to set Vitality on series point A pistol win for Vitality, and it was over. Or so it seemed, until Natus Vincere showed immense mental fortitude and won six rounds in a row to close the gap. Just when the comeback looked to be a reality, however, William "mezii" Merriman bagged a triple kill as the sole A defender to set his side on series point, and Vitality finally got the job done two rounds later to clinch their tournament title.

header: ZywOo earns 20th HLTV MVP at IEM Cologne
text: Vitality's superstar stepped up in the LANXESS with a 1.34 rating in playoffs and overtakes device on the all-time list of HLTV MVPs. Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut has earned his 20th HLTV x 1XBET Most Valuable Player (MVP) award after starring in Vitality's intense run to the IEM Cologne trophy. The Frenchman has now overtaken Nicolai "device" Reedtz on the all-time list, and is just one behind his great rival Oleksandr "s1mple" Kostyliev who has 21 career MVP medals. Find all HLTV MVP winners on our dedicated MVP page. It is also his second LAN Cologne MVP after winning it in his rookie year at ESL One Cologne 2019, where Vitality lost to Liquid (and online for Cologne 2020 Europe during the pandemic.) This time, he leaves with both the medal and the trophy. HLTV all-time MVP winners (CS:GO and CS2) Oleksandr "s1mple" Kostyliev: 21 (5 online) Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut: 20 (6) Nicolai "device" Reedtz: 19 (3) Christopher "GeT_RiGhT" Alesund: 10 Kenny "kennyS" Schrub: 10 The MVP also puts ZywOo straight back into the race for a historic fourth HLTV player of the year title against upstarts Danil "donk" Kryshkovets and Ilya "m0NESY" Osipov, given Cologne's status as one of the most prestigious events in the calendar. "I will work harder every day to get back on my level," ZywOo said to James "BanKs" Banks on stage after winning the trophy in a trademark display of his modesty. "It was a hard tournament for me, my teammates helped me a lot." While few players would say that after a 1.31 rating at an event, ZywOo was right to credit his teammates. He hit some sky-high peaks before the final, with 1.76, 1.96, 1.86, and 1.77 map ratings before the final, but was less consistent than Shahar "flameZ" Shushan in groups and had a tough series against FaZe. Even after the fantastic final, ZywOo ended on the exact same kills per round win (1.03) and average damage per round win (103.4) as flameZ over the event. Ultimately ZywOo's step-up in the playoffs (1.34 rating, with flameZ on 1.17)  was what counted against his teammate and Mihai "iM" Ivan and Valeriy "b1t" Vakhovskiy from Natus Vincere to secure the MVP. And, as much as his humility should be admired, the arena is what matters most — and that is where we saw ZywOo maintain his sky-high standards as others faltered, with a 1.29 rating after 117 gruelling rounds against the world No. 1 in an instant classic of a grand final.

header: ZywOo: "I had never played this kind of final"
text: The French superstar said Vitality needed the boost from this win after losses in Dallas and EPL and added they "have so much more to bring to the table." Vitality emerged victorious from a thriller of a best-of-five grand final at IEM Cologne, taking down Natus Vincere in the nearly 120-round title decider to secure their first trophy of the year. Consistent as always and putting on a team-high 1.31 rating in the overtime-filled grand final affair, Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut came away with the HLTV Most Valuable Player Award. After the match, the French superstar spoke with HLTV about the victory and finally getting to the top step of the podium after two failed attempts. "It was an amazing final to play," he said. "I had never played this kind of final, and finally we won it. We really needed it after the losses in Dallas and EPL." ZywOo overtook Nicolai "device" Reedtz for the second-most HLTV MVPs and is now just one away from tying Oleksandr "s1mple" Kostyliev's 21 medals. But when asked about the chance to break that record at a time when the Ukrainian doesn't seem to be making a comeback anytime soon, ZywOo was humble as always: "I'm thinking about that, but at the same time, I don't care," he said. "I'm not thinking about getting an MVP every time I play a tournament." Congratulations on your victory. A crazy series with some really close games. What is going through your head? Ah, a lot of things. Now the pressure is going down. It was an amazing final to play, to be honest. I had never played this kind of final, and finally we won it. Yeah, amazing. It's tough to say something because the pressure is going down. We're just happy. Everyone is smiling now and it's amazing. I just want to thank my teammates because they played really well as well. It was a great final. Before the match, you had said you needed to play your best game to win. Are you happy with the way the team played? I think we played a good game, but it could have been way better. It's the final, so there's a lot more pressure on the table. Sometimes, we didn't play our game. But in the end, we won. Obviously, we're going to watch the match and talk about the mistakes we made. But in the end, we won, and we are just so happy with the results.
