This is your first trophy of 2024 after losing two finals. How does it feel to finally lift a trophy this year? We had kind of a joke. It was, like, 'If we win Cologne, we're just going to forget about Dallas and EPL.' And now, after winning Cologne, we're just going to enjoy. Our goal this year was to lift one trophy at least, and we've done it. We are happy, and we're just going to enjoy it now. apEX had been to two finals here in Cologne. He said in an interview with us that he really wanted to win this tournament or Katowice before he retires. Are you happy that you guys managed to win this one for him? Yeah, of course. We're obviously happy for him. Like he said in the interview, he wanted to win Cologne or a Major. I think we didn't really talk about that, but everyone did it for him. Everyone was really focused, working really hard before the second season. We were really prepared and we were focused on that. apEX, us, the team, we were ready to fight. You had the support of the Golden Hornets here, but it felt like most of the crowd was cheering for NAVI. What was it like to play against the crowd here? Actually, I didn't feel the crowd was favoring NAVI or anything because we were too focused and the Golden Hornets were on our side and gave us a lot of power and energy. So I didn't feel this. The Golden Hornets gave us everything and we're just going to enjoy this tonight with them and have a good drink. You had a massive lead now on Inferno but you took some time to close it out. It seemed like you were getting a little bit frustrated until that massive round from mezii. Why do you think that it took you so long to close it out? Do you think that maybe you were trying to hurry things up a little bit? Yeah, a bit. Maybe we took it too easy because we were leading 11-2 and we were maybe thinking that we had already won. But I didn't feel any frustration, I just felt that we were maybe playing a bit more scared or not together because we wanted to finish the game. But some players were talking during the game to say, like, 'Just take your time, we know what we can do during the game.' And we just finished it in a good way. You now have 20 MVP medals, the second-most overall, and you're just one behind s1mple. How does that make you feel, and do you think it's possible to beat s1mple this year? Maybe. I mean, if I have another MVP, I will be on the same level. To be honest, I'm thinking about that, but at the same time, I don't care. It's weird because I'm not thinking about getting an MVP every time I play a tournament. Obviously, the last day of the tournament I'm thinking about it, but when I am with the team, I'm not thinking about that. I'm just doing my thing, playing with my team. That's it. We are now entering a very busy period of the season. We have the BLAST Finals, IEM Rio and, of course, the Major. How big of a boost is this victory for the team? To be honest, it's going to be a good boost because we really needed it after the losses in Dallas and EPL. We have so much more to bring to the table. We know we made some mistakes. We have so much to improve and we can do so much better. So it's going to be a good momentum boost for the rest of the year. And hopefully, we'll lift another trophy.

header: IEM Cologne 2024 reaches third highest non-Major peak in CS history at 1.05M viewers
text: Only the 2022 editions of IEM Cologne and IEM Katowice reached higher peak viewer counts than Vitality and Natus Vincere's barn burner of a final. IEM Cologne 2024's grand final broke the 1,000,000-viewer mark, making it the event with the third-highest peak in Counter-Strike history outside of the Majors. Its peak count of 1,051,810, recorded during the final by Esports Charts, puts the 2024 edition of IEM Cologne in a select group of only four non-Major events to break the 1M viewer barrier. Most-watched non-Major events of all time, per Esports Charts IEM Cologne 2022 - 1,249,426 IEM Katowice 2022 - 1,122,015 IEM Cologne 2024 - 1,051,810 IEM Katowice 2020 - 1,002,132 IEM Katowice 2024 - 972,312 This year's IEM Cologne only trails IEM Katowice 2022 and IEM Cologne 2022, two events that FaZe won in dramatic fashion. First over G2, in a series which included a 31-27 marathon on Mirage, and then over Natus Vincere in one of the greatest series of all time, a best-of-five that went the distance. The Vitality and Natus Vincere final from this year's thriller now joins that pantheon, edging ahead of the IEM Katowice 2020 final between G2 and Natus Vincere that was held without fans at the Spodek Arena due to the outbreak of Covid-19. IEM Cologne 2024 reaching 1.05 million viewers puts it in 12th place on the all-time Esports Charts list once you include Majors, ahead of PGL Major Krakow 2017 (961,413) and StarLadder Major Berlin (836,306). It's still far below the all-time peak of 2.7 million viewers, however, which was reached at the first post-pandemic arena event, PGL Major Stockholm 2021, and the CS2 peak of 1.85 million hit at PGL Major Copenhagen earlier in 2024.

header: Vitality join the Intel Grand Slam race
text: Five teams are currently in contention for the $1 million prize. The Intel Grand Slam pattern has been broken. G2 had won two eligible events out of seven, MOUZ two out of five, FaZe two out of three, and Spirit a single one to create a 'V' shape in the official Intel Grand Slam graphic (which can be seen in the tweet below). But everyone knows that V is for Vitality, the newest team in the running after winning IEM Cologne. The French organization's incursion into the IGS standings also comes at the best possible moment, as IEM Cologne is an ESL Pro Tour Championship tournament (as are IEM Katowice and ESL-operated Majors). Winning one of these EPT Championships is one of the two requirements, along with winning four tournaments in a 10-tournament window, needed to pick up the $1 million prize. Vitality joining the fray means that the teams already in the running are one tournament closer to losing their eligibility due to the 10-tournament window rule. G2 have an EPT Championship under their belt from last year's IEM Cologne, but they must win two in a row at ESL Pro League and IEM Rio to complete the gauntlet. MOUZ have one more chance than G2, but no EPT Championship, and FaZe have one more chance than MOUZ, and also no EPT Championship. Spirit have only one title under their belt and five chances left, and their one title is an EPT Championship earned earlier this year at IEM Katowice. The IGS race is made up of: G2 (2 chances remaining) MOUZ (3 chances remaining) FaZe (4 chances remaining) Spirit (5 chances remaining) Vitality (9 chances remaining) The next eligible events are: ESL Pro League Season 20 — September 3-22IEM Rio 2024 — October 7-13

header: Vitality added to BLAST World Final team list
text: The IEM Cologne champions will face Natus Vincere, Spirit, and five other teams in November at the $1,000,000 event. Vitality are the third team to receive an invite to BLAST Premier World Final, the $1,000,000 event that has closed the year since its inception in 2021. This year, the Shanghai Major will have that honor, and it is still unclear exactly when the World Final will take place because of a scheduling conflict with the RMR qualifiers for the Major. The location is also yet to be announced after BLAST's deal with Abu Dhabi expired. The World Final's pitch is to bring the best teams of the year to one small eight-team LAN, and BLAST achieves that by inviting the winners of the biggest events: Major winners NAVI, IEM Katowice champions Spirit, and now IEM Cologne victors Vitality. Two slots also go to winners of the other BLAST Premier stadium events, Spring Final (which Spirit won) and Fall Final. The final slots are then decided by the BLAST Premier leaderboard, including if a team, like Spirit, wins two events that normally result in an invitation. Four slots will be decided this way, with FaZe and G2 now in fourth and fifth place after IEM Cologne. The final two spots will be more of a brawl, with MOUZ and Astralis in the lead but plenty of ranking points up for grabs at the final three events (ESL Pro League S20, BLAST Showdown, and BLAST Fall Final) before rosters lock on October 23. Due to Valve's rules around partner leagues, 2024 will be the final iteration of the World Final in this format. It will be replaced in spirit by BLAST Rivals, a bi-annual eight-team event that will invite teams using Valve's World Ranking. The team list for the 2024 World Final is currently:

header: Vitality claim No.1 spot after IEM Cologne victory
text: Vitality's win in Cologne was enough to see them surpass NAVI in the HLTV world ranking. IEM Cologne 2024 marked itself firmly in CS history over the past couple of weeks, not only by being the first iteration of the prestigious event to be played in CS2, but also due to SAW's historic underdog run and an instant-classic of a grand final, where Vitality defeated Natus Vincere to return to the top of the world ranking. As a result of the history-making that went down in Germany there was not only one team that experienced movement in the world ranking, with SAW and Spirit also seeing notable shifts. Thanks to their impressive run to the trophy at IEM Cologne Vitality have jumped two places in HLTV's world ranking to reclaim their place atop the pile, which they vacated in February of this year. apEX's side had not claimed a single title prior to their arrival in Germany, kicking off their season with a poor showing at IEM Katowice before finding their feet and claiming a litany of top-four and second-place finishes. 2023's team of the year did not drop a series on their way to the ultimate prize in Cologne and racked up a resume that included wins over FaZe, MOUZ, and incumbent No. 1 team Natus Vincere in the grand final. Powered by tournament MVP Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut and their ever-potent offensive halves Vitality had to battle through a 117-round epic to secure the title, making for a well-earned return to top billing. Portuguese squad SAW were the surprise package of IEM Cologne, a Cinderella run that began in the Play-in taking them all the way to the semi-finals. With a powerful trio of youngsters, potent teamwork, and effective anti-stratting at their disposal, SAW upset the likes of G2 and FaZe across a rousing campaign that was ended by eventual winners Vitality. In bagging an admirable top-four SAW made the deepest run at a Big Event of any Portuguese side in history, making their country proud and firmly building upon the promise they showed earlier in the year. They have been duly rewarded with a significant leap to the organization's peak HLTV ranking. The final notable ranking change saw Spirit slide down to No. 5 after their woeful performances in Cologne. The Russian side posted double-digit round totals on only one of the four maps they played, and exited the tournament without a win to their name.

header: FISSURE announce BB Dacha Belgrade S2 Play-in groups
text: Two teams will progress out of each group to the main event, where the likes of Spirit and MOUZ await. FISSURE has announced the group distribution for the play-in to the second BetBoom Dacha Belgrade event of the year, as well as providing HLTV with the schedule. Falcons, 9z, and FURIA are the three highest-ranked teams in attendance at the Play-in and will be hoping to reach the main event, where Spirit, MOUZ, Virtus.pro, and HEROIC await. The group distribution has thrown up a potential match for 9 Pandas anchor Evgeny "r3salt" Frolov against former side Aurora, after their unamicable split which saw Timur "clax" Sabirov go the other way. header: IEM Cologne grand final day as it happened
text: That's where the trouble began. That smile. damned smile. Here's the big three: Oleksandr "s1mple" Kostyliev: 21 MVPs (4 online) Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut: 20 (6) Nicolai "device" Reedtz: 19 (3) Speaking to James "BanKs" Banks: "Mirage was everything for the momentum. We would not have played Inferno CT that badly. We had an extended break to gather our thoughts, but they fully dominated us anyway. They deserved it." On positives: "I'm so proud, but it hurts a lot. There were a lot of map points. I'm happy. It was a banger of a final, both teams played a 3-0 CT side, an amazing game to play. But going home after Inferno sucks." On B1ad3: "He did a good job, in overtime you get one more timeout. He was really involved, between maps as well, and everything was needed in such a long game." The curse continues... It's hard to think of one better. An instant classic, especially that Mirage. Speaking to Eefje "sjokz" Depoortere on stage: On Mirage: "We threw three map points on Mirage. I told everyone, stay calm, shit happens, we didn't play well, but let's focus. Everyone had a good moment individually." They took their time — closing Inferno out, and to get their first trophy of 2024 — but Dan "apEX" Madesclaire and company have done it. apEX lost Cologne finals in 2015 and 2019. He lost finals at Dallas and Pro League in 2024. It's third time lucky in both cases. Vitality 12-8  Natus Vincere Vitality 11-7  Natus Vincere We don't want to jinx them, but that's five in a row. Four more and we're even. Vitality 11-3  Natus Vincere Four kills and a 1v1 clutch. A chance? Vitality 11-2  Natus Vincere The mental battle is over. It would take a miracle from here. Vitality 10-2  Natus Vincere Look at that dance of happiness! Vitality 9-2  Natus Vincere Vitality 7-1  Natus Vincere More pain for NAVI in the clutch. What a reverse from yesterday. Vitality 6-1  Natus Vincere Brutal opening for NAVI. They can't get anything done on this defence. Mirage seems to have broken them mentally. Vitality 1-0  Natus Vincere The usual trend after a map three like that would be NAVI getting blown out on map four. But are Andrey "B1ad3" Gorodenskiy's men made of sterner stuff? Pistol goes against them. This series is delivering on all accounts, and the viewership is there to match: according to ESCharts, Natus Vincere vs. Vitality peaked at 1,050,002 viewers at the end of Mirage, the third-highest non-Major peak in Counter-Strike history. Here are the top-four non-Major peaks after the new entry: IEM Cologne 2022 - 1,249,426IEM Katowice 2022 - 1,122,015IEM Cologne 2024 - 1,050,002IEM Katowice 2020 - 1,002,132 Inferno will begin at roughly 21:35 . Go get your dinner, this is far from over. They needed six map points but Vitality have done it! Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut ends on 36, and Mihai "iM" Ivan on 37. What a battle all the way through — a real contender for game of the year. Vitality 19-20  Natus Vincere This is masterful from Mihai "iM" Ivan, his 11th multi-kill. Milliseconds in it! Vitality 18-18  Natus Vincere Five map points squandered by Vitality! Ihor "w0nderful" Zhdanov was 17-22 after that whiff on Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut, but is now up to 25-23. Serious recovery from the young gun under the lights. Vitality 17-15  Natus Vincere Ihor "w0nderful" Zhdanov's nerves are showing at the worst possible time, as Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut wakes up. Vitality 16-15  Natus Vincere We've barely said Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut's name this map, but he's accumulated 26 frags and the latest two were disgusting. Watch for yourself. Vitality 15-15  Natus Vincere First NAVI get Mihai "iM" Ivan into Window to flank B, and then at 15-14 Aleksi "Aleksib" Virolainen calls the A Rush at a perfect time. Vitality 13-13  Natus Vincere NAVI miss the bomb falling on Short and Lotan "Spinx" Giladi takes full advantage. Vitality 12-12  Natus Vincere Vitality emerged winners on Nuke, what happens this time? NAVI have looked the better side in gun rounds, you must say. Vitality 10-12  Natus Vincere Mihai "iM" Ivan is in flow state, swinging everything — even a scoped up Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut — but finding the coolness required in the late round. Fantastic CT side play again. There's a reason he has a 1.60 (!!!) CT rating in Cologne so far. Vitality 10-9  Natus Vincere Thanks for the clutch Mihai "iM" Ivan! Unfortunately, CS2 is a bad game and winning it put NAVI in a terrible economic situation. Vitality 7-9  Natus Vincere Vitality 5-7  Natus Vincere 5-1 to 5-7 in a flash. NAVI looking good on home turf. Vitality 5-3  Natus Vincere There is a conscious effort from Vitality to upset NAVI's game plan, just like on Dust2. Players are popping up far from their usual positions: Connector player Dan "apEX" Madesclaire hiding on Bench on B, Lotan "Spinx" Giladi on A, or Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut under Balcony. But NAVI, after some economy struggles, are starting to work it out. Desk slam from apEX. Vitality 2-1  Natus Vincere Pistol went NAVI's way but that doesn't mean an automatic 3-0. Lovely Connector setup from Dan "apEX" Madesclaire and Shahar "flameZ" Shushan. Vitality 0-1  Natus Vincere Third pistol in a row for NAVI. One streak must end. But the desk aren't as convinced by Vitality's, who faced lower opposition and are more reliant on all-in executes than NAVI's brutal defaults. Aleksi "Aleksib" Virolainen's men the favorites for a 2-1 lead. 11-10, Shahar "flameZ" Shushan is set perfectly to catch NAVI pushing Doors. But then he messes up the jump on the box. His fault, or the game's? Vitality 10-13  Natus Vincere "Absent on map one, but shows up in map two," exclaims Chad "SPUNJ" Burchill as Valeriy "b1t" Vakhovskiy secures Dust2 in the 4v5. Vitality 8-11  Natus Vincere Two improbable retakes, but Vitality go back to the well with a third B pop and it succeeds. NAVI need to sort B out - retakes just aren't sustainable. You can see it on Aleksi "Aleksib" Virolainen's face. He's worried. Vitality 7-11  Natus Vincere Most teams would have saved. And they would have been right to. But NAVI pull it off! And they do it again the round after: A 2v3 on B this time. Dan "apEX" Madesclaire is going to pull his hair out. Vitality 7-9  Natus Vincere Justinas "jL" Lekavicius had to start round 16 with just a Deagle, and the round is decided by one frag: A Shahar "flameZ" Shushan entry onto jL's bonnet. You have to wonder how he would have done with an M4 and full utility. Vitality 6-9  Natus Vincere Vitality 5-8  Natus Vincere 2/2 pistols for Vitality on Nuke, and 2/2 for Natus Vincere on Dust2. Vitality 4-6  Natus Vincere Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut caught some flak from Janko "YNk" Paunović for a quiet Nuke but Dust2 is his playground for a reason. Shades of Nicolai "device" Reedtz in that one: Vitality 3-5  Natus Vincere Oh no NAVI. You have Vitality where you want them but it comes undone against Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut's Deagle. Vitality 2-5  Natus Vincere Oof, Not what he needed. Vitality 2-3  Natus Vincere Shahar "flameZ" Shushan pushes Long to kill Valeriy "b1t" Vakhovskiy, and then — in a 5v3 no less — Lotan "Spinx" Giladi pushes the B Tunnels smoke to catch Justinas "jL" Lekavicius. We know NAVI are a gameplan-heavy team, and Vitality don't want to let them dictate the pace. Vitality 0-1  Natus Vincere Dust2 will be a crucial pivot map for this series. Vitality have picked it often as of late, and NAVI will have to contend with the full extent of Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut and co's firepower. The Vitality fans will have enjoyed that one. He smashed SAW yesterday and map one ends with Dan "apEX" Madesclaire top of the scoreboard. Vitality 16-14  Natus Vincere He may have got annoyed at his teammates but what a response from Dan "apEX" Madesclaire individually! The choke from 10-4 to 12-12 on T side could have broken him. Instead, it vitalized (pun intended) him. Vitality's captain ends the map 6-0 in openers, with 23 frags and 6 multi-kills. Vitality14-14  Natus Vincere NAVI could have won this round in so many different ways. But France says no. Great mechanics from the Woo too! Vitality 13-13  Natus Vincere Scoreboard topping performance from the Romanian who has been so good on CT side all event. That pistol whiff is all but forgotten! Vitality 12-12  Natus Vincere Dan "apEX" Madesclaire finds the gap but Justinas "jL" Lekavicius says no to Vitality! 10-4 becomes 12-12. Vitality 12-11  Natus Vincere He's talked the talk and now he's walked the walk, with two key kills to start round 23. Vitality 11-11  Natus Vincere Dan "apEX" Madesclaire's frustration is boiling over now — just like it did against Spirit in London. Can't be helping his mates on Vitality. Vitality 11-10  Natus Vincere NAVI's comeback is getting more and more momentum, and you can see the stress on Vitality. Bit of a hairdryer treatment from Dan "apEX" Madesclaire in the tactical timeout. Let's see if it works. Vitality 11-7  Natus Vincere Justinas "jL" Lekavicius is so often the reliable closer for Natus Vincere but Lotan "Spinx" Giladi — who is having a great game at 17-9 now — gets the W. Key that the Israeli continues, a man who has been criticised for his arena play by the likes of Mathieu "Maniac" Quiquerez this year. Vitality 10-6  Natus Vincere 0/2 in pistols for NAVI this game, but a good start to the CT side when it comes to the gun rounds. Vitality 10-5  Natus Vincere As always, we'll have the best shots from the arena all day courtesy of Radosław "MAKKU" Makuch and Josip "brcho" Brtan. See the full gallery here. Vitality 10-4  Natus Vincere Psychological warfare from Dan "apEX" Madesclaire. Valeriy "b1t" Vakhovskiy is 1-11 at the half, and then he calls a Ramp rush right into the Ukrainian with Shahar "flameZ" Shushan getting the easy entry. Long way back now. Vitality 8-4  Natus Vincere Dan "apEX" Madesclaire pumped his fist after a key gun round win earlier on, knowing he had called the Aleksi "Aleksib" Virolainen fake correctly. Two great tactical sides here, which means it might come down to firepower — and NAVI need more from Valeriy "b1t" Vakhovskiy, who has been their best player this event and got the MVP at EWC. Vitality 3-2  Natus Vincere Justinas "jL" Lekavicius was the fuel behind NAVI's Mirage comeback yesterday with two key first half clutches. And he's delivered early on in the final — like he always does in these arena matches. Vitality 1-0  Natus Vincere William "mezii" Merriman should have had the highlight of the pistol round with three from Silo, but it's Mihai "iM" Ivan who gets the headline — for all the wrong reasons. He need to put this whiff out of his mind. And soon. Let's check in on the statistics behind the runs of Natus Vincere and Vitality to get a temperature check ahead of the grand final. CT side stats T side stats As we can see Vitality, as they have all year long, have been heavily reliant on their T sides. Their offensive halves, and how Natus Vincere handle them, will be key to this grand final. Natus Vincere meanwhile will want to take advantage of the poor CT sides of Vitality. Another thing to note is Natus Vincere's strong 4v5% on both sides; Aleksi "Aleksib" Virolainen is great at calling with the information garnered from an opening kill, even when it's one of his own players dying. Vitality player stats NAVI player stats Both teams have been getting fantastic production out of their players across the board. Many eyes will be on Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut, as he has a propensity to disappear in the big games at prestige events. Aleksi "Aleksib" Virolainen fans, look away. The Finnish IGL has a torrid record in BO5 matches at Big Events, stretching all the way back to 2019. He's only managed to win a single map across four series. Can he break that streak today? Aleksi "Aleksib" Virolainen spoke with James "BanKs" Banks on the broadcast ahead of the grand final, with the Finn thinking now was the time for his team to finally beat Vitality. On what it means for NAVI to reach three grand finals in a row: I think everything, right? Reaching three grand finals in a row is super good, reaching our goals step by step. Now we just need to challenge the BO5, challenge Vitality who are looking pretty strong, but so are we. On his bad BO5 record: I don't look at it at all. I know what we're capable of, I really trust this group of people and I know they trust me, so no matter the circumstances I know we can do it. On the matchup with Vitality: I feel like if there is a time for us to beat Vitality, it is now. We've practiced them a lot, we know their style, they're really explosive and have really good talents, but you've got to beat them some time. Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut had a quick chat with Eefje "sjokz" Depoortere as he entered the arena before the grand final, and he was clear about his team's need to focus on themselves. ZywOo: "We didn't think about the past, we are in the present now. For the game we will just focus on ourselves. I think NAVI are one of the best teams right now, so we need to play our best game to win." "We know we have one of the best teams in Vitality right now, so if all five play good, we can win this." Recent history does not favour Natus Vincere. Over the last two years Vitality have dominated this matchup, racking up a sizeable winstreak against their opponents in today's grand final. The stage is set for the showdown between Vitality and Natus Vincere, the best team of 2023 and arguably the best team of 2024 thus far. Up to this point in 2024, Vitality have been short of the form that saw them win five significant trophies last year, but here in Cologne, they have been back to their best. Natus Vincere were accused by many of fluking their Major win back in Copenhagen, but since then they have been working hard to prove the doubters wrong, and now may very well be playing the best CS of any team in the world. IEM Cologne would be the perfect place for Vitality to inject new life into their season, or for Natus Vincere to tighten their grip on the top spot in the world rankings. Who will take the trophy?

header: C9, B8 secure last Rio EU closed qualifier spots
text: NIP, ENCE, BLEED, and Monte won't have the chance to fight for a spot at the Brazilian event. The second IEM Rio Europe open qualifier has wrapped with Cloud9 and B8 advancing past 500 and Monte, respectively, to complete the list of teams who will fight over two spots at IEM Rio in the closed qualifier. ENCE were among the notable names who failed to advance, falling to No. 98-ranked kONO in a worrying loss ahead of the RMR closed qualifiers on Wednesday. Cloud9 were tested in the top half of the bracket, facing two of the four highest-ranked teams out of the top-16 in BLEED and Ninjas in Pyjamas. Aleksandar "kassad" Trifunović's troops nearly recovered from a dismal 3-9 T half on Anubis courtesy of a 2.16-rated CT effort from Joakim "jkaem" Myrbostad, but fell short in round 24 and had their qualifier run ended in the Round of 16. Ninjas in Pyjamas fared even worse on the same map as they started up 5-0 and 6-1 on the T side, but won just one round after that in a woeful display of Counter-Strike, with Emil "HeatoN" Christensen calling it a "horrible showing" and saying the team played "like a FACEIT level-eight mix." Cloud9's new lineup, meanwhile, looked solid with more time together under their belts, with its star trio all ending the qualifier averaging a 1.24 rating or higher across four maps. The team nearly let an 11-5 lead slip on 500's pick of Ancient in the qualifying match, but demolished the Bulgarian team 13-1 on Dust2 to advance with a more convincing win. B8 also had a close call against AMKAL in their Round of 16 match and needed overtime to take the win, but comfortably dispatched of Sashi 13-6 in the quarter-final to set up a qualifying game against Monte. The Polish-majority squad was almost indomitable on the CT side of Ancient, going up 9-3, but tallied just two T rounds in a shameful second half that allowed B8 to close out their pick. Mirage was less contentious as B8 edged out a two-round lead at the break and didn't relent, closing out the game 13-8 before Monte had a chance to recover. The eight teams who will compete from August 26-28 in a double-elimination, best-of-three bracket for two spots at IEM Rio are:

header: Valve take stance against Snap Tap-like features, remove jump-throw binds
text: "We are no longer going to allow automation via scripting or hardware that circumvent core coordination skills," the developers said. Valve have issued a blog post addressing the usage of keyboard hardware features and scripts that allow players to partially automate their movement in-game. In it, the developers have taken a hard stance against such features, which recently became a hot topic in the community following the release of Snap Tap and SOCD on Razer and Wooting keyboards, respectively. The two keyboard features, along with a config script equivalent known as 'null binds,' effectively removed the skill of coordinating multiple movement key presses while counter-strafing by prioritizing the latest key press. This is against Valve's idea of what is acceptable in Counter-Strike, the statement says, and players using these features will be kicked from their matches on official servers moving forward. "Developing one's coordination and reaction time has always been key to mastering Counter-Strike. Recently, some hardware features have blurred the line between manual input and automation, so we've decided to draw a clear line on what is or isn't acceptable in Counter-Strike," the statement reads. "We are no longer going to allow automation (via scripting or hardware) that circumvent these core skills and, moving forward, (and initially--exclusively on Valve Official Servers) players suspected of automating multiple player actions from a single game input may be kicked from their match." To prevent "accidental infractions," Valve also disabled in-game binds that include "more than one movement and/or attack action." Other than the aforementioned null binds, this also includes various jump-throw binds that have become prevalent in both professional and casual play. Valve has urged players who have a keyboard with input automation to disable the feature before they play on official servers. The hard ban on these aids comes at a crucial time. The qualification process for the Perfect World Shanghai Major begins later this week with online qualifiers taking place all around the world — some as soon as two days following the change. It is expected to impact professional play substantially, not least because keyboards with these features have quickly become widespread among pro players following their release this summer. With Valve's response also removing step-jump-throws, which allowed various advanced utility to be thrown with absolute precision, there is precious little time for players to adjust to the changes.

header: Jump-throw grunt now audible to opponents; VacNet 3.0 testing begins in new update
text: A minor gameplay change and a rollout of a new anti-cheat measure were tacked on in Valve's latest update. Valve took a firm stance against Snap Tap-like features and scripts that allow players to partially automate their movement in its latest update, rolling out measures to ignore certain multi-input binds and to detect and kick players from Valve-official servers for hardware-assisted counter strafing. Two smaller entries in the patch notes may have been overshadowed by the resulting conversation, one being that the grunt sound made to confirm a successful jump-throw is now audible to nearby players. The other is Valve taking further steps to combat cheating with the testing of "VacNet 3.0" on "a limited set of matches," with the developer asking to be informed in case of any accidental cancellations at its team feedback email. The complete patch notes can be found below: INPUT - Certain types of movement/shooting input automation such as hardware-assisted counter strafing will now be detected on Valve official servers, resulting in a kick from the match - Input binds that include more than one of the following commands will now be ignored by default. Support can be re-enabled using the cheat-protected convar 'cl_allow_multi_input_binds 1' sprint, reload, attack, attack2, turnleft, turnright, turnup, turndown, forward, back, left, right, moveup, movedown, klook, use, jump, duck, strafe, zoom, yaw, pitch, forwardback, rightleft - The jump-throw confirmation grunt sound can now be heard by other players nearby VacNet - Initial testing of VacNet 3.0 has begun on a limited set of matches. If you believe your match was incorrectly cancelled, email us the match details at csgoteamfeedback@valvesoftware.com

header: TheMongolz invited to Elisa Masters Espoo
text: The World No. 11 are making the trip to Finland straight after IEM Rio in October. The MongolZ are the latest addition to the Elisa Masters Espoo 2024 team list, joining 9z and ENCE to become the third top 30 team to receive an invite. B8 and home team JANO will also attend, after winning Elisa Invitational Spring and Elisa eSM, respectively, leaving just three slots to be filled. Garidmagnai "bLitz" Byambasuren and company ended last season in the top ten of the world rankings after winning YaLLa Compass 2024, but have not quite managed to build on that success after the break. They were upset by 3DMAX in the Skyesports Championship final, and — despite overcoming Eternal Fire and Spirit — would have been disappointed by a 9-12th placed exit from IEM Cologne after losses to paiN and SAW. The MongolZ have ESL Pro League Season 20 and IEM Rio in their calendars before Elisa Masters, with Rio's grand final taking place just three days before action is set to kick off in Espoo on October 16. The team list for the Finnish event is now:

header: Community reacts: Jump-throw binds are caught in the crossfire of Valve's Snap Tap ban
text: Pro players showed their shock on social media last night, as Valve removed jump-throw binds just two days before the Shanghai Major RMR qualifiers. Valve, a little over one month since Razer's Snap Tap feature was released and imitated by Wooting and SteelSeries, have made their stance clear: You are not allowed to use these keyboard programs in-game. "We are no longer going to allow automation (via scripting or hardware) that circumvent these core skills and, moving forward, (and initially--exclusively on Valve Official Servers) players suspected of automating multiple player actions from a single game input may be kicked from their match," their news post read. In order to effectively kick Snap Tap users, all binds with more than one movement or attack action have also been disabled. This means that jump-throw binds have also been banned, a decision that has left professional players scrambling to learn new grenade lineups just two days before the Major qualifiers. First of all, however, the response to the Snap Tap ban has been positive, with key advocate and KZ-fanatic Robin "ropz" Kool weighing in first. Keyboard manufacturer Wooting, who also argued against Snap Tap before introducing it to their hardware after a consumer poll, have also welcomed the news. Jokes were made at the expense of players who rushed to buy Razer keyboards, only for their key feature to be banned one month later. Razer's Senior Esports Ambassador Jimmy Malavong also saw the funny side. But the majority of professional players' reactions have not centered on Snap Tap at all, as they show dismay at Valve's decision to remove jump-throw binds. A small sub-section of the community, however, welcomed the change in a hope that harder lineups will increase the skill ceiling. A challenge for Valve — if they do want to enforce the ban long-term — will be avoiding easy workarounds, such as simply using two keys for jump throws: One for jump, and one for '-attack,' (a bind for releasing mouse1 more accurately) and simply pressing them at the same time. This method was common in CS:GO when jump throw binds were banned by ESL and other TOs.

header: HAVU release ottoNd and Airax
text: uli is now the last remaining member of the Finnish squad from the 2023 lineup. HAVU are down to three players after removing in-game leader Jussi "Airax" Airaksinen and AWPer Otto "ottoNd" Sihvo. The decision was made by new coach Petteri "peku" Jaakkola, a former assistant coach to Slaava "Twista" Räsänen at Rare Atom, who assumed duties in July. HAVU added Joel "Jelo" Lentonen in April after the departure of Matias "Banjo" Kivistö, but results did not improve and the team has slumped to No. 133 in the world rankings. "Motivation and the general picture in the performance was good before and after the summer break," peku told HAVU's website.  "It's a shame that many similar mistakes were repeated in terms of gameplay, which is why the roster change had to be made. "As for these player changes - one big point was the development curve of the players and its monitoring, like this with a three-month sampling. The players in big roles did not perform well enough, and the balance of the team was also a bit wrong in relation to the players." HAVU are now on the lookout for a new IGL and sniper to add to their rifle core of: Samu "uli" Leirilaakso Joel "Jelo" Lentonen Luka "puuha" Eklund Petteri "peku" Jaakkola (coach)

header: HLTV Confirmed: Snap Tap, jump throw, and IEM Cologne thoughts
text: Join the show from Chad "SPUNJ" Burchill, Milan "Striker" Švejda, and Zvonimir "Professeur" Burazin who attended Cologne in person are joined by Danish "Nohte" Allana for a new episode of HLTV Confirmed. The quartet will discuss Vitality's first tournament win of 2024, Natus Vincere's run, the difference between G2 and FaZe in groups and on stage, and the performances of MOUZ and SAW. The latest Valve update kicked off a lot of community discourse, so we will of course be hearing thoughts on the Snap Tap and jump throw ban, and how it will affect the upcoming qualifiers for the Shanghai Major. Topic list: IEM Cologne- Grand final: Vitality & NAVI- FaZe, G2 playoff flop- MOUZ & SAW stage wins- What are the odds: Astralis IGL Recent news- Snap tap and jump throw ban Road to Shanghai- Skinionaire- EU Closed qual groups- Major cycle roster deadlines Live broadcast on TwitchUpdates and clips on TwitterPast HLTV Confirmed episodesAudio versions of the show

header: BLAST ban Snap Tap for Showdown onwards
text: BLAST is following Valve's stance on the movement-assisting keyboard systems. BLAST has banned the use of Snap Tap-like assistants from Fall Showdown onwards, the tournament organizer has confirmed to HLTV. "Due to the recent update and stance from Valve, BLAST will not allow the use of the Snap Tap and SOCD or similar assistants that produce the same outcome for Fall Showdown and all future BLAST events," a representative said in a statement. The statement focusses in on Snap Tap, and does not mention BLAST's stance on the jump-throw binds that Valve intended to remove from the game in their latest update. Since the patch, however, players have found workarounds that act as de facto jump-throw binds. Jump-throw scripts are valid in BLAST's current rulebook under clause 11.7.1, reading "so-called 'Jumpthrow' scripts and binds are specifically allowed." It remains unclear how BLAST will enforce the ruling, since the auto-kick upon detection of any Snap Tap-like system has only been rolled out for Valve Official Servers at the time of this article's publication. BLAST matches are played on third-party servers, and will not have access to the system. ESL, meanwhile, is yet to take a public stance on the matter. BLAST Fall Showdown, an online event, begins in just two days time, with FaZe taking on Rare Atom in the curtain raiser. 16 teams will fight for two invitations to BLAST Fall Final, an arena event slated to be held in Copenhagen in late September.

header: All you need to know about BLAST Fall Showdown Fantasy
text: Showdown is expected to be the only online event in the 2024 Fall Fantasy season. - You can create your teams on the Fantasy page here. - Two eight-team, single-elimination, best-of-three brackets. - In a bracket like this, it’s important to get players that will have the winning run, or at least reach the last round. Picking your favorites to win both brackets is the surest way to a high placement. - Meanwhile, it’s worth noting that in the Spring Showdown three out of four teams that reached the final round were underdogs (SAW, OG, and Metizport were all ranked were in the bottom half of teams ranking-wise). The online format and singe-elimination bracket create opportunities for upsets, and it might make sense to hedge your bets to guarantee some points. - Since FaZe are clear favorites in their bracket, their prices are way bigger than those of other teams. But you can afford several sub-200K players from the other bracket’s main contestants, mainly VP, Complexity, and Falcons. - The users can count on both season points and skin prizes as follows. 1. Hydra Gloves | Mangrove (Field-Tested)2. M4A1-S | Hyper Beast (Field-Tested)3. AK-47 | Neon Revolution (Field-Tested)

header: Into the Breach replace BOROS with REDSTAR after 41 days*
text: The international side has opted for changes just over a month after the completion of the new lineup. Update 18:09 : Into the Breach have announced that Hristiyan "REDSTAR" Pironkov will be the man replacing Mohammad "BOROS" Malhas on the active lineup. The Bulgarian most recently plied his trade for the short-lived 5W lineup alongside Thomas "Thomas" Utting and Joel "joel" Holmlund. REDSTAR helped 5W to a first-place finish in their debut outing in Regional Clash Arena Europe 2024 with a 1.25 average rating across the event, before the team parted ways after being abandoned by the organization. Into the Breach have announced the benching of BOROS from their Counter-Strike roster. In brief comments on the decision, the organization said BOROS is "still a talent, it just ain't quite working," while the Jordanian lamented that it is the "first time I am happy to be benched." The move comes just 41 days after BOROS was announced as the last piece of Into the Breach's summer rebuild, which saw the British organization bring together Owen "smooya" Butterfield, former Guild Eagles duo Dionis "sinnopsyy" Budeci and Flatron "juanflatroo" Halimi, and Nicolas "Keoz" Dgus. In their short time together, a string of mixed results has left smooya's men sitting just outside the top 100 in the world ranking. The British AWPer has been vocal about the team's lack of results, recently stating in a post-game interview that he believes the team's results and work ethic have been "completely pathetic," adding that Into the Breach would be "top 30 in no time" if "the players are willing to do the hard work." BOROS' replacement is due to be announced at 18:00  according to the organization's post on X. Into the Breach is now: Owen "smooya" Butterfield Dionis "sinnopsyy" Budeci Flatron "juanflatroo" Halimi Nicolas "Keoz" Dgus Hristiyan "REDSTAR" Pironkov Gustavo "Juve" Alexandre (coach) Karol "rallen" Rodowicz (benched) Mohammad "BOROS" Malhas (benched)

header: BLAST Fall Showdown teams, format, schedule, prizes, talent
text: FaZe and Virtus.pro lead the pack as 16 teams fight for one of two BLAST Fall Final berths. 16 teams are set to clash in the online BLAST Premier Fall Showdown event, set to run August 21-25, with all eyes set on grabbing one of the two BLAST Premier Fall Final berths on offer. FaZe and Virtus.pro are the biggest names lined up to compete, but plenty of well-known rosters like Complexity, Falcons and HEROIC will be nipping at their heels hoping to overcome the odds to book a spot in Copenhagen. Cloud9 will be making only their second foray against tier-one teams since rebuilding their lineup in the off-season, OG will be facing their stiffest test since adding Christoffer "Chr1zN" Storgaard and Christian "Buzz" Andersen to the roster, and we will also get to see how pro players adapt to Valve's banning of Snap Tap and jump-throw binds. The format for BLAST Fall Showdown is straightforward. The 16 teams participating will be split across two single-elimination, BO3 brackets. The winners of each bracket earn a spot in Fall Final. Bracket A Bracket B 1-2. $20,000 + Fall Final spot3-4. $12,5005-8. $7,5009-16. $5,000 Desk Jacob "Pimp" Winneche Alex "Mauisnake" Ellenberg Interviewer James "BanKs" Banks Commentators Conner "Scrawny" Girvan Mohan "launders" Govindasamy Vince "Vince" Hill Jack "Jacky" Peters As usual, HLTV are running a fantasy game for you to test your CS knowledge and analytical skills. Join the HLTV league for a chance to earn points towards the $10,000 fantasy season, as well as the following skin prizes: 1. Hydra Gloves | Mangrove (Field-Tested)2. M4A1-S | Hyper Beast (Field-Tested)3. AK-47 | Neon Revolution (Field-Tested)

header: Shanghai Major qualifier super-week set to start
text: Online qualifiers will run all around the world from August 21-30 to find the remaining 29 teams participating in the Europe, Americas and Asia RMRs. The Perfect World Shanghai Major is more than three months away, but the first phase of the qualifying process for the premier competition is already due to start. Online qualifiers will run in Europe, North and South America and all over Asia in a super-week taking place from August 21-30, to find the remaining 29 out of 56 teams participating in November's Regional Major Ranking tournaments. Here's how it will all play out in each region: Only the 16 best teams as per Valve's Regional Standings can breathe easy in Europe after they've been invited directly to the RMR. Teams already at the RMRs (November 17-24) After open qualifiers were removed in the region, the only way to enter the Europe RMR is through the closed qualifiers, to which another 32 teams received invites based on the Valve ranking. The two tournaments will be played concurrently from August 21-23 in a Swiss format. The top eight teams in each group will advance to the RMR. Closed qualifiers (August 21-23) In the Americas, the eight highest-ranked teams according to Valve's Regional Standings have skipped the online qualifying stage and made it straight to the RMR. Teams already at the RMR (November 12-15) They will be joined by eight teams coming from closed qualifiers in North America and South America. Once again invited based on Valve's ranking, 16 teams will play in each sub-region for four spots at the RMR later this week: Closed qualifiers (August 26-28) Only three out of the eight participating teams in Asia have been directly invited to the RMR via Valve's Regional Standings: Teams already at the RMR (November 11-14) Five more teams will come from a series of two-stage qualifiers in China, Oceania, East Asia, Rest of Asia, and the Middle East, with each sub-region qualifying one team for the RMR. This is the only region to retain open qualifiers due to the lack of data there, and these will be used to fill each sub-regional closed qualifier up to eight teams. Open qualifiers - Arabia (August 21-22)- Levant and North Africa (August 21-22)- South Africa (August 21-22)- China (August 23-24)- Oceania (August 23-24)- East Asia (August 25-26)- Rest of Asia (August 25-26) Several other teams received invites straight to their respective closed qualifiers, though only Oceania had at least four teams ranked on the Valve Regional Standings: Closed qualifiers (August 27-30)

header: JiJieHao bench Kjaerbye
text: Kjaerbye finds himself warming the bench after only officially joining the team on June 30. JiJieHao has moved Markus "Kjaerbye" Kjærbye to the bench, sources with knowledge of the matter told HLTV, bringing to an end to the Dane's short stint on the starting roster. HLTV knows that Kjaerbye is taking some time off to deal with personal issues. Last month, he revealed that he had lost his sister to cancer just days before the Esports World Cup. No official replacement has been announced, but JiJieHao have registered Viktor "Duplicate" Mitev as their fifth for the upcoming Arabia RMR open qualifier for Perfect World Shanghai Major. Kjaerbye joined JiJieHao officially in late June having been without a team for nearly two years, last turning out for Endpoint in September 2022. He did however feature for the squad in the Esports World Cup MENA closed qualifier in April. The Dane's only HLTV-recorded LAN appearance for JiJieHao came at Esports World Cup itself, where the team exited after a BO1 loss to Sashi. Kjaerbye struggled in the aforementioned game, garnering a 0.63 rating as he posted seven frags across 21 rounds. JiJieHao are now: Issa "ISSAA" Murad Hussein "m1N1" Hijazi Osama "0SAMAS" Orabi Denislav "dennyslaw" Dimitrov Markus "Kjaerbye" Kjærbye (benched)

header: ESL forces teams to choose Rio or Atlanta qualifier due to "fairness to all participants" *
text: ESL mandated that the two qualifiers must have mutually exclusive teams. Update August 21, 10:10 : ESL provides explanation In a comment on the decision on X, SVP Game Ecosystems at ESL FACEIT Group Ulrich Schulze said the following: "Ensuring that teams do not play in qualifiers for events that overlap, i.e. they cannot attend both, is not about reducing opportunities nor is it about extra work for ESL admins. It is about fairness to all participating teams in the qualifiers. "If a team played in both qualifiers, won one of them and won or progressed far in the other qualifier, it would be unfair to any team they beat along the way in the qualifier of the event they ultimately did not attend. Simply inviting the runner-up of that qualifier would not solve for this. "I understand how this may be a source of frustration for teams affected, but they would very likely be equally frustrated if they were on the other side of the situation I described above." The team lists for the North America IEM Rio and ESL Challenger Atlanta closed qualifiers have been finalized following the conclusion of the open qualifiers. FLUFFY AIMERS and LAG join invited sides Liquid and Legacy in the battle for a spot in Rio, while NRG and Party Astronauts will face Nouns and Wildcard for a chance to play on home turf in Georgia, USA. ESL Challenger Atlanta is scheduled to run from October 4-6 and IEM Rio from October 7-13, leaving insufficient overlap for teams playing in the first event to arrive in time for the latter. However, the NA closed qualifiers for the tournaments do not overlap and are scheduled for August 29-30 and August 31 - September 1, respectively. Rather than allow teams to attempt to qualify for both tournaments and, in case one team qualifies for both, force them to pick between them, ESL mandated that teams had to pick the qualifier they wanted to compete in, including teams who were invited and those who advanced through the open qualifiers. NRG and Party Astronauts made it through the open brackets for both events but were forced to pick which closed stage they would compete in, with a third-place decider match played in the second Rio open qualifier to determine an extra replacement team ahead of Party Astronauts' decision. ESL's directive has been poorly received and openly criticized by teams and players in North America as it further reduces the already limited opportunities for upcoming teams to compete in international tournaments, particularly with both events taking place in the Americas. The team lists for the qualifiers are:

header: Perfect World announces CAC 2025*
text: The tournament will take place in October. 11:47  Update: PGL is partnered with Perfect World, which is running CAC 2025, and will not host another event simultaneously despite initially having the timeslot. Perfect World has announced the 2025 edition of the CS Asia Championships, the tournament's fourth iteration since its debut in 2018. There were also editions in 2019 and 2023, when it returned for the first time after the COVID-19 pandemic. CAC 2025 has been announced for October 1-13 in China, adding a second event to a period in which ESL will also run its own tournament. The CAC tournament series will also expand to 16 teams in 2025, up from eight in all its previous iterations. The tournament's previous champions were FaZe in 2023, MOUZ in 2019, and Natus Vincere in 2018. No CS Asia Championships event has been announced for 2024, as Perfect World is busy preparing to host its first Major, which will take place in Shanghai from November 30 to December 15. This is how 2025 is shaping up: January 13-26 - BLAST tournamentJanuary 29-February 9 - ESL tournamentFebruary 10-23 - PGL tournamentFebruary 25-March 16 - ESL tournamentMarch 17-30 - BLAST tournamentMarch 31-April 13 - PGL tournamentApril 15-20 - YaLLa CompassApril 21-27 - ESL tournamentApril 28-May 4 - BLAST tournamentMay 5-18 - PGL tournamentMay 19-25 - ESL tournamentMay 26-June 1 - StarLadder tournamentJune 9-22 - First MajorJuly 23-August 3 - ESL tournamentAugust 4-17 - BLAST tournamentAugust 20-24 - ESL tournamentAugust 25-September 7 - BLAST tournamentSeptember 12-21 - StarLadder tournamentSeptember 23-October 12 - ESL tournamentOctober 1-13 - CS Asia ChampionshipsUnknown date - YaLLa CompassOctober 18-November 2 - PGL tournamentNovember 3-9 - ESL tournamentNovember 10-16 - BLAST tournamentDecember 1-14 - Second Major

header: Introducing HLTV attributes
text: There's a new way to find out the style of a player, rolling out today on all stats pages. There's plenty of ways to measure a player's performance. From our very own forums to broadcasts and debates elsewhere, you'll have heard plenty about Rating 2.0, kills per round, average damage per round (ADR), and the like. What is harder, on our stats pages right now, is establishing the type of player someone is. Someone's frag count or impact rating may correlate with certain roles but to confirm if someone is an aggressive opener, selfless entry fragger, or baity lurker, you would have to actually watch them play. Until now. We're rolling out seven HLTV Attributes that show you the style of a player, not their performance. It won't be perfect, nothing ever is, but our database can see far more games than any scout: This will give you a glimpse into every player from Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut down to a 15-year-old that is coming up in a local scene. It's split into seven categories, that complement each other to build a full picture of a player. Each player gets a score from 0-100 in the seven, and the full scale is used: It's not like FIFA, where 70 is a bad score. 50 is the average score for a top-tier professional player, based on CS2 averages over one event. When you click a player's main 0-100 score in a category, a dropdown of more advanced statistics becomes visible. These include the classics you expect to see, as well as new stats like how often a player is last alive, kills and damage in round wins, how many opening kills someone gets specifically with the AWP, and more. And, most importantly for all you hatemaxxers, we have saving stats too. If you're unsure on what any of the metrics are quantifying, just hover with your mouse and some text will come up explaining each in more detail. There's two key filters, a side one (with toggles for Terrorist, Counter-Terrorist, and both sides) and whether you want to see stats per round, or per 24 rounds. The idea of making it per 24 rounds is to make the stats more similar to what you might see on a matchmaking scoreboard. 0.83 kills per round is a fairly inconspicuous number on its own, but 20 frags per 24 rounds is something you know intuitively as an impressive figure.  It's also helpful for Fantasy: Jimi "Jimpphat" Salo averages 3.7 trade kills per 24 rounds (one of our new metrics launching with attributes), making him a decent choice for the Avenger (4 trade kills in one map) booster. Now, let's get into the categories themselves with some examples. The first one, Firepower, is a bit different in that it is more of a traditional performance measure but it is useful in showing a player's raw output. It only takes into account kills, damage, and multi-kills to show which players are dealing the most damage without any complications from high survival rates or good round-to-round consistency to differentiate it from Rating 2.0. We then get into the true stylistic measures, with Entrying. This is measured using traded death stats to see who is the most common lamb sent to slaughter on the bomb-site entry or CT setups. Its twin and opposite is Trading, which uses traded and assisted kills to highlight players more likely to be second into a site. In combination, these two can tell you a lot. High Entrying and low Trading will usually be a supportive sacrificial entry. The opposite will be a trademark baiter. Some players will be high in both, as versatile members of the map control pack happy to go first or second. And some lurkers or super-aggressive space takers will be low in both, because they operate on their own so often. Next into the pie is Opening, which also complements Entrying. This one is based on opening kills and attempts to show the players most often involved in early-round duels. If a player is high in both openers and traded deaths, it suggests plenty of early-round tumbles as a pack whereas an aggressive lurker might score high in Opening but low in Entrying. It's important to stress that this is about showing what a player does most often, and not really about how good they are at doing it. Finn "karrigan" Andersen will have a high entering score thanks to how often he is traded as the bomb-site entry, but other players may do it with cleaner movement or a higher success rate and end up with a lower score. We are showing stylistic tendencies, not a player's overall skill. The opposite of Opening is Clutching, based on how often a player is in clutches (last alive  %) and how often they win them (clutch points). Clutches are pretty rare, so this is a metric that always benefits from large samples sizes, but for people who wanted a per-round version of the total clutches leaderboard here it is. Then we have Sniping, a simple one based on Scout and AWP kills, which is calculated slightly differently to make hybrid and secondary AWPers orange, primarys green, and pure rifles red. Finally, Utility is based on flashbang usage, flashbang assists, and overall utility damage to ensure flowers are handed out to specialists like Aleksi "Aleksib" Virolainen and Dan "apEX" Madesclaire. Now we hand it over to you. Play around with the 22 new metrics, including trading stats, clutching, and how often a player finds an opener with a sniper, and learn something new about the players at the top and bottom of the scene.

header: Dramatic r3salt-clax swap finalized moments before 9 Pandas' RMR qualifier campaign
text: In a series of twists and turns, the trade of r3salt and clax was first canceled and then finalized moments before 9 Pandas were due to play in a Shanghai Major qualifier. On Saturday, Aurora and 9 Pandas announced the trade of Evgeny "r3salt" Frolov and Timur "clax" Sabirov between the two sides. The situation was already charged enough with the Aurora organization and players insinuating r3salt had attempted to leave behind their backs, but the story didn't end there. In a dramatic twist, Aurora stated on Wednesday morning that the trade had been canceled on the previous day over the "non-fulfillment of all agreed-upon terms," and that the two players were to return to their former teams. This left 9 Pandas scrambling for a solution at the last minute, as they were due to play with r3salt in the European closed qualifier leading up to the Perfect World Shanghai Major RMRs later on the same day of the announcement. In a happy ending, the two sides have now come to a new agreement to finalize the trade, after all, just moments before 9 Pandas' first match in the RMR qualifier against Insilio was due to start. In a statement about the situation, 9 Pandas only said that the original problem that caused the trade to be revoked was "not financial, but in communication" and that a non-disclosure agreement prevents them from disclosing the exact details. "Despite the fact that the initial conditions of the transfer could not be met due to a number of hitches, today we were able to offer an alternative solution that satisfied both clubs," 9 Pandas said.

header: ENCE and TSM in trouble as EU RMR CQ day 1 reaches end
text: gla1ve's team is staring elimination in the face after two best-of-one losses. The opening day of the closed qualifiers for the Europe RMRs has come to a close, with teams like ENCE, TSM and AMKAL left fighting for survival after losing their opening two games. Despite being the highest-ranked team in Closed Qualifier A, ENCE got off on the wrong foot in the tournament and fell to KOI and UNiTY in best-of-one games. These results only add to a disappointing start to the season from Lukas "gla1ve" Rossander's team, who lost to PARIVISION in the CCT Season 2 Europe Series 7 quarter-finals and couldn't make it out of the Europe open qualifiers for IEM Rio. TSM's newly built full Danish team lost to BLEED and GamerLegion, while AMKAL, who are playing the qualifier with Emil "nota" Moskvitin as their fifth player, were defeated by Permitta and Sashi. Meanwhile, SAW, the highest-ranked team in the closed qualifiers, blasted into the 2-0 pool with convincing wins over OG and Qiang. The only other top-20 team in the qualifiers, BIG, recovered from a shock 13-3 loss to Passion UA with a 13-5 win over Insilio to end the day in the 1-1 pool. Below you can find the qualifier's standings after day one: Group A Group B The Europe RMR closed qualifiers will continue Thursday with the third Swiss round, featuring a best-of-three format for the elimination and progression matches. The match-ups are:

header: sAw as OG eliminate HEROIC from Showdown: "So many problems we need to fix"
text: OG's team play and game plan punished sloppy play from HEROIC. OG have upset and eliminated HEROIC from BLAST Premier Fall Showdown after securing a 2-0 win in their opening series (13-10 Anubis, 13-11 Nuke). Christoffer "Chr1zN" Storgaard and Christian "Buzz" Andersen's additions have breathed new life into an OG roster that has struggled to contest top opposition in the past year and spiraled down the rankings, dropping from around the top 10 to a fringe top 30-40 team. The Danish captain's move from MOUZ NXT is showing early promise in turning that around, however, with the team making it through the Europe open qualifier for IEM Rio, and now casting HEROIC out of the Showdown. The defeat adds to a downtrodden period for the Norwegian organization, which has struggled with visa issues for Abdul "degster" Gasanov and is on a streak of poor results with a Play-in elimination at IEM Cologne and group stage exit at YaLLa Compass before the break. "It was a rough match, and to be honest, we just didn't wake up for the first map, the first half, especially," a dejected Eetu "sAw" Saha said in a post-match interview. "It went without us being there fully, mentally, people weren't really able to find solutions. Almost everything we did was out of our control, and they were able to punish it. "It's super disappointing to go out so fast, especially since Cologne, how it went, and that gave us some extra time to practice and now we are not able to show any of that, going out so fast. It's a sad situation. There are so many problems, like by the looks of it coming into these officials with what we need to fix. Sure there are some close maps, but then you look at the rounds and it shouldn't even be this close. We should be able to capitalize on way more situations. Congrats to OG on the win, but there is no way that any team should be able to punish us with these kinds of plays, so often at least." It wasn't a pretty series for Damjan "kyxsan" Stoilkovski's men as they arrived on the server looking out of sorts, with a lack of coordination, teamplay, and awareness of gaps on display for much of the series, but particularly so in a disastrous 2-10 T side on Anubis. That blowout proved too large a deficit to overcome despite a recovery effort in the second half, and an equally poor start on Nuke, down 1-8, was again not one that HEROIC could pull back from as they fell just short of forcing overtime in the second half.

header: SAW, Cloud9, SINNERS and Sangal qualify for Europe RMRs
text: SINNERS surprised with their imperious run, whilst Cloud9 laboured but got the job done. The European closed qualifiers for the Perfect World Shanghai Major RMRs played out the first qualification matches today, with four teams sealing RMR berths. SAW and Cloud9, two names many expected to see at the RMRs, made it out of closed qualifier A, whilst Sangal and SINNERS secured their spots through qualifier B, with the Czech side surprising with their form. Tomáš "oskar" Šťastný put up absolutely stellar numbers across four maps to ensure SINNERS breezed through the qualifier in commanding fashion, such that the Czech squad racked up a 52-13 aggregate round score against solid tier-two opposition. Sangal, the other team to make it out of qualifier B, had a tougher time. The team has been in excellent form in tier-two in recent months, winning the last two CCT Season 2 Europe events, but needed overtime to get the win over BC.Game and were run very close by BLEED in both maps of their qualification series. Ultimately, the strong showings of Samet "jottAAA" Köklü were enough to get Sangal over the line in the close maps. In qualifier A, SAW confidently secured their RMR berth with minimal fuss, backing up their Cologne run by showing they were a cut above their closed qualifier opposition. Permitta pushed SAW close on Nuke in their qualification bout, but other than that, Rafael "arrozdoce" Wing, João "story" Vieira and Michel "ewjerkz" Pinto had no problem blowing away every opponent in their path. Cloud9 had perhaps the shakiest run of all, benefitting from a kind draw against a Johnny Speeds side playing with a stand-in before being run close by Passion UA. Things were toughest of all for Kirill "Boombl4" Mikhailov's men in the qualification match against 9 Pandas. Despite playing with a brand-new addition in Evgeny "r3salt" Frolov, 9 Pandas pushed Cloud9 all the way on Inferno before spanking them 13-1 on Anubis, setting up a decider. Cloud9 once again managed to eke out a narrow win on the decider, ensuring an RMR berth after some hard-fought matches. The resurgent form of Sergey "Ax1Le" Rykhtorov will be a promising sign for Cloud9, their star rifler a key component of the victory over 9 Pandas.

header: AMKAL snap nine-match losing streak against NIP in Fall Showdown
text: The Ninjas have been eliminated after another messy match against the struggling Russians. Ninjas in Pyjamas have been sent packing from the BLAST Premier Fall Showdown after a 2-1 loss to AMKAL in the Round of 16. The result is all the more striking given that the Russian team played with its head coach and was coming off a nine-match losing streak, during which it had lost to two academy squads, including NIP's Young Ninjas. AMKAL, who turned to Svyatoslav "svyat" Dovbakh after benching Daniil "Sdaim" Tupov earlier this month, will move on to face OG in the next round of the tournament. OG pulled off their own upset on Wednesday as they beat HEROIC in just two maps. It was a rematch of the messy Copenhagen Major RMR Overpass game, which AMKAL won after three overtimes. Tonight's match was just as chaotic (but with two more maps), and casters Mohan "launders" Govindasamy and Conner "Scrawny" Girvan couldn't help but burst out laughing at the succession of comedic moments. After losing back-to-back games in the RMR closed qualifier, AMKAL came out looking revitalized and cruised to a 13-3 victory on their map pick of Inferno. Ninjas in Pyjamas responded by winning Ancient by the same scoreline, with Fredrik "REZ" Sterner putting in a 2.05 rating. The Swedish player came up clutch in the decider map of Vertigo in a 1v3 situation as his team was facing series point in overtime. Ninjas in Pyjamas still equalised the score, only to collapse in the next set of extra rounds.

header: BLAST World Final moves to Singapore
text: The tournament will take place in the Southeast Asian city-state this year. BLAST has announced a new location for its World Finals in 2024: Singapore, where the tournament will move after having been held at the Etihad Arena in Abu Dhabi for the past two years. "We are excited to host the BLAST Premier World Final and the BLAST Dota Slam in Singapore," said James Woollard, Director of Market Development at BLAST. "The Counter-Strike event marks the first BLAST-branded event in Southeast Asia and the inaugural Counter-Strike tournament series in the region, solidifying Singapore's position as a world-class esports destination." The World Final 2024 will take place from October 30 to November 3, with eight teams competing for the $1,000,000 prize pool. All three of the previous champions will be present: Vitality, G2 and Natus Vincere, alongside Spirit and FaZe. Three more spots are up for grabs, one for the BLAST Fall Final champion and two more from the BLAST World Ranking, where the likes of MOUZ, Astralis, Liquid and Virtus.pro are fighting for those final invites. The team list for the event is:

header: ohnePixel's DRILLAS, JiJieHao among teams through to Middle East RMR qualifier
text: One spot at the Asia RMR will be up for grabs in the eight-team, double-elimination bracket. The open qualifiers for the Middle East RMR closed qualifier have concluded, seeing seven teams advance through the Arabia, South Africa, and Levant & North Africa open brackets to join NOM in a fight for a spot at the Asia RMR. The Levant and North Africa qualifier featured the most teams (15) and a handful of notable names, including Richard "shox" Papillon competing with SSG Ghouls, POGGERZ featuring the former Twisted Minds core of Shuaib "D0cC" Ahmad and Deyvid "h4rn" Benchev, and Volodymyr "Woro2k" Veletniuk's DRILLAS, a mix-team supported by streamer ohnePixel. The latter two won their best-of-threes to advance through to the closed qualifier, with Unlucky Much? claiming the final spot over Lebanon after winning the third-place decider. Only nine teams took part in the Arabian open qualifier, including Christophe "SIXER" Xia's Onyx Ravens and Issa "ISSAA" Murad's JiJieHao. JiJieHao played with Viktor "Duplicate" Mitev as a substitute after moving Markus "Kjaerbye" Kjærbye to the bench ahead of the qualifier, but showed no signs of struggle as they romped through the bracket alongside Onyx Ravens to advance, and beat them in the seeding match for a top finish. South African mainstay Bravado finished atop their region's qualifier, which featured 13 teams and saw Punishers claim the second spot over EXDHQ. The complete team list for the Perfect World Shanghai Major Middle East closed qualifier, set to play out from August 28-30 with one spot at the Asia RMR up for grabs, is:

header: Rooster qualify for ESL Challenger Atlanta
text: The Australian team will once again represent the country at an international LAN event. Rooster have punched their ticket to ESL Challenger Atlanta after emerging on top of the four-team Oceania Closed Qualifier. This will be the second trip abroad in 2024 for the Australian team, which attended the IEM Katowice Play-in at the end of January. Rooster have since lost star player Corey "nettik" Browne, who linked up with TALON. Rooster had to work extremely hard to come out on top of the double-elimination qualifier. They were sent to the lower bracket in the opening round by Mindfreak, forcing them to survive two elimination series to reach the grand final against The Art of War. With Hugo "Oath" Correia leading the charge, The Art of War won the first map of the series, Inferno, in overtime. Rooster responded with a comfortable win on Nuke before completing the reverse sweep on Mirage after overcoming a 7-1 deficit. Rooster join fellow Australian side FlyQuest and four other squads on the team list for ESL Challenger Atlanta, which will take place from October 4-6 at the Georgia World Congress Center. The final two teams will come from the European and North American closed qualifiers, scheduled for later this month. The team list for the North American is now as follows:

header: Complexity and Falcons to clash in Showdown quarter-finals
text: Virtus.pro also got an opening victory and are waiting for the winner of BIG vs. GamerLegion. The second day of the BLAST Premier Fall Showdown has ended, with three more teams making their way through the single-elimination bracket and three going home. Normality somewhat returned as the favorites prevailed in all three series on day two. OG knocked out HEROIC on the first day of play right before AMKAL beat Ninjas in Pyjamas in a wild series. Virtus.pro took out Zero Tenacity in two maps to kick off the day's action. The first was a fought-out Anubis, Z10's pick, which went down to the last round of regulation. On their home turf of Dust2 Dzhami "Jame" Ali and company were in command, turning a 7-5 T-side lead into a comfortable 13-8 victory. This victory puts VP in the quarter-finals, where they will face the winner of the BIG vs. GamerLegion series. Complexity and Falcons are set to face each other in the quarter-finals after their opening victories. The match is set for Saturday at 15:30 Complexity recorded theirs against Metizport, with star player Jonathan "EliGE" Jablonowski putting in a fantastic performance to earn a 1.80 rating in the 2-0 series. The North American has a 1.27 in the last month, just above his three (1.25) and six (1.23) month averages. A quick 13-2 on Metizport's Ancient pick could have made for a quick 2-0, but it got twisted for Complexity on Vertigo as they needed an overtime to break the tie after 24 rounds. It was smooth sailing, though, as they won it 4-0 to end 16-12. Falcons also needed overtime on their map pick against M80. After stealing Ancient 13-9, Marco "Snappi" Pfeiffer and company had to dig deep to tie it up after facing two map points on Dust2. In the end, they pulled it off in extra rounds as Spanish AWPer Álvaro "SunPayus" García topped the board with a 1.47 rating. Friday will mark the end of the Showdown's first round as BIG will face GamerLegion and Cloud9 will go up against paiN. The first quarter-final match will then be played to close out the day: OG vs. AMKAL

header: 1WIN, Enterprise, AMKAL and Zero Tenacity eliminated as EU RMR CQ day two concludes
text: ENCE and TSM stay alive after an early trip to the 0-2 pool, but have difficult matches ahead. 1WIN, Enterprise, AMKAL and Zero Tenacity have had their Perfect World Shanghai Major aspirations ended early after being eliminated from the Europe RMR closed qualifiers with 0-3 records. They were beaten by TSM, ENCE,  Insilio and Johnny Speeds, who advance to the 1-2 pool and have two more best-of-threes standing between them and spots at the Europe RMRs. Lukas "gla1ve" Rossander and Valdemar "valde" Bjørn Vangså's sides ended day one of the qualifier on shaky footing after best-of-one losses resulted in an early trip down to the 0-2 pool of RMR qualifier A. With backs against the wall, the pair recovered with better displays in their first elimination games by dispatching Enterprise and Abay "HObbit" Khassenov's 1WIN, respectively, with confident 2-0 victories, but won't have an easy path forward with fourth round matches against Monte and BC.Game. Insilio dispatched of AMKAL in Qualifier B, with Vladislav "Krad" Kravchenko's side edging out another overtime win on Vertigo a day after their messy game against Ninjas in Pyjamas, only to get blown out on Nuke and Mirage. Meanwhile, Johnny Speeds labored to a win over Zero Tenacity, requiring overtime on Mirage and scraping a 13-11 win on the Inferno decider off the back of multi-fragging from Jonatan "bobeksde" Persson. Below you can find the qualifier's standings after day two: Group A Group B The Europe RMR closed qualifiers will conclude on Friday with two, best-of-three Swiss rounds, starting with the 2-1 and 1-2 pools and concluding with the 2-2 matches for the final EU spots. The match-ups are:

header: BetBoom Dacha Belgrade S2 teams, format, schedule, prizes, talent
text: The second edition of BetBoom Dacha Belgrade kicks off on August 24. Here's everything to know about the $500,000 event featuring the likes of MOUZ and Spirit. BetBoom Dacha returns this week with the event's third edition, taking place from August 24-September 1. Once again taking place in Belgrade, Serbia, the studio tournament will feature teams ranging from the world's No. 4 and No. 5, MOUZ and Spirit, to some heavy underdogs like 42nd-ranked 9 Pandas, fighting for $500,000 in prizemoney. Below is everything to know about the event: BetBoom Dacha Belgrade Season 2 features 12 teams staggered across two stages: the play-in and the playoffs. Play-in 9z, Falcons, FURIA, Eternal Fire, BetBoom and Aurora received invites to the play-in stage, and they'll be joined by paiN and 9 Pandas, who secured a spot at the event through closed qualifiers in South America and Europe. They have been distributed into two groups, played in a double-elimination, best-of-three bracket. The finalists of each group will advance to the playoffs, where four more teams await after receiving direct invites. Playoffs The previous tournament's champions and runners-up, MOUZ and Spirit, have been seeded directly into the playoffs along with Virtus.pro and HEROIC, who will also be returning after taking part in the previous edition in May. The playoffs will be played in a double-elimination bracket, played in best-of-three series until the best-of-five grand final. BetBoom Dacha Belgrade Season 2 will take place from August 24-September 1. The full schedule looks as follows: Play-in Playoffs BetBoom Dacha Belgrade Season 2 offers $500,000 in total prizemoney, which will be distributed as follows: 1. $250,0002. $125,0003. $50,0004. $25,0005-6. $10,0007-8. $5,000Play-in group winners: $10,000 A six-man talent lineup will deliver the action on the official English broadcast: Commentators Adam "Dinko" Hawthorne Jason "moses" O'Toole Henry "HenryG" Greer Anders "Anders" Blume Hosts Pala "Pala" Gilroy Sen Anastasija "Heccu" Tolmačeva HLTV's Arron "Dempz" Dempsey and Dmitrii "Dimitrii" Novyi will provide full coverage of the event on location in Belgrade, Serbia, including interviews, photos and videos, and the latest updates from the ground.

header: Monte end ENCE's seven-Major streak in 1-2 round of the EU RMR's closed qualifier
text: Johnny Speeds were also eliminated in overtime on the decider map of their series with Rebels. ENCE, a mainstay in top-tier Counter-Strike, have been knocked out of the Perfect World Shanghai Major EU RMR Closed Qualifier by Monte in a three-map series. The Finnish organization will therefore not field a team at a Major for the first time since they missed FACEIT Major London in 2018, ending an attendance streak of seven in a row. The series started with Olek "hades" Miskiewicz single-handedly smashing his former team on Ancient. He went 21-2 to earn a 2.27 rating in the 13-1 thrashing. The Pole was benched from ENCE in May to make way for academy graduate Paavo "podi" Heiskanen, who ended up being his team's highest-rated player in the series, with a 1.19 by the end of it. It was not enough, however, as despite winning a close Anubis 13-11, the Mirage series decider went to the Polish-majority squad, 13-7. ENCE, who lost the team lead by Eetu "sAw" Saha and Marco "Snappi" Pfeiffer that won the organization's only trophy in the past five years, counted on magic and heroics to stay relevant early on in the year with a playoffs finish at IEM Katowice and a Major appearance in Copenhagen.
