Now, it appears that ENCE's pixie dust has run out as the team's discards, Paweł "dycha" Dycha and hades, have gotten one over them at a crucial juncture. Elsewhere in the closed qualifier's Group A, BC.Game and Rhyno were eliminated. BC.Game had won their opener against ECLOT, but couldn't cut it against Sangal, GamerLegion, and TSM. Rhyno had surprised with an OT victory against GamerLegion in the opening round, but also suffered took three Ls in a row against BLEED, UNiTY, and B8. Over in the B qualifier, one of the year's feel-good stories came crashing as Johnny Speeds were eliminated in a third-map overtime by Rebels. The Swedish team, who had been on a great run of form leading up to the RMR and even bootcamped at NIP's facilities in Stockholm in preparation for the qualifier, fielded a stand-in for Hugo "chawzyyy" Günther and couldn't make it through. Qiang, who came into the qualifier after losing support from their organization, PERA, were also eliminated in the 1-2 pool. They were taken out by Insilio in two maps. Sashi also survived to reach the 2-2 pool and will, therefore, play the deciding round of the qualifier as they took out ARCRED in a three-mapper that went the distance on the Inferno decider, 13-11.

header: BIG, Passion UA & ECLOT among teams through to Europe RMRs
text: Six more European sides have punched tickets to Shanghai. The 2-1 pool matches in the closed qualifiers for the Europe RMRs have come to an end, seeing ECLOT, PARIVISION and UNiTY come through Closed Qualifier A and 9 Pandas, BIG and Passion UA through Closed Qualifier B. BIG, the only top 20 team still trying to make it out of the qualifiers after SAW had gone 3-0, came back from a map down to beat Permitta 2-1. Johannes "tabseN" Wodarz's troops breathed a sigh of relief as the series' second map, Mirage, came down to overtime before they demolished the Polish side on Nuke. Passion UA edged past OG in a three-map series, while 9 Pandas defeated fellow Russian side Nemiga in just two maps with a great performance from their newest signing, Evgeny "r3salt" Frolov, who averaged a 1.32 rating in Closed Qualifier B. Over in the A qualifier, ECLOT were the first team to make it out of the 2-1 pool as they upset BLEED 2-1, the same scoreline by which PARIVISION beat GamerLegion. Shortly afterward, world No.99 UNiTY beat KOI 2-1 in stunning fashion, adding to the Czech contingent in Shanghai. The teams in the 2-2 pool will have little time to rest as the 2-2 pool will kick off shortly. The match-ups for these do-or-die clashes are: EU Qualifier A: EU Qualifier B:

header: OG, KOI, and BLEED miss out as EU RMR qualifiers reach end
text: The full 32-team list for the Perfect World Shanghai Major Europe RMRs is now complete. The Perfect World Shanghai Major 2024 EU RMR Closed Qualifiers have come to an end following the conclusion of the do-or-die 2-2 pool matches, with Sashi, Rebels, B8, TSM, GamerLegion, and Nemiga securing the final available spots. This means that all 32 teams set to compete at the Europe RMR in Shanghai are now known, with the participants set to be split into two 16-team Swiss groups at a later date. The Closed Qualifier A 2-2 pool saw three high-octane bouts between teams expected to make it to the RMR before the event. B8 were the first to qualify after a 13-1 demolition of Monte on Mirage, while TSM followed shortly after with their win over KOI. The final match was a clash between Aleksandar "kassad" Trifunović's BLEED and GamerLegion, and the Erik "ztr" Gustafsson-led team came out on top after a spirited 3-12 comeback on Mirage. The failure to qualify is a tough pill to swallow for BLEED, with their Serbian coach branding the exit "embarrassing" in a post-match tweet. Closed Qualifier B was a more subdued affair, as the favorites had already secured their spots at the RMR. OG were bested by Sashi in the biggest clash of the round to miss out on their second consecutive Major, while Rebels won the Polish derby against Permitta to secure a spot. The final RMR berth went to Nemiga, who beat Insilio in a three-map series that spanned 73 rounds. The full Perfect World Shanghai Major 2024 EU RMR team list is as follows:

header: The EVPs and Best Five of IEM Cologne 2024
text: iM once again takes the top EVP in an event where Vitality win and ZywOo takes the MVP. IEM Cologne 2024 delivered in spades, justifying its status as one of the most prestigious non-Major tournaments with the fantastic underdog run of SAW and culminating in Vitality winning their first trophy of the year. You would have bet your house on Mathieu "ZywOo" Herbaut winning the MVP if you knew that Vitality would take the trophy home, but it ended up being very close: ZywOo had a slow game in groups against FaZe, and only secured the MVP after hitting a 1.34 rating in the semi-final and final. The team effort behind Vitality and Natus Vincere's runs to the final means we are handing out plenty of Extremely Valuable Player (EVP) awards, so let's not waste any more of your time. We start with Mihai "iM" Ivan. Just like in Paris more than a year ago, iM put together a MVP-level performance only to falter in the final against ZywOo and Vitality. The much-maligned Romanian opener has experienced an upswing as of late, and ended Cologne with 108.7 damage in NAVI's round wins and a 1.50 CT rating. In the year since Paris, iM averaged a 1.04 rating. In the last three months, that figure has skyrocketed to 1.14. The narrative around NAVI has been one of a fantastic team with a strong tactical identity, but sometimes lacking the firepower of the superteams in the international scene. If iM can maintain this form, that narrative has a very early expiry date. Shahar "flameZ" Shushan came the closest out of any Vitality member to toppling ZywOo's record of taking the MVP in every Big Event tournament he has ever won. He was ahead of ZywOo after groups having starred against FaZe and MOUZ, but in the arena just fell short of securing his first ever MVP. Still, he ended just 0.04 rating points behind ZywOo on 1.29 in Vitality's map wins, and was similarly impressive in round wins (1.00 KPRW, 105.6 ADRW). Speaking of debut MVPs, Valeriy "b1t" Vakhovskiy grabbed his first at Esports World Cup and was set to go back-to-back after spearheading Natus Vincere's stomps past Group A and the win over MOUZ in semi-finals. He ends up being fourth in the list, failing to improve his case in the final — and hurting it on Nuke with a 1-11 K-D start in a map that eventually went Vitality's way in overtime — but he still ends with a very strong EVP. Lotan "Spinx" Giladi, the No. 5 player of 2023, has endured a quieter 2024 but at Cologne he stepped up when it mattered to grab his second EVP in three events. His clutching was impactful, winning six total 1vX situations including two 1v3s. His 4K 1v2 against Natus Vincere on Nuke was particularly impressive for a player whose temperament in the big moments has been questioned. Where to start with G2 and Ilya "m0NESY" Osipov? The Flash and company had a peculiar tournament, dropping to the lower bracket only to demolish Spirit, Astralis, and SAW with a 78-15 record in their six map wins (88-28 overall). That left all of their raw statistics fairly inflated, but the difference with m0NESY is that he put up a hell of a fight against MOUZ in the arena as his team around him faltered. Justinas "jL" Lekavicius had rightfully earned a reputation as a big game player after the Major, Spring Final, and Esports World Cup all saw him go up a level under the bright lights. That narrative took a hit here — he had a poor final by his standards, ending bottom of the 10-player scoreboard at a 0.95 rating — but his superb group stage and impactful clutches against MOUZ still proved his value to NAVI's run. SAW and Michel "ewjerkz" Pinto were the talk of the town after their run to the semi-finals, a stretch that featured wins over G2 (No. 5) and The MongolZ (No. 11) and was backed up in the quarter-final victory over FaZe (No. 6). ewjerkz was poor in SAW's losses, but by far their most impressive in the wins: He averaged a 1.41 rating (with Rafael "arrozdoce" Wing on a 1.26) in the six map wins and 1.09 KPR in round wins, enough for an EVP. Dan "apEX" Madesclaire didn't get his EVP but he is recognised in the Best Five. Vitality earned a staggering 66.7% T side win rate in Germany, a clear sign of both their firepower and depth of apEX's calling. In terms of roles, flameZ fits in as a CT anchor with b1t, which means one of him or iM will have to tweak their T roles. Given flameZ's 1.37 T rating, and iM's 1.01, we'll probably have flameZ on map control and iM as the aggressive lurker for a nicely balanced squad. Roland "ultimate" Tomkowiak was almost unknown before the summer break, but was scouted by Russel "Twistzz" Van Dulken and identified as the aggressive AWPer to alleviate Liquid's early-round issues. At Cologne, he has delivered the openers required (0.15 overall, 0.06 with snipers) but, more surprisingly, star level fragging output (0.81 KPR, 3rd). Unfortunately, he could not quite crack the high bar required for a group stage EVP after he disappeared in the crucial decider against FaZe (where Liquid were 11-1 up). He also earned his high numbers against FURIA and Complexity, opposition outside of the top ten. MOUZ, like HEROIC did in 2023, once again had a good team result but lacked a standout individual (with Ádám "torzsi" Torzsás coming closest) to crack the EVP list. FaZe had a similar story, where Robin "ropz" Kool and David "frozen" Čerňanský came close but did not quite stand out enough on a personal level. G2's rifling trio of Mario "malbsMd" Samayoa, Nemanja "huNter-" Kovač, and Nikola "NiKo" Kovač all recorded bonkers numbers in the lower bracket demolition job, but fell off in playoffs. When you split the value for the LB stomps in four, since the quartet all did so well, only m0NESY did enough for an EVP. apEX had a run of three EVP-level maps starting in the semi-final against SAW and carrying onto his overtime fragging display on Nuke in map one of the final, but was too inconsistent outside of those three maps. ZywOo and m0NESY both add to their No. 1 case as Danil "donk" Kryshkovets recorded his worst-ever LAN event.

header: TALON among four teams to secure spots in Asia RMR Oceania closed qualifier
text: Eight Oceanic teams will play for a single spot at the Asia RMR from Tuesday. All eight teams participating in the Perfect World Shanghai Major Oceania closed qualifier have been determined after the open qualifier reached the top four stage. Among the four teams to move on to the closed stage are TALON, a team put together this summer featuring former 100 Thieves and Renegades in-game leader Aaron "AZR" Ward, various talent from the region, as well as a European AWPer, Miłosz "mhL" Knasiak, and former Ninjas in Pyjamas coach Daniel "djL" Narancic. The AZR-led squad most notably beat SemperFi to join three other qualified teams — The Art of War, Arcade and Vantage — and four teams invited via Valve's Regional Standings in the closed qualifier. Only one Asia RMR spot is on offer in the Oceania closed qualifier, and it will be decided from August 27-29 in a double-elimination bracket. Below are the eight teams who will fight for a chance to stay on the road to the Shanghai Major:

header: chopper: "Changes are unlikely before and after Shanghai"
text: Spirit's in-game leader spoke at length about their IEM Cologne debacle and what they're doing to get back on their feet after the tough start to the season. To say the start of the second season has not gone according to plan for Spirit would be an understatement. Fresh off a victory at BLAST Premier Spring Final, Danil "donk" Kryshkovets and company entered the new season as the No. 1 team, but their form disappeared in a puff of smoke as they bombed out of the Esports World Cup and IEM Cologne after the break. The latter exit was a particular cause for concern, as Spirit only won eight rounds over three out of the four map losses they suffered against The MongolZ and G2 in Germany, and produced some early calls for changes in the team. Leonid "chopper" Vishnyakov all but ruled out the possibility of roster changes in the near future in an interview with HLTV, going as far as to say they are "unlikely to happen both before and after Shanghai, no matter what happens." While participating in media obligations for BetBoom Dacha Belgrade he delved in-depth into the reasons behind Spirit's horrendous Cologne exit, touching on issues with the team's atmosphere as well as his leadership as he took responsibility for their disappearance. You can read the full interview below, in which chopper also spoke about Spirit's consecutive losses to the new G2, Valve's decision to ban Snap Tap and remove jump-throw binds, and the upcoming campaign at BetBoom Dacha Belgrade: This interview was conducted in Russian and later translated by Russian-speaking HLTV staff. I want to start with IEM Cologne, an extremely unfortunate result for your team. What went wrong? In Cologne, we were a little disunited as a team. We had issues that we didn't solve before the event; it started after the break. And in Cologne, all of those small issues with relations or with the game showed and hit the team hard. After the tournament, we tried to solve everything, and we'll see how it will go at this event. You said that there were issues regarding the game and relations between the players. What do you think was the key factor? As for me, the greater factor was that I, as a captain, couldn't put the team in a lighter vibe so the players would be relaxed. I was thinking more about the game, not the atmosphere in the team. I think it was the biggest problem for me at the event. You lost to Mongolz in the opening match and to G2 in the elimination game. Which loss hit you harder? Both losses were hard to take. I'd say the second one was more of a knockout for us. In the first game we were at least playing, even though we had difficulties, but in the second game we didn't even join the server as a team. So it was a knockout game for us. You lost to G2 in Cologne and at the Esports World Cup. How do you explain losing to them twice? Is it their stronger new roster, or was it more about your form? I think there are several different factors. Firstly, I can say that they have a strong roster for sure, their players are in their peak form. They're charged, they have a light mood, no problems, and everything is well. They're still not winning events, but it's much easier for them to play now with malbsMd and Snax than with HooXi and nexa, it's 100%. As for us, there are also different factors. At EWC, we won the first map, lost Mirage, and not sure what the third map was… But there we had certain issues due to which we lost. I believe they were in good form, but we also played the third map terribly. We fought there, at least. Yes, we lost the first map disastrously, fought on Nuke, and on map three, what happened happened. In Cologne, we didn't even start playing from map one. In Riyadh, you can break down the game and talk about rounds and mechanical mistakes. If you watch the Cologne game, there's nothing to analyze. Spirit was absent from the server. After the win in Katowice, and overall considering the high ceiling that the team has shown, you can often hear people talking about changes in the roster. To put it straight, are changes in the team possible before Shanghai? Or do you rule out such a possibility? I think changes in Spirit are unlikely to happen both before and after Shanghai. You always need to give it an adequate look. We have a very young team. The backbone of the team, in my view, is the IGL, AWP, and the star player. And this core has been playing together for only half a year, it's so little. Also, some players are young. So I think that changes are unlikely after Shanghai, no matter what happens, because most players here haven't reached their peak form. And you need to look at the season: We won Katowice, then we reached playoffs everywhere with this young roster, and before the break we won a big event. It means that it wasn't like we entered Katowice and thanks to donk or peeker's advantage won the event. No, we won another event four months later. The team is putting in work and fixing the mistakes. Yes, we have a tough period right now, after the break we couldn't gain form, we had issues with the atmosphere within the team. But I think with proper work from everyone - and we're working a lot on this - everything will be fine, so it's unlikely for any changes to happen. Do I understand it right that you look at your performance as if the glass is half full and not half empty? In a sense that you're happy with how your young team has shown itself and what events you won, but if something doesn't work, it's still within your expectations. Do you talk through the issue of expectations with the team? That you probably need to have a more realistic outlook? That's a good question, because what happened in Cologne is that we had wrong expectations of ourselves. I don't know about the guys and can't speak for them, but I had expectations that we're a super team, we won two events, we're tier 1, tier S, and we need to reach the semi-finals at minimum. And I believe those thoughts of mine hurt the team. I'm supposed to have an understanding that we are a young team… And I do have it. I remembered it the entire season when we were working together. But after the break, I didn't manage to find these questions within myself. But now the team helps me and I look at it with a more clear view. So yes, we need to look at everything that happened as the glass is half full. We're a super young team. And donk's showing in Katowice was not his last performance, he will show an even better one. We have one of the best snipers and two great anchors. If we were not in form at that moment, we just need to step up, believe in each other, and everything will be well. Because we work a lot, spend a lot of time with each other, and it will have an impact. I presume hally has a significant weight in these conversations you mentioned. But who else is involved? Actually, a lot of people work with our team. Our coach, psychologist, and manager can always share their opinion. Our CEO also works with us, he also helps us sometimes. Team Spirit are doing everything, and I thank them for that. They help us with all sorts of issues: visas, travel, apartments, and so on. A lot of people work with our roster, and we just need to appreciate what people do around us and show a good game. Speaking again of hally, can you tell us why he was absent during BLAST Groups? hally had an illness, which is why he couldn't attend. But during BLAST he tried to help, he stayed in touch. But after that he got better and came to work with us at Cologne. Your team received an invite to IEM Rio but decided to skip the event. Can you tell us what went into that decision? We have people who are responsible for all of our travel, these are our manager, coach, and CEO. Honestly, I'm not very involved in this, but the guys said that we  would have a lot of events, and they didn't want us to get burned out before the Major. For the first time, this team is playing so many LAN events in a row - not just online, but on LAN. We had EWC, a week off, BLAST groups, five days later we had Cologne. We dropped out early, which is why we had a bigger break, but after that we're having one week at BetBoom Dacha, straight after that we're going to EPL, a week off, then we might have EPL playoffs, depending on the results. Straight after EPL there will be BLAST. The events go one after another, without a break. And to go to Rio, you need to spend two days on travel, you can't play praccs really. I'm expressing my opinion, not sure what came into the guys' decision, but I think it makes sense if we don't want to get exhausted and burned out and show the best we can at the events we will be playing. Valve recently updated the game, removing Snap Tap and jump throws. What do you think of this change and how was it taken by your team? Snap Tap didn't really affect us because we only got Snap Tap keyboards after Cologne. We looked around, everyone was using them. Some got really boosted by it, some did not, but it's not the point. We actually decided to give those keyboards a try, to practice them a bit. And we were playing with them for four or five days, everything is awesome, we really got into it. Cool feature! Boom, it got disabled. Damn, but we only got it… But whatever. Half of the team tried and I did like it, but it doesn't make a lot of difference for us, we didn't get used to it a lot. But I personally enjoyed it a lot. I tried it and was like, damn, Snap Tap is great! My player model is super nimble! When they removed it, I was like, how to play again? My model is slow again… But I only played three or four days, I don't think it will be significant. Regarding jump throw and run throw, it's quite surprising. My opinion is that if it comes down to pressing two or three buttons, and it depends on your skill, it's cool. Teams will indeed start to think about getting some grenade nerd to throw some of these nades, because not everyone will be able to do it. It will require more skill than just pointing and throwing. On the other hand, I don't mind jump throw. It's convenient, you don't need to practice anything, you just point and throw. So I'm fine with both ways, it's not crucial. The most important is for Valve to make up their mind on the matter. If they want it to be banned forever, then let it be like that from now on so people could train it. Give people time to show who's great at nades, and who's going to be failing them. But now most of the community doesn't like it being removed. Now there are RMR qualifiers, and half of the teams are struggling with grenades. Then just return them ASAP, in two or three days. But I just want stability, so we, as players, know if we wouldn't be playing without these binds for long, or we would be able to go back since most don't like it being removed. BetBoom Dacha. Last time you lost to MOUZ, this time you and them are also the main favorites. What do you expect from this event, and how important is it for you to perform well here? I just don't expect anything from this event. The most important thing for us at this event is to join the server and enjoy playing with each other. No matter the preparation, whether opponents know how we play or not, we just have to show what we're capable of. Because the last two events there were plenty of moments where we simply didn't show how we're able to play. Not only we didn't show our best, we didn't even show our normal level. For me it's important to just play CS and enjoy the game with each other. Neither maximum nor minimum, just normal. What place we finish doesn't matter. Everyone understands within the team that if we play our normal game, and just enjoy the game, we can win this tournament.

header: Complexity's woes continue with Showdown exit
text: The North American side notched just one series win over Metizport before faltering to Falcons. The quarter-final clash between Complexity and Falcons has drawn to a close, seeing Marco "Snappi" Pfeiffer's men emerge victorious after dropping their map pick of Nuke to kick off the series. For Complexity, this result adds to the team's tally of early exits since the conclusion of the player break. Although Jonathan "EliGE" Jablonowski and co. finished the first half of the year on a high note, the team has failed to find similar success since returning to action, with their most notable showing so far being their 9-12th finish at IEM Cologne. Complexity's members are now set to return to North America for a brief reprieve from their six weeks in Europe, before crossing the pond once again for their next outing at ESL Pro League Season 20. Falcons, meanwhile, now sit one series victory away from reaching the BLAST Premier Fall Final in Copenhagen, with the international side set to face the victor of Virtus.pro's game against BIG in their qualifying match. As for the series itself, Complexity got off to a solid start on Falcons's pick of Nuke, capitalizing off a 9-3 CT-side to snatch the map 13-6. Complexity failed to find similar success on Vertigo, as it was Falcons who hit the ground running in the first half, accruing an 8-4 lead on the defense. Although the North Americans managed to keep things close in the second half, sharp individual plays from Snappi kept Complexity just out of reach, leading them to lose their pick 10-13. Anubis saw another strong first half from Falcons, who carved out another 8-4 lead despite missing out on the first pistol round. After missing out on the second pistol round, Complexity were left with no room for error, allowing Falcons to quickly end the map with a 13-5 scoreline to send the North Americans packing.

header: 9z and paiN triumph in BB Dacha Play-in openers
text: Falcons and BetBoom stare elimination in the face after early trips to the lower bracket. 9z and paiN have claimed victory in their opening Play-in matches at BetBoom Dacha Belgrade Season 2, beating Falcons and BetBoom, respectively, to advance to the upper final of Group A where a spot in the main event is on the line. It will be a rematch of the teams' meeting just two weeks ago at IEM Cologne, where Rodrigo "biguzera" Bittencourt's side reverse-swept 9z to eliminate them in the lower bracket of Group A. paiN then moved past The MongolZ but fell short of making the playoffs to a red-hot G2. The Brazilian team's mission to bed João "snow" Vinicius into anchor roles and stabilize after losing Vinicius "n1ssim" Pereira following their Copenhagen Major run continues to bear fruit, with a 2-0 win over Cloud9 in BLAST Fall Showdown while in Serbia for BetBoom Dacha offering an injection of confidence ahead of the team's opening match against BetBoom. The Russian team got off to a torrid start to the series, going down 4-8 on their Mirage pick and losing it 8-13, with Pavel "s1ren" Ogloblin and Aleksandr "KaiR0N-" Anashkin managing five kills apiece. The latter had a resurgence in a back-and-forth Vertigo, where BetBoom recovered from a 6-9 deficit to steal the map 13-10, but a 1.79-rated showing from Lucas "nqz" Soares on the Anubis decider proved too much to overcome as paiN eventually closed out the map to take the series. 9z have been in a purple patch of form of their own in recent months, finishing top-four at IEM Dallas, winning FiReLEAGUE Global Finals, and fighting through the Play-in of IEM Cologne before their elimination by paiN. Maximiliano "max" Gonzalez's troops showed that same form upon arrival in Belgrade, 1.98 and 1.51-rated showings from Antonio "MartinezSa" Martinez and Matias "HUASOPEEK" Ibañez Hernandez powering 9z to a 12-round streak over Falcons to win Mirage, 13-5. Marco "Snappi" Pfeiffer's side were equally as dominant on Dust2, rolling over the South American team on the T side 9-3 before closing 13-7, but couldn't convert a 10-6 lead on the Nuke decider as a fantastic T side from 9z saw them win seven straight to close the series and cast Falcons down to the lower bracket.

header: r3salt: "I've moved to 9 Pandas to f*** even harder than I do now"
text: The new 9 Pandas rifler shared a number of details surrounding his hectic transfer from Aurora. In one of the more bizarre player transfers in recent memory, Aurora's young gun Evgeny "r3salt" Frolov was swapped with domestic rival 9 Pandas's Timur "clax" Sabirov, but only after a back-and-forth maneuver that saw r3salt briefly return to Aurora's bench before finally being allowed to transfer within hours of the start of 9 Pandas's RMR qualifier campaign. Even before the transfer had gone through, fissures between r3salt and his former teammates were apparent, with Aleksandr "KENSI" Gurkin and the organization insinuating that r3salt had attempted to leave behind the team's back. After completing the transfer, 9 Pandas managed to secure their place in the Perfect World Shanghai Major with a 3-1 in Closed Qualifier B, and the Russian side have now arrived in Belgrade to compete in BetBoom Dacha Season 2. Ahead of his team's first match in Belgrade, r3salt discussed his perspective on the chaotic transfer in an interview with HLTV, shedding light on his issues with Aurora, his feelings when it seemed the deal would fall apart, his hopes for his new team, and a potential face-off versus his former team, among other topics. This interview was conducted in Russian and later translated by Russian-speaking HLTV staff. Recently a player swap was announced between Aurora and 9 Pandas involving you. Aurora commented it in a way that implied that you wanted to leave the team behind their backs. What can you say about this? First of all, thank god the deal came through. Secondly, I've already said this, but there was no business done behind their backs. Initially, after two months of intense playing – we played online, then in Australia – I couldn't quite get how the training process would be set up. And when we got to work on that, I immediately started to tell the organization what didn't work for me, and a little after to the coach and some of the teammates. As for Norwi and KENSI speaking out… They knew nothing, but since they're so close with the organization's management, it sounds very silly of them. Because if the management knows, they must know as well. I remember reading about Norwi being in a restaurant with me, just two of us eating and chatting, and he thought whether I would tell him that I want to go to 9 Pandas or not. So he knew. On Twitter, Aurora published KENSI's comment where he spoke of you along the lines of 'rats that are fleeing the ship.' Why do you think they posted that? Could it be a misunderstanding, or are they trying to bad mouth you? I can understand the organization completely, they're just riding the hype train. One post after another, and everyone eats this, it's getting reposted, so obviously they would continue doing this. But they calmed down a bit, KENSI and Norwi did as well. But at first, there was so much shit. Even in the group chat when I was leaving, there were only curse words said about me, while I talked normally. Like, I share some reasonable thoughts on why things went this way, problems, why I left. I apologized for some things going wrong, and why I decided to go here. But they didn't want to take it sensibly and were only telling me to go to hell. That's it. You wanted to go to 9 Pandas, but Aurora is higher than 9 Pandas in the HLTV ranking. The team also had some small successes, particularly, when you won the online Skyesports Masters. From the outside, it can seem like a step back, but how do you look at it? Small successes tell nothing at all, I think about the prospects. I've moved to 9 Pandas to f*** even harder than I do now. Actually, if Aurora's roster developed, it could possibly be a top 10 team in the world. Me and the coach both had that opinion, we talked about this a lot, but because some players didn't work hard enough on the things that are important, it was not happening. So I wanted to move to a different team where I know how the process is set up. From day one, I could see that it's indeed the way I want it to be. And I think that after some time we will naturally be higher than Aurora in the ranking. So your main issue with Aurora was work ethic and the overall process that was set up there. Can you share more about that? Honestly, I don't want to get specific. But I saw people in comments saying that r3salt doesn't fit the vibe of the team. And I was like 'Okay, they watch the vlogs, it's just bullshit which I never even watched.' But one could think of something, like I walk in my headphones, I don't give a shit about anyone, etc… yet the vibe in the team was okay. We talked, we were all friends, family – no doubt. So my main issue was with the training process, and it was the reason for the move. Not long before the start of the RMR qualifiers the deal that was supposed to include the move fell through. But just before 9 Pandas' first match at the qualifier it was announced that the swap had happened. How did you live through that moment? When you learned about the deal falling through, what was your reaction? That was the worst night and morning of my life. I was messaging everyone that I felt like shit, and I really did. I didn't know what to do. I thought that the following day and following couple of months I would be out of business, because I would be benched and because they would want to punish me, so to say. I didn't know what plans to build. I really thought that I should go out in the night and find a hobo to stab me, and that's it. The following morning I had the same thoughts. But I was sitting on the first floor with spirit 9 Pandas Sports Director, there was another round of negotiations with Aurora. And then he starts smiling and lifting his finger, pointing up. And I understand that 'F***, seems like I need to go start warming up.' I got so f***ing charged. Played an hour and a half on deathmatch, after that a warmup pracc, and then the match. Those are indescribable emotions, that back and forth was just crazy. I had an entire week like that. All the guys in Aurora knew I would be leaving, but I didn't know how to even look them in the eyes. It wasn't comfortable for me. I acted nice, said hi, hit the high fives – just being polite. And then all the shit came out. What made you take this entire situation so closely? What consequences did you imagine it could have had? They would ask for an insane buyout for me, and some changes happening in some proper teams would be a great miracle. Even though there's some shuffle season opening up, it's not 100% that someone would be making changes. It could have been great if someone picked me up, but I couldn't count on that. This is why I had those thoughts. I wanted to play for 9 Pandas, and it fell through, and I thought 'What am I gonna do next?' I was already messaging harumi, saying 'F***, just pick me up as an analyst, I would be analyzing the RMRs with you and just chill…' Yeah, I had thoughts like that. During that ill-fated night, were you involved in the negotiations in any form? There were also claims that you supposedly bought yourself out, is it related to reality in any way? No, I was not involved in the negotiations in any way. I was comparing myself with my followers because I knew literally nothing. I was just sitting and waiting to be told that everything was cool and I would be playing. But at first, I was hearing 'Everything is bad, you won't be playing,' and I'm like, 'I'm in Aurora, great.' As for buying myself out, it's just a clickbait. I don't know why people post this, where do I even get that kind of money? Someone says that I took out a bunch of microcredits, sold someone… No, I would not have money like that, it's all 9 Pandas. And I thank them for that. You have already managed to reach the RMRs with 9 Pandas, you won the online qualifier with a 3-1 record. How did it go? Did you guys feel confident as a team? Or were you a little nervous since you just joined the team and it's already an important tournament? My goal is to just reach the Major, and if you want to do so, you need to go through the closed quals. And it's just a game. I played as usual, can't speak for the other guys. But iDISBALANCE was yelling in the first two games, and to me, it seemed like he was a little agitated. As for myself, I was just playing the game and doing my job on the map, which led to success. You're now playing BetBoom Dacha, your team got here via the Closed Qualifier. Do you have any goals or expectations from this event? I don't know about the rest, but I just want to play CS. If we beat someone, great. Like when we played Cloud9 in the 2-0 bracket at the RMR qualifier, we were playing really well. There were plenty of moments where either team got lucky. At this event, we just want to show that we're on a proper level, not just a top 40 team like we are right now. After some time, there should be a different number on the rankings page. You said you wanted to beat someone… Would you want to play against Aurora? I don't care, to be honest. If it happens, it's probably going to be cool for the viewers. But for me, it's not a grudge match, just a game like all others. I will be just playing my game, and that's it.

header: BLEED, B8 among YaLLa Compass Summer invites
text: The journey towards YaLLa Compass 2025 continues with a 16-team group stage. YaLLa Esports has announced the eight teams invited to the YaLLa Compass Summer group stage, completing the 16-team list for the Swiss bracket after eight additional teams advanced through the Contenders tournament. Four teams fresh from qualifying for the Perfect World Shanghai Major Europe RMR — Sashi, GamerLegion, B8, and Nemiga — are invited alongside four who missed out — BLEED, Zero Tenacity, AMKAL, and Monte. The teams join the likes of PARIVISION, SINNERS, and 9INE, who advanced from the Contenders stage, in the 16-team Swiss group stage that will run from August 26-September 19. Eight teams will advance through the best-of-three group to the playoffs, where another four invited teams will start runs from the quarter-finals and take aim at a top-two finish in hopes of securing spots at the YaLLa Compass 2025 closed qualifier. The team list for the group stage looks as follows:

header: FaZe, VP prevail in Showdown quarter-finals
text: The matches to decide the last Fall Final attendees have now been determined. The quarter-finals of BLAST Premier Fall Showdown 2024 have wrapped up, seeing FaZe and Virtus.pro move past their respective opponents of paiN and BIG to earn their places in the two qualification series. FaZe are now poised to face off against OG for a shot at the Royal Arena in Copenhagen, with the latter side having beat HEROIC and AMKAL to set up the clash with Finn "karrigan" Andersen's troops. Meanwhile, Virtus.pro will be squaring off against Falcons, who recovered from a rough start to their day with a loss to 9z at BetBoom Dacha Season 2 with a 2-1 victory over Complexity in the Fall Showdown. FaZe encountered little difficulty to start versus paiN, strolling through their opponent's pick of Anubis with a 13-5 scoreline. Their own map pick of Inferno proved to be far more difficult of an affair, as paiN's men emerged the victors in overtime, despite a whopping 31 kills from Robin "ropz" Kool. The tough loss on Inferno did little to mar FaZe's confidence however, as the international side quickly rebounded on their decider of Mirage, bagging another 13-5 scoreline to send paiN packing from the Fall Showdown. Virtus.pro's brawl with BIG served as the final match of the day, one that ended up being far closer than the match that preceded it. Dzhami "Jame" Ali's men made a game of BIG's pick of Ancient, crawling back from a 6-11 deficit to force overtime, only to fall at the final hurdle as the Germans locked it down 19-16 in double OT. Virtus.pro rebounded on their pick of Mirage, taking it 13-7 in a straightforward affair. Dust2 seemed like it would be going the way of BIG early on, as Johannes "tabseN" Wodarz and co. accrued an 8-1 lead on their CT-side. Unfortunately for BIG, the German side seemed to be a shell of themselves on the offense, garnering just two rounds as Virtus.pro roared ahead to take the map 13-10.

header: Steel Helmet among five teams to secure spots in China RMR closed qualifier
text: captainMo and company made the most of a second chance to book the final closed qualifier spot. The team list for the Perfect World Shanghai Major 2024 China RMR closed qualifier has been completed following the conclusion of the open stage. Steel Helmet are the biggest name to make it through the qualifier despite being far from convincing. The veteran squad required three maps to overcome red demon in the lower bracket final after previously losing to Bromo. The team, featuring veterans Ke "captainMo" Liu and Hui "DD" Wu, will be joined by XNL, Teamwork, SHPL, and Bromo in the closed qualifier. The tournament will also feature the invited trio of TYLOO, Rare Atom, and CatEvil. The Chinese RMR closed qualifier is set to start on August 27 and will offer one spot at the Asian RMR, slated for November 11-14 in Shanghai, China. The team list for the China RMR closed qualifier is as follows:

header: Magisk: "Sometimes we only start playing proper CS in the elimination matches"
text: Magisk spoke positively about Falcons' recent progress but noted they are still in a position where they need to play as much as possible to grind their way up. Falcons have experienced a modest uptick in form in recent weeks, whilst not always earning results commensurate with their improved play. At IEM Cologne they ran MOUZ close across a 1-2 series loss, took FaZe to overtime before being eliminated, and they just made it to the qualification match of BLAST Premier Fall Showdown by virtue of confident victories over M80 and Complexity. The beginning of Falcons' campaign at BetBoom Dacha began in familiar fashion, with the team playing reasonably well and running 9z close, but coming out on the wrong end of the result. Having bounced back with a comfortable win over BetBoom, Magisk sat down with HLTV to give his insight into the teams recent modest improvements, the reasons for the uptick, and his thoughts on his team's firepower. The 26-year-old was also asked about recent rumors of Nikola "NiKo" Kovač being close to joining the team for 2025, but did not give a straight answer either way. What are your thoughts after that game? It must be nice to get a convincing 2-0 victory. Obviously it's always nice when you win 2-0. I felt like we had it in control most of the match, it was a little rough at the beginning of T-side Nuke, but I think we adapted pretty well today, which was a good thing. We also did some good individual plays, but overall I feel like it was a pretty comfortable win. I'm just happy we are improving slowly, getting better from game to game, and also this is one of the reasons why we want to play as many official games as possible, to get to know each other and get to know how we should react, have a lot of learning from official games. That's where you learn the most, how you should react to certain situations and all these types of things. Right now, we're just trying to get as many official games under our belts, so we can get data about how we should improve. At the start of this Falcons roster, things were a little rough, but from the outside, it now seems you are starting to creep in the right direction. You are in the final of Showdown, you played pretty well in Cologne, you played well against MOUZ and could have won the first map against FaZe. Does it feel like that, like the progression is getting going now? Ever since we got dupreeh, I feel like it was the first time we could actually create a foundation and have the proper structure around the team to build up our tactics and playbook. From there, you just need a lot of official games to get to know each other and, in some way, get up to date with the meta. At the end of last year, me, Snappi and zonic missed the beginning of CS2 with official games, so we kind of had to catch up all the time. With the first edition of the team, I felt like that was impossible. Since we got Peter, that was the first time we felt we could build a team, a structure, and a playbook we could rely on. Since then we have been improving tournament to tournament, a little bit slowly, of course, but it is moving in the right direction. Against MOUZ in Cologne, we should probably have won that game. On the third map, Ancient, we had five rounds in a row where we could have broken their money, we had advantaged situations, and they made hero play after hero play. Sometimes that's what you need to convert those games. When we lose, we most of the time lose 1-2 and in close games, where we have the idea that if we just converted the advantageous situations we had, we could beat the best of the best. There's a long way from saying that to actually doing it, and that's what we're trying to do right now, find the consistency in the team and individually finding our plays. Obviously, we don't have a superstar, so it's difficult sometimes with the roles and all these types of things. We are all just trying to learn, there's a lot of people in new positions who have to learn a lot of things and get comfortable. As an example, maden is playing Conn for the first time in his career and there's a lot of learning lessons, about reactions, how to help people, how to take the space on the map, all these types of things. I think that's the process we have been going through, and also why it has been going a bit slow. But it's going in the right direction, which is the nice thing. What about dupreeh coming into the team allowed you to make this progression? Was it just having a more set five-man lineup, or is there something specifically he brings? Obviously, I love Peter, but I just think we needed a consistent five-man who could actually be professional in being there, all these types of things, and someone we could rely on. This is one of the reasons he was picked up, you can always count on dupreeh and count on him being a professional, someone you can trust in-game and outside of the server. We needed that in the team. We could have taken a gamble in getting a young talent, but sometimes you don't know what you're getting, and with all the rough times we were going through at the start of the team, we needed consistency and we needed to know what we could rely on. We felt it was a better choice to go with a veteran than a young talent, because we needed to get the foundation straight. How important are tournaments like this for a team in your position? There aren't all the top teams in attendance and you could put together a deep run. Do you see it that way, as a good tournament for a team in your stage? We were not supposed to play this tournament at the beginning, but after we couldn't qualify for the playoffs in Cologne we wanted to have more official games so we could get more data and prepare the journey for the RMR. Right now, we are in a position where we need to grind, we need to grind the ranking to stay at the top. It's a bit different from what we are used to, but that's the world we live in and we need to accept that. We are not at the level we want to be right now, which means we need to give everything, be able to look ourselves in the eye and say we gave 100%. If every other tier-two team is capable of playing tournament after tournament, then we need to put in the effort, and get the data we need from the official games to learn all the time. It's just what we needed, we needed to play more to get up in the rankings but also get the lessons learned, learned the hard way sometimes. That's why we're playing a tournament like this. There are a lot of games, a lot of opportunities, and a lot of best-of-threes. Recently the CS transfer rumour mill has been turning, and KRL said on stream that Falcons were looking to bring NiKo in for 2025. Have the team heard anything about this, have you had any discussions about these rumours? I'm here to focus on BetBoom and the BLAST Showdown, I'm not familiar with anything. I'm just focused on being present and being in the now. I cannot comment on rumours and stuff like this, so yeah, I'm here to just focus on BetBoom and BLAST Showdown. As a more general point, does the team feel in a good place in terms of firepower? It's the one thing where people will look from the outside and, like you said earlier, see that there is no superstar. Are you happy with what you've got? I think on a good day, we have the firepower to beat the best of the best, but doing it consistently is a problem. That's what we are working on, to find consistency in the individuals so that everyone feels comfortable, and also to get more experience in their new positions, to get all these teamplay things. We are a new team and although some people have played together, it's a mix of ENCE and Vitality. The only way you get to know each other is by playing official games. Sometimes we have lost games because we don't turn up individually, the way CS2 is right now you need to be consistent and make the least amount of mistakes because it's not that many rounds anymore, and with the economy and everything, you need to be really sharp from the beginning. Sometimes that's been our weakness, we start playing proper CS in the elimination matches, where the experience kicks in because it's all or nothing. That's something we are trying to work on, to be ready from game one. Sometimes the individual firepower is a little bit too inconsistent, but we are getting in the right direction. We are also now winning games when we don't feel like we are popping off individually, and I think that is a good sign.

header: FaZe and Falcons cruise to BLAST Fall Final
text: The eight teams set to face off in the Royal Arena in September have been decided. The BLAST Premier Fall Showdown has concluded, with FaZe and Falcons bagging the two remaining spots in the Fall Final over their respective opponents of OG and Virtus.pro. The team list for the competition taking place in Copenhagen from September 25-29 is now complete, and it looks as follows: FaZe have faced a number of shortcomings in recent months, failing to score many deep runs while also falling to sides like SAW and Ninjas in Pyjamas. Although the international side dropped a map to paiN earlier in the Showdown, FaZe recovered with a series win versus the Brazilians and carried that momentum into a straightforward victory over OG to move to the Fall Final. Likewise, Falcons are also a side that has struggled to attain notable results in recent memory, with a runner-up finish at ESL Challenger Jönköping being their most impressive showing in the last few months. After bagging an opening win over M80, Falcons had to contend with two of the highest-ranked sides in attendance, Complexity and Virtus.pro, but Marco "Snappi" Pfeiffer's men came out on top to secure Danny "zonic" Sørensen a place in the Royal Arena for the first time since 2019. FaZe's face-off versus OG kicked off the final day of play in the Showdown, with FaZe setting the pace early with a dominant 9-3 half on their opponent's pick of Dust2. OG pieced together some rounds after having a chance on the offense, but it was only a matter of time before FaZe stole away the map 13-8. OG were far more competitive to start on Ancient, managing to stay toe-to-toe with Finn "karrigan" Andersen's men to secure a 6-6 halftime scoreline. Unfortunately for OG, their T-side was not nearly as fruitful, garnering only two rounds before FaZe sent them packing from the Showdown with another 13-8 win Falcons's series against Virtus.pro proved to be a similarly one-sided affair, as the international side hit the ground running on their pick of Vertigo, snagging ten rounds to Virtus.pro's meager two. Dzhami "Jame" Ali and co. were not dissuaded even despite the dreary first half, eventually crawling to double-digits right after Falcons claimed match point. In the end, a 1v4 clutch from Álvaro "SunPayus" García would put the nail in the coffin on Vertigo, locking it down for Falcons 13-10. Virtus.pro's pick of Mirage saw Falcons secure another blowout half, going 9-3 on the CT-side. This time around, Virtus.pro were unable to make the map competitive in the second half, faltering 6-13 after briefly extending their lifespan with a pistol win.

header: paiN through to BB Dacha playoffs; BetBoom eliminated
text: The Brazilian outfit is the first team to make it out of the Play-In stage in Belgrade. paiN are through to the main stage of BetBoom Dacha Belgrade Season 2 after beating 9z 2-0 in Group A's upper bracket final. Meanwhile, BetBoom have been sent packing after a 0-2 loss to Falcons in the lower bracket. paiN join MOUZ, Spirit, Virtus.pro and HEROIC in the tournament's double-elimination playoff stage, which is slated to begin on August 28. Before that, however, they must play the group final on Tuesday, with $10,000 on the line. paiN and 9z had met each other just two weeks earlier to the day, in the group stage of IEM Cologne. Back then, the Argentine team had taken a map off paiN, exacting revenge for the loss in the group stage of the FiReLEAGUE 2024 Global Finals at the end of the season. This time around, Rodrigo "biguzera" Bittencourt's troops required only two maps to move past their South American rivals. They ran out 13-9 winners on 9z's map pick of Nuke before coming back from 7-1 down on Inferno to win the map 13-10. In the group's lower bracket final, BetBoom were no match for Falcons, who produced an improved performance after yesterday's fade-away against 9z. This means that, for the second time in a row, BetBoom exit the company's own tournament without a single win to their name. In April, the team finished bottom of their group following losses to MOUZ and Falcons. Álvaro "SunPayus" García topped the scoreboard for Falcons on both maps while only rarely using the AWP - providing much-needed versatility to a team that has struggled for firepower all year long. Falcons are set for a rematch against 9z on Monday, with the team also taking part in the BLAST Premier Fall Showdown and IEM Rio.

header: PARIVISION disqualified from Europe RMR over banned coach involvement*
text: Multiple staff members and a coach permanently banned from Valve-sponsored events were present in the room during at least one of PARIVISION's games in the EU RMR closed qualifier. 17:15  Update: PARIVISION rifler Robert "Patsi" Isyanov has since commented on his team's disqualification, describing it as "the most ridiculous and sad situation in a career (if not in life)." Perfect World, the organizers of the Shanghai Major, have announced that PARIVISION have been disqualified from the Europe RMRs due to having a Valve-banned individual present during their closed qualifier campaign. With PARIVISION's disqualification, the final spot in the Europe RMRs will be decided via a three-team single-elimination bracket. BLEED, Monte, and KOI will fight for the final RMR berth on offer as the three squads finished Closed Qualifier A with a 2-3 record, with BLEED receiving a bye into the final decider match due to having the highest Bucholz score of the trio. PARIVISION found itself in the crosshairs after a video of their post-match celebrations was posted on social media following their win against GamerLegion in the 2-1 qualification match. In the now-deleted footage, the team was surrounded by multiple staff members, including their coach, Ivan "F_1N" Kochugov. Not only is it against Valve's Major rules to have team staff present in the room for online matches in the Major cycle, but F_1N is also banned from participating in Valve Majors entirely. Despite that, sources told HLTV that F_1N was submitted as PARIVISION's coach as part of their official lineup, which indicates an oversight on Perfect World's part. Valve's Major rulebook, section Stage Integrity, sub-section Team staff restrictions says: "In the case of any matches where event admins are not physically present (e.g. online matches), no team staff, including the coach, may be physically or virtually present or communicate with the players at any time during the match." F_1N was one of over 30 coaches suspended in 2020 for using the infamous coach bug, which could give an unfair information advantage to the user. The 40-year-old was found to have used it in six official matches for 34 rounds, enough to earn a permanent ban from Valve, while the Esports Integrity Commission (ESIC) barred him from their member events for nearly nine months. "It should be noted that Valve bans are by default the highest priority eligibility-related ruleset in any official event," reads Perfect World's statement. "When these bans are well-known and established beforehand, as was the case here, it is expected that all teams should follow these eligibility rules prior to any further participation in an official event."

header: biguzera: "My feeling is I'm the team's father"
text: paiN's captain has his sights set on reaching the final in Belgrade. After falling just short of qualifying for playoffs at IEM Cologne, paiN have returned to competition with haste, competing in BetBoom Dacha Season 2 in Belgrade, Serbia. So far, the Brazilian side have found success in this outing, bagging wins over BetBoom and domestic rivals 9z to secure a place in the top eight of the event alongside names like MOUZ and Spirit. Not long after his team's victory over 9z, paiN captain Rodrigo "biguzera" Bittencourt shared his thoughts with HLTV regarding the matchup versus the South American side, paiN's aims for the event, and what the team is working to improve on in order to be able to contend with top teams. Congratulations on a 2-0 victory, but it was a pretty tough game. Yeah, it always is against 9z. They play so well all the time, and against them we never know how it will be, we just know it's gonna be difficult. You have played them a fair bit recently, obviously you played them in Cologne, does that make it harder? Yeah, of course when we play a lot against someone we know about each other. The tournament so far has been good, you have two wins. Are these the type of tournaments you look at and think paiN can go really deep, maybe make a final? Because there's a few top teams here, but not all the best teams in the world. Yeah of course. I think this kind of tournament we have a big chance to go far, to go deep, maybe a final or win the tournament. In general, paiN are on the verge of taking the next step and getting into that top echelon of teams. What do you think you need to do to get there, to take that next step to improve? Maybe I could say the usual words, 'play more in Europe,' but I don't think it's just this. We need to improve and be more calm sometimes, play situations better on the server. Everyone is good and has insane aim, these kinds of things, but sometimes we make some mistakes that the top 10 teams usually don't make. So we have to improve little things, but a lot of little things. It's like a puzzle, lots of little pieces. You have a team that doesn't necessarily have the most experience. What's it like for you leading a team with a couple of teenagers? For example there's snow who's barely played top CS. My feeling is always like I'm the father of the team, the daddy, and these kind of things. I'm always saying in my opinion what is wrong and right, and they always listen to me, so it's good. I'm very happy to be in a team like that, maybe I'm good with that role, so I like it. Throughout your career you've always been one of the best players on the teams you've played on. It's still the case now, for example in your last match you were the top player on the server, but it feels like you've got a lot of skill around you now. Does it feel like that, maybe there's a bit less pressure on you to frag every single game? Yeah for sure. To be on a team where everyone can shine all the time is good, because the pressure for me is just IGLing, not in the fragging. So for me it's a good thing.

header: Live updates from Shanghai Major RMR qualifiers
text: As the second day of the Oceania closed qualifier began, Vantage forfeited their lower bracket match against Mindfreak after being unable to field their full lineup. This has resulted in the team's elimination from the tournament. The Art of War and Arcade are playing in the lower bracket now, and soon Rooster will play TALON for a place in the grand final: Teams like Gods Reign, True Rippers, and Hansel "BnTeT" Ferdinand's Alter Ego are in play for a single Asia RMR spot in the Rest of Asia closed qualifier, which is just going live with the opening round of the double-elimination bracket: Over in East Asia, Temuulen "Zilkenberg" Battulga's Chinggis Warriors and another Mongolian challenger ATOX are among the favorites: As a result of Take Flyte utilizing an improper substitution in their elimination match versus Legacy, a Perfect World representative has confirmed with HLTV that the North American side has been disqualified from the RMR closed qualifier. The ruling amounts to very little practically, as Take Flyte fell to Legacy 1-2 prior to Perfect World's decision, eliminating them from the competition entirely. The representative clarified that Take Flyte's loss will be counted as a forfeit. Fluxo have beaten inSanitY in the 1-1 pool of the South America RMR closed qualifier to avoid an early elimination. Andrei "arT" Piovezan's side had their backs up against the wall after getting upset, alongside RED Canids and ODDIK, in their opening match, but have now earned a chance at qualifying for the RMR after securing wins over Dusty Roots and inSanitY. The match against the latter team saw Fluxo nearly fumble enormous 11-1 and 12-3 leads on Inferno, scraping the win in round 24, before closing the series out on Mirage after nearly letting another 12-5 lead slip. Nouns have locked in an Americas RMR berth after reverse-sweeping NRG in the 2-0 pool. Nick "nitr0" Cannella's side recovered from a 3-7 deficit on their pick of Anubis and won the map to start the series on good footing, but were obliterated on Ancient 13-6 and unable to overcome a formidable 1.80-rated and 27-14 K-D performance from Jeorge "Jeorge"  Endicott on the Mirage decider as Nouns closed out the series. Wildcard have locked in a spot at the Americas RMR in Shanghai after beating BOSS 2-0 in the first advancement match of the NA closed qualifier. The team around Peter "stanislaw" Jarguz has looked fearsome since adding Swedish duo Tim "susp" Ångström and Love "phzy" Smidebrant in July, and had little difficulty carving a path through the qualifier with one-sided wins over Mythic and E-Xolos LAZER before their win over BOSS. The second day of the NA RMR closed qualifier has begun with the two qualification games. Wildcard are playing against BOSS for an RMR spot, while Nick "nitr0" Cannella's NRG will meet Nouns. Later in the day, four best-of-three elimination matches are set to take place. 2-0 (qualification games) 1-1 (elimination games) BESTIA and Case have secured the first two Americas RMR spots avaliable after their respective wins over KRÜ and W7M in the 2-0 pool. The tournament has now moved to the 1-1 pool of matches, where the losers are set to be eliminated. The remaining teams are set to clash for the two remaining RMR spots: Six best-of-threes today in South America, with the winners of Case-W7M and KRÜ-BESTIA booking tickets to Shanghai. The losers of those 2-0 matches will then join the winners from the 1-1 games to form a brutal bracket where just two more slots will be decided from six 2-1 matches. 2-0 (qualification games) 1-1 record (elimination games) Steel Helmet, who made it to IEM Chengdu earlier in the year, are out of the Asian RMR closed qualifier in the first round after losses to TYLOO and Bromo. A disappointing outcome for veterans Hui "DD" Wu and Ke "captainMo" Liu. SHPL have also been knocked out of contention. The two favorites expected to fight for the single Asia RMR spot in Oceania's closed qualifier have so far delivered on their promise. Aaron "AZR" Ward's TALON and Rooster have reached the upper bracket final after cruising through the first two rounds. They will play a best-of-one against one another on Wednesday for a place in the grand final, where the team qualified for the Asia RMR will be decided on Thursday. Meanwhile, the first two elimination matches are about to go down in the land Down Under: The two highest-ranked teams in the Chinese closed qualifier have reached the upper final: TYLOO stomped Steel Helmet and Teamwork on the way, while Rare Atom went the distance against CatEvil. The first two elimination matches in the lower bracket are still due to be played before the first day of the qualifier draws to a close: One spot at the Asia RMR will be decided in each of the Chinese and Oceania closed qualifiers over the next three days. The competitions have just kicked off with names such as TYLOO and Rare Atom in play in China and Rooster and TALON in Oceania: The first two rounds of play concluded in the NA RMR closed qualifier with results going largely as expected, with the largest outlier being BOSS beating Legacy in the 1-0 pool to cast the Brazilian team down to the 1-1 elimination round. NRG, Nouns, and Wildcard join BOSS in the 2-0 advancement pool while LAG, Limitless, Phoenix, and Homyno had their runs ended early. The standings after day one can be found below: 2-0 advancement pool 1-1 elimination pool RED Canids have kept their Shanghai Major hopes alive after scraping together a reverse-sweep victory over Intense, losing Dust2 11-13 before edging out 13-11 and 13-10 wins on Mirage and Nuke. Fluxo and ODDIK, two other favorites who suffered early trips to the elimination round, bounced back with more confident wins over Dusty Roots and Vikings KR, respectively. Standings after day one: The second round of games in the North America RMR closed qualifier is about to get underway, with teams in the 1-0 pool facing off in best-of-ones before the four, best-of-three elimination matches in the 0-1 pool closes out the day. Outside of a close shave for NRG against Akimbo, the opening round of the NA RMR closed qualifier has gone as expected with all the favorites coming out on top. Notably, BOSS received a forfeit win after a member of Take Flyte got stuck in traffic and couldn't make it home in time for the start of his team's match. Favorites may have avoided each other in the second round of the South America RMR closed qualifier, but it still hasn't been smooth sailing for RED Canids. The team around Marcelo "coldzera" David and Henrique "HEN1" Teles dropped their opening best-of-one to Case, 11-13, and are now 0-1 down in their elimination best-of-three against Intense after another 11-13 loss. The same is the case for ODDIK, who lost their opening game in overtime and are now 0-1 down to Vikings KR. Andrei "arT" Piovezan's Fluxo, who also suffered an upset loss in their opening round, are faring better in their series against Dusty Roots in their own elimination match, while W7M, BESTIA, Case, and Max "bayKo" Bayko went 2-0 for the day and need to win just one best-of-three to make the RMR. The round-two matchups have been announced, and the favorites are set to avoid each other. The 0-1 pool is played in a best-of-three format, as teams get eliminated after two losses, while 1-0 games remain best-of-one. The full schedule is as follows: After some classic NA drama, the game has now gotten underway after a small 35-minute delay. Ryan "freakazoid" Abadir was nowhere to be found before Mythic's opening match against Wildcard. None of his teammates were able to reach the 31-year-old, and it looked like Mythic will need to forfeit the match. With just minutes to spare, Austin "Cooper" Abadir has now reached his brother, and the match might be happening after all. ODDIK, Fluxo, and RED Canids, the three highest-ranked squads at the closed qualifier, have all found themselves in the 0-1 bracket after opening losses. With just four RMR spots up for grabs, the trio is up against it early on. The second round will be drawn imminently and is set to begin at 21:00 . Two matches, two upsets at the Americas RMR closed qualifier, and the second and third highest-ranked squads find themselves in the 0-1 pool. Fluxo were bested by KRÜ in the opening match of the tournament, while Henrique "HEN1" Teles' RED Canids fell to Case in an 11-13 loss. The Americas closed qualifiers are kicking off today, starting with the South American side of things. The likes of Fluxo, Marcelo "coldzera" David's RED Canids, BESTIA and Sharks are in play among 16 teams who are fighting for just four spots at the Americas RMR. The first two rounds of the Swiss format will be played today, and the first-round matchups can be found below: A total of 40 teams from all over Asia, Oceania and Africa are now locked in to fight it out in five sub-regional closed qualifiers over the next four days. Only five of them will get to advance on the road to the Perfect World Shanghai Major and play in the Asia RMR in Shanghai at the beginning of November. Full story: After six teams were found via the open qualifier, the Rest of Asia closed qualifier team list has been finalized. These eight teams will play for one Asia RMR spot from August 28-30: It's a split down the middle between East Russian and Mongolian teams, who will fight it out for a single Asia RMR spot from August 28-30: Hansel "BnTeT" Ferdinand's Alter Ego are one of three teams to have advanced to the Rest of Asia closed qualifier after traversing the open qualifier without too much trouble. They're now playing for seeding in the closed qualifier, and they'll play for one Asia RMR spot there from August 28. Forward and Dewa United are also through so far, along with the invited Gods Reign and True Rippers, and three more spots will be decided over the course of the next few hours. IHC, -72c, THE and NomadS locked in four out of the five East Asia closed qualifier spots on offer in the open qualifier, joining Chinggis Warriors, ATOX and GR in the next stage. One more closed qualifier spot is up for grabs in the fifth-place decider bracket: The Rest of Asia region reached the quarter-final stage yesterday, most notably featuring Alter Ego, a team that boasts some well-known names: former TYLOO duo Hansel "BnTeT" Ferdinand and WingHei "Freeman" Cheung and ex-MVP PK member Hyun-Pyo "XigN" Lee. Six spots are up for grabs for the remaining eight teams in play today: The last stage of the final two open qualifiers for the Asia RMR are getting underway in the East and Rest of Asia regions. Five spots are on offer in East Asia, where NomadS already got a spot after Glamour had to forfeit the match due to not being able to field a full roster. The other three quarter-finals are live: The matches which will decide the replacement for the disqualified PARIVISION will be played on Tuesday, with KOI and Monte facing off first before the winner meets the highest-seeded BLEED: The East Asian qualifier has also reached the end of day one, with most of the favorites reaching the qualification matches. The exception are The Huns, who faltered in the first round in a 4-13 loss against horjoon. Five out of the remaining eight teams are set to secure East Asia RMR closed qualifier spots tomorrow. Two of the biggest names in the Rest of Asia qualifier have reached the quarter-final stage. NKT breezed through the competition to set up a qualification clash against Dewa United, while Alter Ego will face ONi for a closed qualifier spot tomorrow. BORING PLAYER have forfeited their qualification series against XNL due to a medical emergency affecting one of their players, with the team also unable to play in the fifth-place decider bracket as a result. This means XNL booked their spot in the closed qualifier, and that Steel Helmet get a bye to the lower-bracket qualification match, while kz5 and red demon will clash on the other side of the bracket. 29 teams have signed up to the Rest of Asia qualifier with the biggest names in the tournament being NKT and Forward, while Hyun-Pyo "XigN" Lee and Jane "aidKiT" Apostoloski have joined forces in Alter Ego. You can find the Rest of Asia bracket here. Over in East Asia, IHC and The Huns were the biggest favorites coming into the event, but the latter have already suffered elimination at the hands of horjoon. Other notable names include -72c, Clutch, and ARAVT. You can find the East Asia bracket here. The Chinese open qualifier is reaching the final stages, and the biggest name still in play, Steel Helmet, are up against the ropes after losing their quarter-final matchup against Bromo. They are still within a shot, as there are five closed qualifier spots on offer in China, but they will need to win the fifth-place decider bracket to advance. You can follow the bracket on HLTV. Today was a short day when it comes to HLTV's coverage of the road to the Shanghai Major RMRs. After the Oceania open qualifier found four teams advancing to the closed stage, only the massive Chinese open qualifier is still going on today. That will only be featured on HLTV from the quarter-finals, expected to be played tomorrow. We'll be back with that along with the other two Asia RMR open qualifiers due to take place tomorrow, in East Asia and Rest of Asia. After TALON, The Art of War, Vantage and Arcade came out on top in the open qualifier's quarter-finals, the Oceania closed qualifier teams are determined. These eight teams will fight for a single spot at the Asia RMR: The quarter-finals of the Oceania open qualifier have gone live with TALON fighting for one of four spots in the closed qualifier. Nemiga secured the final spot in the European RMRs after defeating Insilio in a three-map series. They join Rebels, Sashi, GamerLegion, TSM and B8 in making it out of the 2-2 pool. GamerLegion have secured a spot in the Europe RMRs after defeating BLEED 2-0 in the final Swiss round. Erik "ztr" Gustafsson's troops won both games in overtime, coming back from 12-3 down on Mirage to book a spot in Shanghai. It's a devastating blow for BLEED, who will once again miss a Major. TSM have locked up a place at the Europe RMRs after beating KOI in a 2-2 pool match. It's a heavy blow for the Iberian team, who reached the Copenhagen Major in February. KOI began their closed qualifier run by winning their best-of-one games but then struggled in the best-of-three series. Permitta's players will be kicking themselves after wasting three chances to qualify for the Europe RMRs. They won their opening two games but couldn't overcome the final hurdle as they lost three series against higher-ranked opponents, including fellow Polish side Rebels. OG, are out of the running for a spot at the Shanghai Major after losing to Sashi 0-2 in the final round of Closed Qualifier B. It's the second Major in a row that OG will miss. In the Copenhagen Major cycle, the team at least reached the RMRs before going 1-3 in Bucharest. OG got off on the wrong foot in their closed qualifier elimination series against Sashi as they were defeated 13-6 on Nuke, the Danish team's map pick. Philip "Lucky" Ewald was the star of the show as he put in a 2.24 rating, with only two of his 27 frags coming with the AWP. Next up is OG's map pick, Ancient. The 2-2 match-ups are: Group A Group B Two more teams have secured their places at the Europe RMRs with wins in the 2-1 pool of the closed qualifier, and there has been no shortage of surprises. Passion UA survived OG's comeback from down 2-10 on map two to win the series in three, and PARIVISION beat GamerLegion in another three-map series. OG and GamerLegion have one last chance to qualify in round five, played later today. With a 2-1 victory over BLEED, ECLOT are through to the Europe RMRs and become the second Czech core to qualify after SINNERS locked down their spot yesterday. It's last-chance saloon now for Aleksandar "kassad" Trifunović's BLEED, who will play in the do-or-die round five next in an hour's time or so. The Oceania open qualifier reached the quarter-finals earlier today. Among teams who made it are Aaron "AZR" Ward's TALON, who will be going up against SemperFi for one of the four closed qualifier spots on offer tomorrow: The next series of matches in the European closed qualifiers are getting underway. Playing in the 2-1 pool and fighting for a place at the RMRs are the likes of OG, BIG and GamerLegion. The pressure is on, as losers will have to play another series back-to-back in the last chance round five. With a loss to Rebels in the 1-2 pool, Johnny Speeds have been eliminated from the tournament. The Swedish side played the tournament with Sebastian "dex" Samuelsson after Hugo "chawzyyy" Günther was sidelined by personal issues, and entered the elimination zone early after losses to Cloud9 and ARCRED in the first two rounds. In the end, they were just one round away from making it to the 2-2 deciders but failed to convert a 12-8 lead on the final map against Rebels. After the 13-1 start on Ancient Monte couldn't close it out on their map pick, Anubis, which went the distance. But ultimately, it went the way of the Polish-majority squad on Mirage, as they turned a 7-5 lead on the CT side into a 13-7 victory in the decider. The Chinese open qualifier has begun today with a staggering 8,600 teams in attendance — a huge increase in interest ahead of China's home Major compared to the PGL Copenhagen qualifier, which had around 3,100 teams. The bracket is not publicly available outside of Perfect World's Chinese platform, but once it reaches the late stages in the next two days it will be featured on HLTV. The first matches of the day are over. B8 secured their survival in the closed qualifier over one of the weaker teams in the lineup, Rhyno, with a 2-0 victory, while TSM also made it past BC.Game in two maps. Qiang was also eliminated in two maps by Insilio, while the three other first round matches have gone to a third map. The Polish AWPer dominated ENCE in Monte's 13-1 victory on Ancient. Monte now head to their map pick, Anubis, up 1-0 in the series. Six teams with 1-2 records in the Europe RMR face off for survival. Most notably, Monte and ENCE will meet in a clash that will see one team go home and the other advance to the 2-2 pool. Johnny Speeds, who have been impressing locally in Sweden and online but went 0-2 while playing with a stand-in, are also fighting to make it to the round of decider matches after a victory over Zero Tenacity. They face Rebels. Group A Group B Insilio and Johnny Speeds have tallied wins in the 0-2 pool of RMR Qualifier B, besting AMKAL and Zero Tenacity, respectively, to stay alive heading into the final day of play. The Swedish team around William "draken" Sundin were blown out by Cloud9 and ARCRED in their opening best-of-ones and didn't look particularly convincing against Zero Tenacity, laboring to an overtime win on Mirage and 13-11 win on the Inferno decider largely thanks to 1.56 and 1.83-rated maps from Jonatan "bobeksde" Persson. AMKAL survived a messy affair against Ninjas in Pyjamas in BLAST Fall Showdown on Wednesday after edging out victory on Vertigo, and started their series against Insilio with another overtime win on the same map. That quickly gave way to blowouts on Nuke and Mirage, however, as Insilio romped to a reverse-sweep victory to advance to the 2-0 pool. ENCE hasn't had a pretty start to the RMR qualifier, falling to the 0-2 pool after losses to KOI and UNiTY, but early elimination has been avoided for now after Lukas "gla1ve" Rossander's side moved past Enterprise in a two-map series. TSM's Danish roster were in the same boat with one-sided defeats to BLEED and GamerLegion stinging their confidence, but a comfortable 2-0 over 1WIN offers some respite despite the team having their backs against the wall. It wasn't pretty, but Cloud9 did just enough to squeak past 9 Pandas and secure their RMR berth.
